questions.text: 1. Which investigation is done to visualise all individual layers of the retina in vivo?
questions.solution:
Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is done to visualise all individual layers of the retina in vivo.

OCT is a diagnostic tool that can give cross-sectional or tomographic images of the retina using light waves. OCT is a non-invasive, non-contact imaging system that gives optical access to the anterior and posterior segments of the eye. The images provided by OCT are akin to in vivo histopathology of the structure. OCT utilises interferometry and low-coherence light in the near infrared range.

An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below.



Other options:

Option B: Ultrasound B scan is used for assessment of the posterior segment in the presence of opaque media, study and localisation of intraocular tumours, orbital tumours, and other mass lesions. 

Option C: Fluorescein angiography is used to study the changes produced by various fundus disorders, using the flow of fluorescein dye along the vasculature of the retina and choroid.

Option D: Perimetry is used to detect visual field changes.

questions.text: 2. A woman came for preconception counselling who has a h/o epilepsy and is taking epileptic drugs, which anti epileptic drug is highly teratogenic?
questions.solution:
Valproate is an anti-epileptic drug that is highly teratogenic to the fetus.

Valproate is an anti-epileptic medication. It is also used as a mood stabilizer in manic episodes as well as in bipolar disorder. The repetitive firing caused by depolarization of cortical or spinal cord neurons is inhibited by valproate. It also prolongs the sodium channel inactivation. It can stimulate the activity of the GABA synthetic enzyme, glutamic acid decarboxylase, and inhibit GABA degradative enzymes.

It is highly teratogenic and can cause congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bififda), clefts, and cardiac anomalies. The intelligence quotient score of school-going children who were exposed in utero to valproate is found reduced. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children. Folate supplementation reduces the chances of neural tube defects. 

The side effects of valproate (mnemonic: VALPROATE)

* Vomiting

* Alopecia

* Liver toxicity

* Pancreatitis

* Rash

* Obesity

* Anorexia

* Teratogenicity

* Oedema

The images below show a baby and a USG with spinal bifida:





Other options: 

Option C: Oxcarbazepine can also cause fetal hydantoin syndrome and spina bifida, but the risk of teratogenicity is significantly lower than valproate. 

Option B and D: Lamotrigine and levetiracetam are considered safer anti-epileptic drugs in pregnancy, with low teratogenic risk when used at appropriate doses.

questions.text: 3. A 15-year-old boy presents with recurrent seizures. A CT done shows the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with CT showing ring-enhancing cystic lesions in the brain with an eccentric dot indicating scolex, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be neurocysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis is a form of cysticercosis caused by Taenia solium. It usually presents with seizures and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion.

Neurocysticercosis larvae can spread to the brain parenchyma, subarachnoid space and ventricles. The four stages of parenchymal neurocysticercosis are:

* Vesicular stage- This stage consists of a viable larva with a scolex (worm head). The cysts are thin-walled with no or little enhancement, and there is no perilesional oedema

* Colloidal vesicular stage- Ring-enhancing lesions with perilesional oedema and mass effect are seen

* Granular nodular stage- thick enhancing cyst walls and progressive surrounding oedema are seen

* Calcified nodular stage- The oedema resolves, and small calcified lesions of 2–10 mm diameter are seen

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma (parenchymal granulomas) can mostly occur at the junction of white and grey matter. On CT, they appear as small, rounded, solid lesions that show homogenous enhancement on contrast CT and show ring enhancement when central caseation or liquefaction occurs. MRI brain shows a conglomerate or lobulated irregular shape, ring-enhancing lesion.



Option C: Brain abscess is seen as a rim-enhancing lesion along with a history of fever.



Option D: Cerebral metastasis appears as solid rather than cystic masses.

questions.text: 4. At a PHC under Ayushman Arogya Mandir, a man presents with two successive BP readings of 140/94 and 152/92. What is the next step in management that the medical officer should do?

choices.text: Start Amplodipine 5mg OD for 1 month and then follow up
Do nothing and wait for BP to rise above 160/100 mmHg
Admit patient and start parental antihypertensives

questions.solution:
The medical officer should start Amplodipine 5mg OD for 1 month and then follow up.

Two successive BP readings of 140/94 and 152/92 suggest that the patient has Stage 1 Hypertension, as per JNC VIII guidelines. As per Ayushman Arogya Mandir, the patient should be started on treatment with ACEis/ARBs, calcium channel blockers or diuretics.

The aim of treatment should be to obtain a blood pressure below 140/90 mmHg, and ideally a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. Control of hypertension has been shown to reduce the incidence of stroke and other complications. 

Note: Ayushman arogya mandir uses Joint National Committee (JNC) - VIII guidelines for diagnosing and grading hypertension. European Society of Cardiology (ESC) 2024 guidelines for hypertension states Office BP of SBP ≥ 140 mmHg or DBP ≥ 90 mmHg is diagnosed as hypertension.

questions.text: 5. Quartiles, Deciles and Percentiles are measures of
questions.solution:
Quartiles, Deciles and Percentiles are measures of Location.

Quartiles divide the data into 4 equal parts. Centiles divide data into 100 equal parts. Deciles divide data into 10 equal parts.



Pearl PM1085: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

* They are also referred to as fractiles.

* Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.

* The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

Types of quantiles:

* Tertiles divide a distribution into 3 equal groups

* Quartiles divide it into 4 equal parts or quarters

* Quintiles divide a distribution into 5 equal groups

* Deciles divide a distribution into 10 equal parts

* Vigintiles divide it into 20 equal groups

* Centiles:

* They are also called percentiles and are commonly used, especially for ranking marks in an exam.

* They divide a distribution into 100 equal parts. Here, the median is the same as the 50th percentile.

* The formula to arrive at the rank order of a value is R = P/100 x (n + 1), where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

Pearl PM0967: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics | Definition | Examples Measures of Location or Central Tendency | These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations. | Mean, median, mode Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread | These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed. | Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation Measures of Position | These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set. | Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

6. Match the tests with the organisms:

1. Eleks test | a. Streptococcus pneumoniae 2. Coagulase test | b. Vibrio cholerae 3. String test | c. Cornyebacterium diphtheriae 4. Quellung test | d. Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The correctly matched tests with the organisms are 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a   Test name | Organism 1. Eleks test | c. Cornyebacterium diphtheriae 2. Coagulase test | d. Staphylococcus aureus 3. String test | b. Vibrio cholerae 4. Quellung test | a. Streptococcus pneumoniae

In Elek's gel precipitation test, a rectangular strip of filter paper impregnated with Cornyebacterium diphtheria antitoxin is placed on the surface of a horse serum agar in a petri dish while the medium is still fluid. The plate is incubated at 37°C for 24-48 hours. Toxins produced by the bacterial growth will diffuse in the agar and, where it meets the antitoxin at optimum concentration, will produce a line of precipitation. The presence of such arrowhead lines of precipitates indicates that the strain is toxigenic. No precipitate will form in the case of non-toxigenic strains.



Staphylococcus aureus is coagulase positive. The coagulase test can be done using two methods:

* The tube test detects free coagulase. When 0.1 mL of an agar culture suspension of S. aureus is added to 0.5 mL of human or rabbit plasma in a test tube with an anticoagulant and incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 3–6 hours, the plasma clots and does not flow when the tube is tilted. This shows a tube coagulase-positive test. 

The below image shows positive and negative tube coagulase tests:



* The slide test detects bound coagulase (clumping factor). The bacterial isolate is emulsified with a drop of saline and added to a drop of rabbit or human plasma. A prompt clumping of the cocci is suggestive of a positive test. It should be performed after ensuring the absence of autoagglutination and can be positive for S. aureus and for a few strains of coagulase-negative staphylococcus. 

The string test is performed to identify Vibrio cholerae as shown in the image below. To perform the string test, a loopful of the bacterial culture is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The bacterial cells of Vibrio cholerae are lysed by sodium deoxycholate, causing the suspension to lose its turbidity and become mucoid. A string is formed when the loop is drawn away from the suspension.



Quellung reaction also called as Neufeld reaction is used to identify capsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae. When a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears 'swollen' due to an increase in its refractivity. This capsule swelling or Quellung reaction was described by Neufeld (image below).

questions.text: 7. A 30-year-old woman presents for infertility workup. Laparoscopic Chromopertubation shows normal tubes and dye spills freely. What is the most likely cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infertility due to PCOS and the image shows bilateral enlarged ovaries with a smooth and thickened capsule on laparoscopy. 

In PCOS, macroscopicaly both ovaries are enlarged. The ovary shows a thick white capsule of tunica albuginea. The ovarian surface may be lobulated but the peritoneal surface is free of adhesions. Multiple cysts ( 12 or more) of 2-9 mm size are located peripherally along the surface of the ovary giving it a 'necklace' appearance on ultrasound. These are persistent atretic follicles. Theca-cell hyperplasia and stromal hyperplasia account for the increase in the size of the ovary which amounts to more than 10 cm3 in volume.

As per the new International Evidence-based Guidelines for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023, these three factors should be considered accurate ultrasound markers for PCOS in adults:

* Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) ≥ 20 in at least one ovary 

* If an accurate follicle count is not possible: Follicle number per cross-section (FNPS) ≥ 10 in at least one ovary, or 

* Ovarian volume (OV) ≥ 10 ml

Laparoscopy is reserved for a therapeutic purpose. ln most cases diagnosis can be confirmed on ultrasound.

Other options:

Option A: A tubo-ovarian mass (usually from infection or chronic inflammation) would likely distort pelvic anatomy and obstruct the tubes, and dye would not spill freely during chromopertubation.

Option B: Most ovarian cysts, especially functional or benign types, are typically unilateral and don’t typically cause the bilateral enlargement with thickened capsules seen in PCOS. Besides, PCOS is a leading and more common cause of infertility than ovarian cysts.

Option D: Endometriosis often presents with pelvic adhesions, endometriotic implants, or endometriomas, which would be visible during laparoscopy. The smooth ovarian surface and absence of lesions point against it.

questions.text:
8. Which of the statements is true about lumbar puncture?

1. LP is urgently indicated if the CT scan is negative in suspected SAH 2. Post-dural puncture headache is common in females and older adults 3. Meningitis after LP is an unusual side effect 4. LP is safely done in thrombocytopenia more than 10000
questions.solution:
Lumbar puncture (LP) is urgently indicated if the CT scan is negative in suspected SAH, and meningitis after LP is an unusual side effect are the correct statements.

Statement 1: LP is urgently indicated if the CT scan is negative in suspected SAH. It helps to establish the presence of subarachnoid blood. Lysis of the red blood cells and subsequent conversion of haemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 hours. This xanthochromic spinal fluid peaks in intensity at 48 hours and lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.

Statement 3: Meningitis after LP is an unusual side effect, as all aseptic precautions are taken while performing it. Meningitis presents with symptoms such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and often a rash, indicating a possible bacterial cause. When evaluating such patients, it is crucial to perform a lumbar puncture to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Other statements:

Statement 2: Post-dural puncture headache is common in young females. It is generally due to continued epidural leakage of CSF from the dural puncture site.

Statement 4: LP is safely done in thrombocytopenia, more than 10000 is incorrect. Performing a lumbar puncture in patients with thrombocytopenia increases the risk of bleeding. Lumber puncture should be done in patients with an adequate platelet count (>20 x 109/L) and without clinical haemorrhages.

Pearl PM0446: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

* May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).

* Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.

* Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.

* Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.

* Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

* Supine position

* IV fluids

* Caffeine and analgesia

* Epidural blood patch

questions.text: 9. A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of breast swelling. Her histopathology and mammography findings are shown below. Her aunt developed breast cancer in her 30s. She has a younger sister, 29 years of age, who requires genetic testing. However, she can only afford one test. Which test should be done?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing ducts lined with pleomorphic cells and desmoplastic stromal reaction and microcalcifications on mammography suggests a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma. A BRCA1 genetic test should be done.

The BRCA1 genetic mutation accounts for most of the familial breast cancers and hence must be preferred in this case.

The image below shows ducts lined with pleomorphic cells and a desmoplastic stromal reaction in infiltrative ductal carcinoma.



Other options:

Option A: PTEN mutation is associated with Cowden syndrome.

Option C: CDH mutation is associated with Lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Option D: TP53 mutation is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

Pearl PM1878: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases. | BRCA 1 | BRCA 2 Location | Long arm of chromosome 17 | Long arm of chromosome 13 Differentiation | Poorly differentiated | Well-differentiated Hormone receptor status | ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative | ER/PR- Positive Associated Cancers | Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers | Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma Male breast carcinoma | Low risk | Increased risk Fanconi’s anemia | Not associated | Associated Medullary carcinoma | Associated | Not associated

Pearl PM1183: Cowden Disease

Autosomal dominant

* Hamartomas of all three embryonal cell layers

* Facial trichilemmomas – most common feature.

* Cancer of the

* Skin disease – acral keratosis.

questions.text: 10. Which of the following is not a risk factor for recurrent nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Hypercitraturia is not a risk factor for recurrent nephrolithiasis.

Urine citrate is a natural inhibitor of calcium-containing stones, and hence, lower urine citrate excretion increases the risk of stone formation. Citrate reabsorption is determined by the intracellular pH of proximal tubular cells. Citrate excretion gets reduced in metabolic acidosis due to an increase in the reabsorption of filtered citrate.

Hypercalciuria increases the formation of calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones, and hyperoxaluria increases the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Hyperuricosuria is a risk factor for uric acid stone formation, which is found in individuals with excess purine consumption and rare genetic conditions that lead to overproduction of uric acid.

Higher dietary calcium intake is related to a lower risk of stone formation. This may be due to a reduction in intestinal absorption of dietary oxalate, resulting in lower oxalate levels in the urine. Low calcium intake is contraindicated as it increases the risk of stone formation. Supplemental calcium may increase the risk of stone formation. Higher intake of animal protein leads to increased excretion of calcium and uric acid, as well as decreased urinary excretion of citrate, resulting in increased risk of stone formation.

Many potassium-rich foods increase urinary citrate excretion due to their alkali content. Dietary factors such as magnesium and phytate have been inconsistently associated with lower stone risk.

questions.text: 12. In a PHC, a researcher measures the weight of a group of 100 patients with Diabetes Mellitus and follows up after 6 months to provide nutritional counselling. A medical researcher goes back and takes the data to perform a statistical significance testing. What test can be used to analyse the weight difference?
questions.solution:
Paired T-test can be used to analyse the weight difference.

The researcher measures the weight of a group of 100 patients with Diabetes Mellitus, which signifies a quantitative variable. The researcher follows up with the same group after 6 months to provide nutritional counselling, which signifies a comparison of a before-and-after scenario. Hence, the Paired T-test must be used in this case.

Pearl PM1104: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

* See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?

* If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.

* If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

* If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

* If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

* Unpaired t tests

* Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.

* It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.

* Paired t tests

* "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"

* So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 

* Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.

* It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.

* It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

* T scores 

* The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.

* The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

* The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

3. Chi-Square Test

* The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

* It is a test of proportions and associations.

* A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.

* If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: 13. All the following follow BNS (Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita) section 116 for grievous hurt, except:
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, severe body pain for 5 days is not an included under grievous hurt, but any hurt that causes the sufferer to be in severe body pain for 15 days is considered to be grievous hurt.

Grievous hurt (Section 116, BNS) is inflicted voluntarily on another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

Clause 1 — Emasculation. (Option B) Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.  Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear. Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint. Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.  Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face. Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth. (Option A and C) Clause 8 — Any hurt that endangers life or causes the sufferer to be in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits for 15 days.

Related BNS sections:

Section 114 of BNS: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt. Section 115 of BNS: Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person is said “voluntarily to cause hurt” and shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both. Section 116 of BNS:  Describes the eight clauses of grievous hurt (mentioned above). Section 117 of BNS: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt and if the hurt which he causes is grievous hurt, is said “voluntarily to cause grievous hurt” and shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

questions.text: 14. A 70-year-old lady with Parkinsonism suffers from aspiration pneumonia, with 3 episodes for the past 6 months. X Ray shows bibasilar bronchiectasis. Moderate oropharyngeal dysphagia is present, and had a poor cough reflex. What is the best appropriate step for long-term prevention of recurrent aspiration pneumonia?

choices.text: Nebulization with N-acetyl cysteine to reduce secretions
Azithromycin for antibacterial prophylaxis and prokinetic effect.

questions.solution:
PEG gastrostomy tube insertion is the best appropriate step for long-term prevention of recurrent aspiration pneumonia.

Chronic neurological disorders, such as Parkinson’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, can present with oropharyngeal dysphagia. For nutritional support, feeding through a nasogastric tube may be considered. However, it do not protect against the aspiration of saliva or refluxed gastric contents. So, Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) is a commonly used method for insertion of a gastrostomy tube in patients with swallowing disorders. It helps in the prevention of aspiration in patients with recurrent pneumonia. 

A PEG tube does not irritate the nasal mucosa. The tube is less likely to become displaced, and hence the feed can be given more reliably. It takes approximately 10 days for a fibrous tract to form around the PEG tube, and if the PEG is displaced or removed during that time, there is a high risk of peritonitis.

Other options:

Option A: High-frequency chest wall oscillation involves an inflatable vest that is attached to a machine. The machine mechanically performs chest physical therapy by vibrating at a high frequency. The vest vibrates the chest to loosen and thin mucus.

questions.text:
15. A woman presents to you for a routine pap smear. Arrange the steps involved in the correct order:

1. Lithotomy position 2. Per speculum examination 3. Scraping of cells using Ayer's spatula 4. Per vaginal examination
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the procedure involved in the collection of a sample for a pap smear is 1, 2, 3. 

The Pap/Papanicolaou smear is used for screening cervical neoplasia.

Procedure:

* The patient is put in a lithotomy position with the labia are parted (Statement 1)

* Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is gently introduced with the use of lubricant or jelly (Statement 2)

* The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula (Statement 3)

* Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush

* Samples are spread separately on two different glass slides

* The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol

* Stained with Pap stain or short stain

Per vaginal examination (Statement 4) is not part of the routine pap smear procedure. In fact, the Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination, because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report, lubricant may prevent detection of organisms and any vaginal bleeding during examination may preclude a proper visualization of the cervix.

questions.text:
16. A 4-year-old child presents with difficulty opening the mouth and tonic spasms in the limbs. The child gives a history of CSOM. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

CSOM- Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with difficulty opening the mouth (trismus) and tonic spasms in the limbs, with a history of CSOM, suggests the most likely cause to be Tetanus.

Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, which is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming rod whose spores are highly resilient and can enter the body through abrasions, wounds, or the umbilical stump, in the case of neonates. It releases tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin), an exotoxin that enters the nervous system and causes disease.

The most common initial symptoms are trismus (lockjaw), muscle pain and stiffness, back pain, and difficulty swallowing. As the disease progresses, muscle spasm develops, and the laryngeal muscles are involved in early stages, leading to airway obstruction.

Generalised muscle spasms involve muscles of the entire body and are painful. Towards the second week of tetanus, autonomic disturbances are maximal as evidenced by gastrointestinal stasis, sweating, increased tracheal secretions and cardiovascular events like blood pressure fluctuations and heart block can occur. The diagnosis of tetanus is based on clinical findings. 

Other options:

Option A: Bezold abscess can occur due to mastoiditis following CSOM and leads to pain, fever, a tender swelling in the neck, and torticollis.

Option C: Meningitis is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media. There is fever with chills and rigours, headache, neck rigidity, photophobia, nausea and vomiting. It can also lead to cranial nerve palsies and hemiplegia. 

Option D: Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis is characterised by Hectic Picket-Fence type of fever with rigours and headache.

questions.text: 17. A 28-year-old woman who has been breastfeeding her 6-month-old baby presents with tenderness and mild erythema of the breast. She was breastfeeding normally. Imaging shows a hypoechoic, irregular mass. Core biopsy shows cystic spaces surrounded by neutrophils. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism in this clinical context of a breastfeeding woman with breast tenderness, erythema, and a hypoechoic irregular mass on imaging, plus histology showing cystic spaces surrounded by neutrophils, is characteristic of granulomatous mastitis, which can be caused by Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii. 

Granulomatous mastitis is a benign, self-limiting, inflammatory breast disease that was earlier considered idiopathic. A distinct histological pattern, termed cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis (CNGM), is believed to be caused by Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii. This condition primarily occurs in young women who are parous, typically manifesting within the initial few years postpartum. It manifests as one or more inflammatory breast masses (central or peripheral), which may or may not progress to form an abscess. It may be associated with skin ulceration, nipple retraction, sinus formation, peau d’orange, and axillary lymphadenopathy. 

A needle biopsy of a solid mass establishes the diagnosis of IGM. Histologically, CNGM often shows lipogranulomas with cystic spaces and neutrophilic infiltrates. In symptomatic patients and in those with infection, treatment with NSAIDs and antibiotics with or without drainage is indicated. In cases of persistent symptoms or progression, treatment with prednisolone (oral or topical) with or without methotrexate has helped in regression of IGM. A major milk duct excision is indicated in patients with a mammary duct fistula. Excision of chronic abscess cavities is performed in patients with recurrence.

Other options:

Option A: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a close differential, but histology should show caseating granulomas, which is not the case here. However, to rule out TB, along with histopathology, evidence on imaging, microbiological analysis, and GeneXpert is required to establish a diagnosis. 

Option C: Cryptococcus neoformans is more common in immunocompromised patients, shows yeast on biopsy, and does not typically cause neutrophil-rich cystic lesions.

Option D: Corynebacterium minutissimum usually causes erythrasma, a superficial skin infection, and not deep granulomatous mastitis.

questions.text: 18. The term Z- plasty refers to
questions.solution:
The term Z- plasty refers to flap transposition and lengthening scar

Z-plasty is a type of transposition flap that incorporates qualities of both advancement and rotation flaps. Z plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. In this technique, two flaps are rotated, each into the donor site of the other, to rearrange the tissues in a way that redirects the lines of tension and lengthens the central limb. It is best used in releasing simple contractures.

Usually, all the limbs are of equal length and ideally, the angle between them is 60°. Two triangular flaps are raised. Theoretically, a 60-degree angle flap will result in a 75% increase in the length of the scar and a 90-degree reorientation of central wound.

Angles smaller than 60 degrees are easier to transpose but result in less lengthening and realignment of the scar to less than 90 degrees. Angles larger than 60 degrees should be avoided because the force required to transpose the flaps increases markedly, making the closure of the wound difficult. 

Relative contraindications to Z-plasty include patients with keloids and hypertrophic scarring tendencies.

questions.text:
19. An obese individual with a weight of 90kg takes a high-carbohydrate diet . Which enzymes are most responsible for weight gain?
* Malonyl-CoA
* Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
* Mitochondrial Carnitine transporter
* Tricarboxylate transporter
questions.solution:
The enzymes responsible for weight gain in this patient are Malonyl-CoA, Acetyl CoA carboxylase and Tricarboxylate transporter (Options 1, 2, 4). 

An obese individual on a high-carbohydrate diet will experience increased lipogenesis (fat synthesis) which would involve the following enzymes: 

* Malonyl-CoA: The initial step in fatty acid synthesis is the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase. It is a key intermediate in fatty acid synthesis.

* Acetyl-CoA carboxylase: It is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis. It converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, thus promoting lipogenesis.

* Tricarboxylate transporter: It transports citrate from mitochondria to cytoplasm. In the cytoplasm, citrate is cleaved to oxaloacetate and acetyl CoA by the enzyme, ATP citrate lyase.

Mitochondrial carnitine transporter is involved in fatty acid oxidation, not synthesis. It helps transport fatty acids into mitochondria for breakdown. Its role is reduced, not promoted, in weight gain.

Pearl PM0638: Biosynthesis of Fatty acids

1. Cheeks and mouth are full

2. More areola is visible below than above its mouth

questions.solution:

21. For a 65-year-old female with an adnexal mass, CT was done, which showed ascites. What are the true statements regarding the given specimen?

1. Sex-cord stromal tumour  2. Call-Exner bodies 3. Inhibin positive  4. CA-125 level raised
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a female with an adnexal mass, CT indicating ascites, histopathology showing call-exner bodies and the gross image are suggestive of granulosa cell tumour, an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumours made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time, it is seen in post-menopausal women. These tumours are usually unilateral. Hormonally active tumours have a yellow colouration due to intracellular lipids that can be seen on their cut surfaces. On histopathology, Call-Exner bodies are seen, which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

Granulosa cell tumours sometimes secrete large amounts of estrogen, and they may behave like low-grade malignancies. Functionally active granulosa cell tumours in prepubertal girls may produce precocious sexual development. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. Androgens may be produced sometimes by granulosa cell tumours which cause virilization of the patient. All granulosa cell tumours are potentially malignant. The most common mutations are found in the FOXL2 gene.

Statement 4: CA-125 levels are raised in Surface Epithelial-Stromal tumours.

questions.text: 22. All are thermal dimorphic fungi except
questions.solution:
All are thermal dimorphic fungi except Cryptococcus neoformans.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi are:

* Blastomyces dermatitidis

* Coccidioides immitis

* Paracoccidioides brasiliensis

* Penicillosis marneffei

* Sporothrix schenckii

* Histoplasma capsulatum

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: 24. An 8 year old is on Carbamazepine 800 mg OD daily. She took Erythromycin 1g OD daily for 2 days. Now, she has developed imbalance and gait ataxia. What can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The child has developed carbamazepine toxicity due to a drug interaction with Erythromycin.

Carbamazepine is metabolized by the liver enzyme CYP3A4, and erythromycin is a known inhibitor of this enzyme. When both drugs are taken together, erythromycin inhibits the metabolism of carbamazepine, leading to elevated blood levels of the anticonvulsant. This results in symptoms of toxicity such as imbalance and gait ataxia, which are classic signs of carbamazepine toxicity.

Epilepsy relapse typically presents with seizures, and hypersensitivity reactions manifest as rash, fever, or organ involvement, which are not seen here. Since the child was stable on carbamazepine before starting erythromycin, the sudden appearance of neurological symptoms points to drug-induced toxicity rather than other causes. 

The following precipitant drugs inhibits metabolism by CYP3A4 and causes toxicity of object drug. Concurrent use should be avoided or dose of object drug should be adjusted.  Precipitant drug | Object drug * Erythromycin

* Clarithromycin

* Ketoconazole

* ltraconazole

* Fluconazole

* Protease inhibitors | * Phenytoin

* Carbamazepine

* Warfarin

* Sulfonylureas

* Diazepam

* Theophylline

* Cyclosporine

* HIV protease inhibitors

* Statins

questions.text: 25. A middle-aged lady choked while eating fish and has associated symptoms of choking, hoarseness of voice and foreign body sensation in the throat. On examination, the fish bone was lodged in the pyriform fossa. What is the nerve responsible for irritation?

choices.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of Superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is responsible for irritation.

The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve runs submucosally in the lateral wall of the pyriform sinus. Foreign bodies may lodge in the piriform fossa and cause irritation. The nerve is easily accessible for local anaesthesia, and it is through this nerve that pain is referred to the ear in carcinoma of the piriform sinus.

Pyriform fossa lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the oesophagus and forms the lateral channel for food. It is bound medially by the aryepiglottic fold, the posterolateral surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. It is bound laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text:
26. A four-year-old child presents with difficulty in walking, a broad-based gait, and inability to perform heel-to-toe walking. The child was clingy towards his mother. On examination, the child is hyperreflexive, and the Babinski sign is positive. What could be the probable diagnosis?

ADEM- Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of difficulty in walking, a broad-based gait, and inability to perform heel-to-toe walking, hyperreflexive, and positive Babinski sign suggests a clinical diagnosis of Spastic diplegic type of Cerebral palsy. 

Spastic diplegia involves bilateral spasticity of the legs that is greater than in the arms. Spastic diplegia occurs due to the injury to the immature white matter during the vulnerable period of immature oligodendroglia between 20 and 34 weeks of gestation, hence seen in those born prematurely. It is often noted when an affected infant begins to crawl. The child uses the arms normally but tends to drag the legs behind more as a rudder, like a commando-crawl, rather than using the normal four-limbed crawling movement.

Examination of the child reveals symmetric spasticity in the legs with brisk reflexes, ankle clonus, and a bilateral Babinski sign. Walking can get significantly delayed, the feet are held in a position of equinovarus, and the child walks on tiptoes. In older children, a scissoring gait is characterized by the knees and thighs pressed together or crossing each other while walking, caused by high muscle tone (spasticity) in the hip adductors.



The subtypes of cerebral palsy and the pathology involved are given below: Cerebral palsy subtype | Pathology Spastic diplegia | Periventricular leukomalacia Spastic quadriplegia | Multi-cystic encephalomalacia Spastic hemiplegia | Middle cerebral artery territory infarction Dyskinetic cerebral palsy | Basal ganglia

Other options:

Option A: Guillain-Barré syndrome causes acute flaccid paralysis. It generally follows 1-6 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. The clinical features include an acute onset of bilaterally symmetrical ascending weakness without any features suggestive of CNS involvement.  

Option C: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an immune-mediated cerebral inflammation following viral exanthem or vaccination. Patients present with altered consciousness, convulsions and multifocal neurological signs affecting the cerebellum, optic nerves, long tracts and spinal cord. Fever may be absent at the time of onset of the disease.

Option D: Spinal cord lesion leads to clumsy gait, foot deformity, bladder dysfunction, or stunted limb growth.

questions.text: 27. The use of MgSO4 has all of the following benefits except
questions.solution:
The use of MgSO4 provide neuroprotection for the foetus, can prevent seizures and prevent placental abruption. Increase in renal perfusion is not a proven effect of MgSO4. 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4) is shown to have anticonvulsant and neuroprotective effects by the following mechanisms: 

* It reduces presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate

* It blocks the glutamatergic N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors

* It can potentiate  adenosine action

* It improves calcium buffering by mitochondria

* It blocks calcium entry via voltage-gated channels

Magnesium sulphate is the drug of choice in the management of eclampsia to control convulsions.It can be used to prevent seizures and can signifcantly lower risk of eclampsia. Even the rates of placental abruption are seen to decrease in women who recieved magnesium sulpate.

It can also have a protective effect against the development of cerebral palsy in very-low birthweight newborns. Hence it is also used for neuroprotection for the fetus less than 32 weeks.

Impaired renal function is a contraindication for MgSO4. However, its effect on renal perfusion is not entirely clear. Some studies report it can decrease renal plasma flow or glomerular filtration rate, while others suggest it may enhance perfusion and exert renoprotective effects, depending on context and dosage. Among the given options, the role of magnesium sulphate in increasing renal perfusion is not well proven and hence, is the correct answer here.

questions.text: 28. Dura when inflamed under the part marked by the arrow gets the referred pain at:
questions.solution:
The part labelled in the image is the posterior cranial fossa. When dura of the posterior cranial fossa gets inflamed, there is referred pain at the back of head and neck region. 

The cranial dura mater is innervated mainly by branches of the three divisions of the trigeminal nerve, namely:

* Ophthalmic division (V1)- tentorial branch

* Maxillary division (V2)- nervus meningeus medius

* Mandibular division (V3)- nervus spinosus

The nerve branches supplying the dura mater in each cranial fossa are:



However, the posterior cranial fossa also gets sensory supply from the C2, C3 fibres distributed by hypoglossal nerve and C2 fibres distributed by vagus nerve. These sensory nerve endings are confined to the dura mater and cerebral blood vessels, and are absent in the brain parenchyma itself, as well as in the arachnoid and pia mater. Stimulation of these dural nerve endings can lead to headache or pain, often perceived in distant areas due to referred pain mechanisms.

Since the skin over the back of the neck and scalp is innervated by the medial branches of the dorsal rami of C2 (greater occipital nerve) and C3 (third occipital nerve), inflammation of the dura in the posterior cranial fossa may produce referred pain to these cutaneous areas — the back of the head and neck.

questions.text: 29. The hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient in case of severe diarrhoea is due to

choices.text: Decreased reabsorption of sodium from kidney
Decreased absorption of sodium from the gut

questions.solution:
The hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient in case of severe diarrhoea is due to increased secretion of Anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). 

Anti-diuretic hormone, also known as Vasopressin, gets activated in severe diarrhoea, leading to dilutional hyponatremia due to increased water reabsorption from the kidneys. In severe diarrhoea, there is hyponatremia due to increased loss of sodium through faeces, leading to decreased absorption of sodium from the gut.

The body also tries to maintain homeostasis by activating the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone system (RAAS), leading to increased secretion of aldosterone, which further leads to an increase in sodium reabsorption from the kidneys.

Note: Among options B and C, the best answer is Option C, as it is a more primary mechanism for maintaining homeostasis of water and electrolytes.

questions.text: 31. Upon gastric lavage of a poison, the lavage turned out black with AgNO3. Which of the following agents can cause this?
questions.solution:
In aluminium phosphide poisoning, upon gastric lavage the lavage turns out black with AgNO3. 

Aluminium phosphide (ALP) is used as a pesticide, insecticide, and rodenticide with a garlicky odour. Silver nitrate paper test is used to detect aluminium phosphide poisoning. 

* When ALP comes in contact with moisture, it releases an active component called phosphine.

* When the silver nitrate-impregnated filter paper, comes in contact with phosphine the paper turns black in colour.

* The test is done in two methods: a. Gastric aspirate: 5 mL of gastric aspirate and 15 mL of water are put in a flask and the mouth of the flask is covered with silver nitrate-impregnated filter paper. The flask is heated at 50°C for 15 to 20 minutes. If the filter paper turns black, it indicates the presence of phosphine. b. Breath: The patient is asked to breathe in and out through a face mask which is impregnated with silver nitrate. If the face mask turns black, it indicates the presence of phosphine. The breath test is positive only if the patient ingests more than 6 grams of aluminium phosphide.

Phosphine is a toxic agent which acts by inhibiting the electron transport resulting from preferential inhibition of cytochrome oxidase. It is a systemic poison and affects all organs of the body. The presence of HCl in the stomach accelerates this reaction. Aluminium phosphite and Aluminium hypophosphite are non-toxic agents. 

Signs and symptoms include irritation of mucous membranes and acute respiratory distress in mild toxicity. Moderate toxicity produces ataxia, numbness, tremors, muscular incoordination and paralysis. Severe toxicity produces ARDS, cardiac arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, pulmonary oedema, convulsions and coma. Cardiogenic shock is the most common cause of death and is associated with higher mortality(35%- 100%). 

There is no specific antidote. Gastric lavage should not be done with warm water as on coming in contact with water, aluminium phosphide releases phosphine and increases the concentration of toxic agent phosphine. So it is done with potassium permanganate and activated charcoal. Magnesium sulphate is used to correct hypomagnesemia, arrhythmias and reduces organ toxicity. Supportive measures to treat acidosis, shock and hemodialysis can be done.

questions.text:
32. Which of the following methods are used to identify different mutated strains of same species of Mycobacterium tuberculosis? 
* Restriction fragment length polymorphism                    
* Chromosome mutation detection                      
* Spoligotyping                        
* Mycobacterial interspersed repetitive units (MIRU-VNTR)
questions.solution:
Different mutated strains of same species of Mycobacterium tuberculosis can be detected by all the mentioned methods - restriction fragment length polymorphism, chromosome mutation detection, spoligotyping and mycobacterial interspersed repetitive unit (MIRU-VNTR) typing.          

TB bacilli have been classified into 4 phage types: types A, B, C, and I (intermediate). Most typing methods currently are based on DNA fingerprinting, which is a powerful epidemiological tool for differentiating between strains of tubercle bacilli.

* Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism with IS6110 probe which is a is a repetitive insertion sequence is currently used for molecular typing of Mycobacteria. Restriction endonuclease cleavage yields nucleic acid fragments containing this sequence and the lengths of these fragments are strain specific.

* Spoligotyping (spacer oligotyping) is based on polymorphism in the direct repeat (DR) locus. This is a region present in all Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains. It is more useful in strains that have no or very few copies of IS6110.

* Mycobacterial interspersed repetitive units - Variable number of tandem repeats (MIRU-VNTR) is slowly replacing IS6110 typing. It is a PCR‑based method that makes use of the length variation at 12 independent minisatellite-like loci scattered throughout the Mycobacterium tuberculosis genome. 

* Genotyping for chromosome mutation detection is also be done in some laboratories.

questions.text: 33. What is the earliest manifestation of Multiple Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Sensory loss is the earliest manifestation of Multiple Sclerosis. 

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. The common symptoms of multiple sclerosis are as follows:

* Sensory symptoms - paresthesia (tingling sensations, pins and needles sensation), hypesthesia (numbness)

* Optic neuritis - decreased visual acuity and colour perception, unilateral/ bilateral, visual blurring

* Limb weakness - spastic paralysis, gait disturbances, Babinski's sign positive

* Facial weakness

* Vertigo

* Ataxia

* Hearing loss 

* Bladder dysfunction

* Lhermitte's sign (shooting pain down the back on neck movement)

* Uhthoff's sign (worsening of neurological symptoms on exposure to elevated temperatures, eg, hot shower)

MRI is the imaging modality of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity. It shows finger-like periventricular and callosal lesions, perpendicular to the ventricular surface (Dawson fingers).

34. Match the diseases with the vectors:

questions.text:
35. Which of the following anaemias responds to erythropoietin?

1. Aplastic anaemia  2. Nutritional anaemia  3. Anaemia of chronic kidney disease 4. Anaemia of Myelofibrotic disorder
questions.solution:
Anaemia of chronic kidney disease responds to erythropoietin.

Erythropoietin (EPO) is useful in anaemia of chronic kidney disease and anaemia of inflammation, in which endogenous EPO levels are inappropriately low. The usual dose of EPO is 50–150 U/kg three times a week intravenously in patients with chronic kidney disease. Most of the patients respond, and haemoglobin levels of 10–12 g/dL are usually reached within 4–6 weeks if iron levels are adequate. The EPO dose can be decreased once a target haemoglobin level is achieved.

Serum erythropoietin levels are typically appropriate for the severity of anemia in patients with myelofibrosis. Patients with inappropriately low serum erythropoietin levels (<125 U/L) considering their degree of anemia can benefit from erythropoietin treatment.

Thus, Anaemia of chronic kidney disease and Anaemia of Myelofibrotic disorder can respond to erythropoietin.

Other statements:

Statement 1: Aplastic anaemia requires haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Statement 2: Nutritional anaemia responds to supplementing the deficient nutrients such as folic acid, iron and vitamin B12.

questions.text: 36. All are correct regarding juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, except
questions.solution:
Biopsy done under local anaesthesia is incorrect statement.

Biopsy of the tumour leads to profuse bleeding and is, therefore, avoided. If it is essential to differentiate it from other tumours, biopsy can be done under general anaesthesia with all arrangements to control bleeding and transfuse blood. 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumour exclusively in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms an angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend from its origin into the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits, and intracranial cavity, resulting in clinical features such as proptosis and frog-face deformity. The clinical features include:

* Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common

* Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to a mass in the postnasal space

* Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube

* Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx

* Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves

Diagnosis is mostly based on clinical and imaging studies. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign), which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.



Digital subtraction angiography shows the extent of the tumour with its vascularity. Surgery is the treatment of choice. Embolisation of the vessels can be done before surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

questions.text: 38. In most cases of endemic and familial multinodular goitre, excess iodine intake can cause signs of thyrotoxicosis. What is this effect known as?
questions.solution:
This effect is known as Jod–Basedow effect which is characterized by iodine induced hyperthyroidism.

In patients with goitre, excessive thyroid hormone synthesis can be caused by increased iodine exposure either as a dietary supplement or as contrast medium, resulting in signs of thyrotoxicosis. It is due to overactivation of the thyroid gland or autonomous nodules within the gland after iodine repletion without adequate feedback control from the pituitary gland. This phenomenon do not occur in individuals with normal thyroid gland. The Jod-Basedow effect is named after "jod", the German word for iodine, and Carl Adolph von Basedow, the German physician who first described the effect.

Other options: 

Option A:  Wolff–Chaikoff effect is iodine-induced suppression of the thyroid gland. In individuals with a normal thyroid, excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification and thyroid hormone production. However, in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease, the suppressive action of high iodide may persist. Clinical relevance: The Wolff–Chaikoff effect has been used as a treatment principle against thyroid storm by infusion of a large amount of iodine to suppress the thyroid gland.

Option C: Pemberton phenomenon refers to the appearance of neck vein distention and difficulty breathing when a person with a large retrosternal goiter raises their arms, due to compression caused by the mass in that position.

Option D: Grave's effect typically refers to the systemic effects caused by Graves' disease, which is an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
39. A 42-year-old man noticed a slow, progressive, painless plaque on the side of the neck. He did not complain of any other systemic signs and symptoms. Which of the following tests are useful in this case?

1. HIV 2. Skin biopsy 3. KOH mount 4. Chest X-ray
questions.solution:
Skin biopsy and Chest X-ray are useful in this case.

The above clinical scenario of a slow, progressive, painless plaque on the side of the neck and the characteristic reddish-brown nodules, plaques, and ulcers with variable scarring and a serpiginous edge are suggestive of lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitised individuals. 

Skin biopsy is usually helpful, but since the quantity of bacilli encountered in cutaneous lesions is small, stains for acid-fast bacilli are usually negative. A chest X-ray will help to analyse the pulmonary involvement.

Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It can also occur over a primary site of inoculation, such as the site of scrofuloderma scar, BCG vaccine, and after a tattoo. 

It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion are often serpiginous in shape and heal with scarring. In India, the buttocks and trunk are more frequently involved. In Europe, most of the lesions are present on the head, neck, and face. The diascopy of lesions reveals diagnostic apple jelly nodules.

Polymerase chain reaction has been successfully used to confirm the diagnosis. Standard multidrug therapy for tuberculosis is used for the treatment. Isoniazid monotherapy is not given anymore due to the emergence of isoniazid-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

The image given below shows lupus vulgaris.

questions.text: 40. A 36-year-old male with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presented with cervical pain and myelopathy. Which of the following is the most probable cause?

choices.text: Compression fracture of cervical vertebral body
Degeneration of cervical spine facets due to Osteoarthritis

questions.solution:
Atlanto-axial subluxation is the most probable cause in this patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, presenting with cervical pain and myelopathy.

Atlantoaxial involvement of the cervical spine can lead to compressive myelopathy and neurologic dysfunction. Neurological manifestations are rarely a presenting sign or symptom of atlantoaxial disease, but they may evolve with progressive instability of C1 on C2. The prevalence of atlantoaxial subluxation has been declining in recent years and occurs now in a lesser number of patients.  Rheumatoid arthritis rarely affects the thoracic and lumbar spine.

In the initial stages of rheumatoid arthritis, the small joints of the hands and the feet are most frequently involved. These most frequently include the wrist, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) in the upper limb, and metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints in the lower limb. Note that distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) involvement is not seen in RA and usually represents coexistent osteoarthritis.

The patients complain of early morning joint stiffness lasting for more than an hour, which improves with activity. As the disease progresses, the following deformities may be seen:

* Trigger finger occurs due to tenosynovitis of the flexor tendons

* Ulnar deviation of the hand occurs due to MCP joint subluxation

* Swan-neck deformity occurs due to hyperextension of the PIP and flexion of the DIP

* Boutonnière deformity occurs due to flexion of the PIP and the hyperextension of the DIP

questions.text:
41. Which of the following are true regarding benzodiazepines and barbiturates:

1. Both act on GABA-A chloride channel                           2. Alcohol causes superadded CNS depression                   3. Flumazenil reverses the action of both                     4. Thiopentone has short duration of action due to its rapid metabolism
questions.solution:
Both statements 1 and 2 are correct regarding benzodiazepines and barbiturates

Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates act on the GABA-A chloride channel, but at different sites (Statement 1). Benzodiazepines facilitate the action of GABA by increasing the frequency of opening of the GABA-mediated chloride channel. Examples include alprazolam, clonazepam, lorazepam, midazolam, etc. On the other hand, barbiturates facilitate the action of GABA by increasing the opening duration of the GABA-mediated chloride channel. Examples include amobarbital, phenobarbital, butabarbital, and pentobarbital. Alcohol can cause superadded CNS depression when combined with either drug, increasing the risk of respiratory depression (Statement 2).

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site of the GABA-A receptor. Flumazenil reverses the effects of benzodiazepines only, not barbiturates (Statement 3). No specific antidote exists for barbiturates, and overdose treatment includes supportive care and urinary alkalinization.

Thiopentone has a rapid onset of action because of its lipophilic nature, so it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters highly perfused organs like the brain, heart, liver, and kidneys. As thiopentone redistributes from the brain to tissues, it perfuses to muscle, fat, and skin. Over time, due to its high lipid solubility, thiopentone accumulates maximally in fat. Fat acts as a storage reservoir since it has low blood flow, and drug release from fat occurs slowly. This redistribution reduces the concentration of thiopentone, terminating its anaesthetic effect. Hence, thiopentone has a short duration of action due to its redistribution, not rapid metabolism (Statement 4).

questions.text: 42. While analysing the prevalence of a disease in some regions, you divide patients into three groups (low, medium and high burden). It is followed by selecting one from each. What type of sampling is this?
questions.solution:
This is a type of Stratified random sampling since the population is divided into homogeneous groups, or strata, and then from these strata, random samples are drawn.

Other options:

Option C: Convenience sampling is a type of non-probability sampling. Convenience sampling involves selecting respondents who are readily available to the researcher. There is no pattern whatsoever in acquiring these respondents.

Pearl PM1146: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

* In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.

* Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.



2. Stratified random sampling

* In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.

* For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.



3. Cluster sampling

* In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.

* In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.

* This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.

* This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.

* Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.

* Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.



4. Systematic random sampling

* In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.

* For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: 44. Identify the carcinoma most commonly associated with the following finding.
questions.solution:
The given image shows lytic lesions in the skull. Follicular thyroid cancer is most commonly associated with it.

Follicular thyroid cancer spreads hematogenously to bone, lungs, liver, and other parts of the body. Hence, it can lead to lytic lesions in the skull.

Other options:

Option A: Hurthle cell thyroid cancer is a variant of Follicular thyroid cancer, but Follicular thyroid cancer has a greater chance of leading to lytic lesions in the skull.

Option B: Papillary thyroid cancer leads to lymphatic metastasis and doesn't spread to bones hematogenously.

Option D: Thyroid Lymphoma can lead to lymphatic metastasis and doesn't spread to bones hematogenously.

Pearl PM2122: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

* Encapsulated

* Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid

* Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy

* Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

Pearl PM2118: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

* Branching papillae 

* Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk

* Psammoma bodies

* Nuclear changes- 

* Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei

* Pseudo-inclusions

* Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: 45. Which of the following strains of HPV are more commonly responsible for cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18 are considered high-risk types that are commonly implicated in cervical cancer.

HPV 16 and 18 can also lead to vulvar cancer. Condyloma acuminata (venereal warts) is commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11. However, rarely can HPV 16 and 18 cause it, too. 

The E6 protein of high-risk types binds to the p53 gene, while the E7 protein inactivates the pRb gene. p53 and pRb are tumour suppressor genes that, when inactivated, result in uncontrolled cell proliferation. The presence of koilocytes is a histopathological marker of the virus. These cells have a perinuclear halo in the cytoplasm, and these cells disappear when dysplasia advances.

questions.text:
46. A 19-year-old girl presents with irregular menstrual cycles. According to the Modified Rotterdam criteria, which of the following are diagnostic for PCOS?

1. Obesity 2. Delayed periods 3. Hirsutism 4. Insulin resistance
questions.solution:
According to the Modified Rotterdam criteria, delayed periods and hirsutism are diagnostic for PCOS. 

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. For the diagnosis of PCOS, the modified Rotterdam criteria are generally followed. It states that at least two of three criteria should be present. These criteria are as follows:

* Irregular menstrual cycles characterised by oligomenorrhoea of cycles >35 days apart or <8 menses a year or amenorrhoea or anovulation  infertility

* Hyperandrogenism which can be clinically detected as hirsutism / acne with a modified Ferriman–Gallwey score of ≥4 to ≥8 or biochemically detected by elevated total or free testosterone. DHEAS (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate)and ANSD (androstenedione) can be consdered. 

* Ultrasound finding of enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume of more than 10 mm3 with 12 or more small follicles, each 2-9 mm in size, placed peripherally. ≥20 follicles per ovary in either ovary or ≥10 cm3 ovarian volume

The new International Evidence-based Guidelines for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023 supersede the previous USG recommendations of the Rotterdam criteria. According to this guideline, these three factors should be considered accurate ultrasound markers for PCOS in adults:

* Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) ≥ 20 in at least one ovary 

* If an accurate follicle count is not possible: Follicle number per cross-section (FNPS) ≥ 10 in at least one ovary, or 

* Ovarian volume (OV) ≥ 10 ml

The ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery:



Pearl PM1151: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

* Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.

* LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.

* Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.

* Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)

* Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor

* DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated

* DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour

* Serum SHBG is reduced.

* Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.

* Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance

* Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases

* Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases

* Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)

* 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

* Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Pearl PM1152: Management of PCOD

Complaint | Management Irregular periods | OCPs Obesity | Lifestyle modification Insulin resistance | Metformin Hirsutism /acne | OCPs with cyproterone acetate Infertility | Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: 47. A 65 year old female presents with recent-onset constipation and blood in stools. She reports a history of altered bowel habits. Colonoscopy reveals a superficial lesion located 6 cm from the anal verge. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma confined to the mucosal layer of the colon, with no evidence of invasion and no lymph node involvement. What is the TNM staging of the tumor?
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the described tumor is Stage 0. 

According to the TNM classification, the tumor is confined to mucosa, i.e., not invading the submucosa. Hence it can be classified as Tis (Tumor in situ). There is no regional lymph node involvement, hence N0 and no distant metastasis, hence M0. So the TNM classification is Tis N0 M0. According to the AJCC staging, Tis N0 M0 corresponds to Stage 0.

questions.text:
48. Identify the true statement regarding free radicals :

1. Lipid peroxidation of membrane lipids  2. Produced by neutrophils and involved in the respiratory burst 3. Superoxide dismutase inactivates free radicals  4. Occurs in fibrinoid necrosis
questions.solution:
1, 2, and 3 are the correct statements.

Free radicals can cause peroxidation of lipids within plasma and organellar membranes, in the presence of O2. Oxidative damage begins when the double bonds in unsaturated fatty acids of membrane lipids are attacked by O2-derived free radicals, particularly by OH. The lipid–free radical interactions yield peroxides, which are themselves unstable and reactive, initiating an autocatalytic chain reaction known as propagation that can result in extensive membrane damage.

Reactive oxygen species are produced by the rapid assembly and activation of NADPH oxidase, which oxidises reduced NADPH and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion. This oxidative reaction is triggered by activating signals accompanying phagocytosis in neutrophils and is called the respiratory burst.

Superoxide dismutase inactivates free radicals and acts as an antioxidant by converting hydrogen peroxide to oxygen.

questions.text: 49. What is the Alvarado score for a patient presenting with fever, nausea, migratory right lower quadrant pain, rebound tenderness, and a white blood cell count greater than 14,000 cells/mm³?
questions.solution:
The Alvarado (MANTRELS) score for this patient is 6:

* Migratory right iliac fossa pain - 1

* Anorexia - 0 (Absent)

* Nausea / vomiting - 1

* Tenderness in right iliac fossa - 0 (Absent)

* Rebound tenderness - 1

* Elevated temperature - 1

* WBC count > 14,000 cells/mm i.e. Leukocytosis - 2

* Shift to the left of neutrophils - 0 (Absent)

Several clinical and laboratory-based scoring systems have been devised to assist in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis. The most widely used is the Alvarado (MANTRELS) score.

questions.text: 51. The CT scan of a 26-year-old who presented with complaints of diarrhoea for 6 months is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with chronic diarrhoea and CT showing ahaustral colon (black arrows) with engorgement of mesenteric vessels (white arrows) points towards the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that usually involves the rectum and extends proximally to involve all or part of the colon, leading to pancolitis. Loss of haustrations in the colon occurs in severe disease. Clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhoea (often with blood), rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus.

In mild inflammation, the mucosa is erythematous with a fine granular surface that resembles sandpaper, while in severe disease, the mucosa is haemorrhagic, edematous, ulcerated and can also lead to pseudopolyps as a result of epithelial regeneration in longstanding disease.

On barium studies, the lead pipe appearance refers to the complete loss of haustral markings in the affected section of the colon, which appears smooth-walled and cylindrical, resulting from chronic inflammation.

CT/MRI features of ulcerative colitis include:

* Loss of haustrations

* Lead-pipe colon appearance

* Bowel wall thickening

* Mucosal hyperenhancement

* Luminal narrowing

* Pericolonic fat stranding

* Pseudopolyps

* Mesenteric vessel engorgement

Other options:

Option B: The terminal ileum is dilated with a patulous ileocaecal valve and a contracted caecum is seen on CECT in tuberculous colitis. Ascites, peritoneal involvement, and lymphadenopathy can also be seen. Central caseous necrosis in lymph nodes appears hypoechoic on ultrasound and shows peripheral enhancement on CT or MRI.

Option C: Crohn's disease shows discrete ulcers with skip lesions, giving a cobblestone appearance. The ileocaecal valve is affected and can be enlarged.

Option D: Pseudomembrane colitis imaging shows a grossly thickened wall, which shows marked mucosal enhancement and is hypodense in the submucosa due to oedema. This produces a target sign, which is described as the ‘accordion sign’.
