questions.text: 52. A young female presents with Septic shock. She has been treated with 30ml/kg crystalloids IV Fluids, however, her MAP stays at 56. Which of the following would be the next best step in management for her?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine is recommended as the first-choice vasopressor in the management of hypotension in a patient with septic shock, and will be the next best step in management. 

Sepsis is defined as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection and is diagnosed by the presence of infection with an increase of 2 or more points according to the SOFA score. Septic shock is diagnosed when a patient has sepsis, along with the requirement of a vasopressor to maintain mean arterial pressure at 65 mm Hg and serum lactate > 2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation.

Management of sepsis includes:

* Early initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics and cardiorespiratory resuscitation to prevent further organ failure due to infection and hypoperfusion

* A blood sample should be sent for cultures before antibiotics are initiated, but empirical antibiotic therapy should be started within the first hour

* Aggressive administration of intravenous fluids should begin within the first three hours, and crystalloids are given at 30 mL/kg

* Norepinephrine is the recommended first-choice vasopressor, and the target mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 65 mmHg, which should ideally be monitored by an arterial catheter

* Sepsis-associated ARDS should be managed by mechanical ventilation with a target tidal volume of 6 ml/kg with high PEEP

* Other general considerations include prophylaxis against thromboembolism unless contraindicated, stress ulcer prevention using antacids, blood glucose management, and renal replacement therapy in case of AKI

Other Options:

Option A: Vasopressin is used only to reduce the norepinephrine dose.

Option C: Dopamine should only be used in specific situations, such as in patients with a risk of tachyarrhythmia or relative bradycardia.

Option D: Corticosteroids 200mg STAT is not the initial choice to manage the patient.

Pearl PM1636: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

* Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count

* Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation

* Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)

* Hepatic function - Bilirubin

* Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

* Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg

* Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min

* Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

* SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.

* qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

* Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 OR

* Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: 53. The murmur of mitral stenosis corresponds to which part of the ECG?
questions.solution:
The murmur of mitral stenosis corresponds to the P wave of the ECG.

Mitral stenosis leads to increased pressure in the left atrium. Left atrial abnormality may cause broad, notched P waves in the limb leads and a biphasic P wave in lead V1 with a prominent negative component representing delayed depolarisation of the left atria.

P wave may become tall and peaked in the lead II and upright in lead V1 due to severe pulmonary hypertension or when tricuspid stenosis complicates mitral stenosis, leading to right atrial enlargement. The QRS complex is usually normal. In severe pulmonary hypertension, right axis deviation and RV hypertrophy can be seen. 

Auscultatory findings in mitral stenosis are:

* A mid-diastolic murmur

* The first heart sound (S1) is accentuated

* The opening snap (OS) is after the A2 sound. It is best heard during the expiration and at the apex of the heart

* The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur, which is heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position. This murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis.

questions.text: 54. Which one of the following is the action of the muscle attached in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the lateral pterygoid plate and the muscle attached to it is the lateral pterygoid muscle, whose function is depression of the mandible. 

Lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Actions of the lateral pterygoid muscle are:

* Depresses the mandible (opens the mouth)

* Protrudes the mandible forward

* Side-to-side movements (for grinding action)

questions.text: 55. A 62-year-old male with AKI after cardiac surgery was admitted to the ICU with declining urine output. The intensivist administers fenoldopam intravenously. How does this drug help in improving renal function in this patient?

choices.text: Dopamine 1 receptor agonism  causing dilation of afferent and efferent arterioles by increasing GFR
Beta 2 adrenergic receptor agonism casuing bronchodilatation
Dopamine 2 receptor antagonism  reducing sympathetic outflow

questions.solution:
Fenoldopam improves renal function by dopamine-1 receptor agonism causing dilatation of afferent and efferent arterioles, increasing GFR. 

Fenoldopam is a D1 agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and acts as a rapid-acting vasodilator. It also binds to α2 adrenergic receptors. It dilates coronary arteries, the efferent and afferent renal arterioles and mesenteric arteries. Adverse effects include headache, flushing and dizziness.

It has no significant affinity for D2 receptors or α1 or β adrenergic receptors.

questions.text:
56. The Bezold-Jarisch reflex typically leads to

1. Hypopnea 2. Bradycardia 3. Hypotension  4. Tachycardia
questions.solution:
The Bezold-Jarisch reflex typically leads to hypopnea, bradycardia and hypotension.

The Bezold–Jarisch reflex is a cardiovascular response triggered by chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the heart and lungs, leading to profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea, followed by rapid, shallow breathing. It can be activated by substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. and serotonin or during myocardial ischemia and coronary angiography, contributing to hypotension in heart disease. It also serves a protective role by limiting toxic substance absorption from the lungs.

This reflex can be activated during myocardial ischemia and reperfusion because of increased production of oxygen radicals and by agents used as radiocontrast for coronary angiography. Activation of cardiopulmonary chemosensitive receptors may also be part of a defence mechanism protecting individuals from toxic chemical hazards, and it may help reduce the amount of inspired pollutants that get absorbed into the blood. This protects vital organs from the potential toxicity of these pollutants and facilitates their elimination. Vasovagal syncope has also been attributed to activation of the Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

questions.text: 58. A 45 year old male with chronic malnutrition is being treated with Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN). 24 hours after the initiation of TPN, he develops hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia. Which of the following best describes the reason for this?

choices.text: Insulin causes the influx of K+, Mg²⁺, PO₄³⁻ into the cell

questions.solution:
The electrolyte abnormalities in the context of total parenteral nutrition are indicative of refeeding syndrome which is best described by insulin causing the influx of K+, Mg²⁺, PO₄³⁻ into the cell.

Refeeding syndrome is a metabolic complication that can occur in patients who are severely malnourished and are rapidly reintroduced to nutrition. This occurs due to increased insulin secretion from acute carbohydrate introduction.

This is due to a shift from catabolism to anabolism, which leads to a number of metabolic changes. One of these changes is increased insulin secretion. This increase in insulin promotes glycogenesis, protein synthesis and also activates the sodium-potassium ATPase symporter, leading to movement of potassium into the cells Magnesium and phosphate are also taken up similarly, which can lead to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia. Additionally, insulin can inhibit the kidneys' ability to reabsorb phosphate, which can lead to hypophosphatemia - the hallmark of refeeding syndrome. Hyperglycemia is seen due to the acutely increased body insulin production not being able to keep up with the rapidly increasing blood sugar levels. 

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to: Starvation, Alcoholism, Delayed nutritional support, Anorexia nervosa, Massive weight loss in obese patients

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention of refeeding involves correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance, administering thiamine and increasing calorie intake gradually.

Options A, B and C: The other answer choices are incorrect because they do not explain the metabolic changes that lead to refeeding syndrome.

questions.text:
59. Which of the following statements is true regarding Bempedoic acid:

1. It is a dicarboxylic acid 2. It inhibits cholesterol biosynthesis 3. It is a non-competitive inhibitor of ATP citrate lyase 4. It is used in dyslipidemia resistant to diet and high-dose statin therapy
questions.solution:
The true statememts about bempedoic acid are statements 1, 2, 4. 

Bempedoic acid, a dicarboxylic acid and a new class of cholesterol-lowering drugs approved by the FDA in 2020, acts by inhibiting de novo hepatocyte cholesterol biosynthesis. 

Bempedoic acid is a competitive inhibitor of ATP citrate lyase and thereby reduces de novo hepatic cholesterol synthesis by reducing the flow of acetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA reductase. Its mechanism of action complements statins and other agents that lower LDL-C. Bempedoic acid’s cholesterol-lowering effects are thus additive with those of statins The drug is approved as an adjunct to diet and maximally tolerated statin therapy to further lower LDL-C and hence, can be is used in dyslipidemia resistant to diet and high-dose statin therapy. A fixed-dose combination of bempedoic acid and ezetimibe can also be used. Bempedoic acid also has application in patients who are statin-intolerant. 

Side effect of bempedoic acid are hyperuricemia (thought to be due to competition for OAT2 in the kidney) that can increase the risk of gout. Other adverseeffects include tendon ruptures and increased serum creatine kinase, creatinine, and hepatic transaminases

questions.text: 60. What is odd according to the statistical parameters paired with the phenomena represented?
questions.solution:
Mean, median; dispersion is the incorrect pair. Mean and median are the measures of central tendency.

Other options:

Option B: Standard error is a measure of variability.

Option C: Correlation coefficient is a measure of relationship.

Option D: Moments are a measure of Skewness. Moments are statistical parameters that describe the shape of a distribution, with Kurtosis being a specific moment that measures the tailedness or peakedness of a distribution.

Pearl PM1089: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

* Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.

* Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):

* This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.

* Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.

For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.

* Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:

* The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)

* Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape

* Assuming all samples are identical in size

* The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 

* Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):

* The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

* Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 

* More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 

SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations. | Mean, median, mode Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread | These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed. | Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation Measures of Position | These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set. | Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

* Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship

* Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

questions.text: 61. Which is the most commonly inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most commonly inherited bleeding disorder.

VWD is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF). VWF is an adhesive protein that promotes the adhesion of platelets to subendothelial collagen and stabilises factor VIII. Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosomal recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (type 1 and type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2). The majority have type 1 disease. 

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilia A is the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding.

Option B: Factor V deficiency is a cause of a rare bleeding disorder, known as parahemophilia or Owren disease.

Option D: DIC is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder characterised by the excessive activation of coagulation and formation of thrombi in the microvasculature.

questions.text:
62. Complete clinical cure for malaria can be achieved by?

1. Artemesin 2. Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine 3. Chloroquine 4. Primaquine
questions.solution:
Complete clinical cure for malaria can be achieved by Artemisin, Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine and Chloroquine.

Artemisin is used for the treatment of severe P. falciparum malaria and is also effective against the asexual erythrocytic stages of P. vivax. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are used in which the rapid-acting and rapidly eliminated artemisinin component is paired with a slower-acting and slower-eliminated partner drug with a distinct antiparasitic mechanism of action. Such an approach is required because artemisinins, when administered alone, require more than 7 days of therapy to eliminate parasites, but when paired with an effective partner, the duration of treatment gets reduced.

Chloroquine is highly effective against the erythrocytic forms of P. vivax, P. ovale, P. malariae, P. knowlesi, and chloroquine-sensitive strains of P. falciparum. Chloroquine rapidly controls the clinical symptoms and parasitemia of acute malaria. Most patients become completely afebrile within 24 to 48 hours after receiving therapeutic doses. Sulfadoxine is a slow-acting blood schizonticide and is more active against P. falciparum than P. vivax.

Primaquine, in contrast to other antimalarials, acts on exoerythrocytic tissue stages of Plasmodium spp. in the liver to prevent and cure relapsing malaria. Primaquine is primarily used for terminal chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale (relapsing) infections due to its high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of these Plasmodium species. It also has gametocytocidal activity against P. falciparum and other Plasmodium species. However, primaquine is inactive against asexual blood-stage parasites, rendering it unsuitable as the principal treatment for an acute episode of malaria.

questions.text:
65. Which among the following are incorrect about tension pneumothorax?
* Occurs due to improper dressing of open wound
* Blunt trauma with simple pneumothorax can never convert to tension pneumothorax
* The single most common cause is due to positive pressure in mechanical ventilation 
* Can be caused due to spinal injury
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 3 are incorrect about tension pneumothorax. 

A tension pneumothorax develops when a ‘one-way valve’ air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the afected lung. Common causes of tension pneumothorax are penetrating chest trauma, blunt chest trauma with a parenchymal lung injury and air leak that did not spontaneously close, iatrogenic lung injury (e.g. due to central venepuncture) and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation. 

If an open pneumothorax is improperly dressed (e.g., complete occlusion of the chest wall defect without a tube thoracostomy) it may convert into a tension pneumothorax (Statement 1).

A simple pneumothorax from blunt trauma can progress to a tension pneumothorax, especially if untreated or if on positive pressure ventilation (Statement 2).

Positive pressure in mechanical ventilation is a common cause of tension pneumothorax since it can cause elevation in the trans-alveolar pressure which results in alveolar rupture and leakage of air into the extra-alveolar tissue, but it is not the single most common cause of tension pneumothorax (Statement 3). 

Tension pneumothorax is a rare and life-threatening complication that can be caused due to spinal injury (Statement 4).

questions.text: 67. What is the diagnosis based on the given diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given diagram is Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO).

The site of the lesion in the case of INO is the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). As seen in the image above, on the left gaze, there is impaired adduction of the right eye and nystagmus on the abduction of the left eye. This means that the lesion is in the right MLF, leading to a defect in left gaze. The right gaze is normal. In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on abduction on the contralateral side.

When the gaze is initiated, the horizontal gaze centre or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements. The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus, which causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye. The second output is to the MLF, which sends an impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus, causing contralateral adduction. These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side. 

The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above.





Features of unilateral INO include

* Straight gaze in the primary position of the eyes

* Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye, with the contralateral eye having nystagmus on abduction

* Looking at the ipsilateral side has no gaze issues

* Convergence may be intact if the lesion is anterior and discrete.

Bilateral INO would present with a limitation of ipsilateral adduction and nystagmus of the contralateral eye on both sides. A few causes of INO include demyelinating diseases (such as multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barré syndrome), strokes, and tumours.

Other options: 

Option B: 3rd nerve palsy leads to ptosis. Eyeball is turned down, out and slightly intorted due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.

Option C: Horizontal gaze palsy occurs due to a lesion of the horizontal gaze centre in the PPRF, leading to ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, with an inability to look in the direction of the lesion.

Option D: Thyroid eye disease is characterised by lid retraction, lid lag, and proptosis.

questions.text: 69. What is the following phenomenon seen?

The image shows the satellitism phenomenon which is shown by Haemophilus influenzae when streaked along with Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar.

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative, non-motile, and non-sporing coccobacillus. H.influenzae causes meningitis, a potentially fatal disease that is most common in children of two months to 3 years old. It also causes laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, suppurative lesions, and bronchitis.

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well-developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus which becomes smaller farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus, which is required for the growth of H. influenza.

questions.text:
70. In the glycine titration curve, find the zwitter bionic pH:

pK1 = 2.4 pK2 = 9.8
questions.solution:
The zwitter bionic pH of glycine is 6.

The zwitter bionic pH, also known as the isoelectric point (pI), is the pH at which an amino acid carries no net electrical charge. At this point, the molecule exists as a zwitterion - a form that has equal positive and negative charges, typically with a protonated amino group (-NH₃⁺) and a deprotonated carboxyl group (-COO⁻).

For simple amino acids like glycine, which have only two ionizable groups (carboxyl and amino), the isoelectric point is calculated as the average of the two pKa values:

pI = ( pK1 ​+pK2 ) / 2

​​Given:

pK1 = 2.4 (carboxyl group) pK2 = 9.8 (amino group)

pI = (2.4+9.8) / 2 = 12.2/2 = 6.1, which is closest to 6 (Option A).

At pH 6.1, glycine is in its zwitter bionic form and has no net charge.

questions.text: 71. During the Mahakumbh mela, the government set up health care camps and mobile medical units for surveillance. A syndromic surveillance is done for fever, diarrhoea, and respiratory symptoms. What is the primary reason to do this?

choices.text: To confirm individual diagnosis with additional tests
For immediate quarantine of symptomatic individuals
To detect warning signs of disease outbreak

questions.solution:
The primary reason to do this is to detect warning signs of a disease outbreak.

Mobile Medical Units (MMU) provide a range of healthcare services for people living in remote, inaccessible, unserved, and underserved areas in both rural as well as urban areas, intending to take healthcare services to the doorsteps of such people. This initiative is covered under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP).

IDSP (formerly known as the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project) is a national, decentralised, state-based surveillance program. The mission is to detect early warning signals for timely and effective public health action so that it can be initiated against outbreaks of prone diseases in both urban and rural areas. It also provides essential data to monitor ongoing disease control programs. 

The program includes a Central Surveillance Unit, State Surveillance Units, and District Surveillance Units, and collects weekly disease surveillance data on epidemic-prone diseases from reporting units such as hospitals and medical colleges. The data is analysed for disease trends and investigated by a Rapid Response Team consisting of specialists whenever there is a rising trend of illness.

The surveillance is necessary to recognise cases or clusters of cases, assess the public health impact of health events, demonstrate the need for public health intervention programs, monitor the effectiveness of prevention and control measures, and identify high-risk groups or geographical areas for targeted interventions.

Other options:

Option A: Confirmation of individual diagnosis with additional tests is done at the level of healthcare centres.

Option B: To reduce the medical personnel is incorrect as MMU itself includes a team of medical personnel.

Option C: Isolation is done for symptomatic individuals and not quarantine. Hence, this statement is wrong.

questions.text: 72. How many cycles of PCR is required to generate half the copies of 26 cycles?
questions.solution:
25 cycles of PCR is required to generate half the copies of 26 cycles. 

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a method used to amplify specific DNA sequences. It involves repeated cycles of denaturation, annealing, and extension. In each cycle, the amount of DNA doubles, leading to exponential amplification.

So after n cycles, the number of DNA copies is 2n . 

After 26 cycles, the DNA is amplified to 226 copies. To find how many cycles are needed to produce half this amount (x), 

2x = 1/2 × 226 =225 

So, x = 25. Therefore, 25 cycles are required to produce half as many DNA copies as 26 cycles.

PCR’s rapid and specific amplification relies on heat-stable DNA polymerases and specific primers that flank the target DNA sequence. Its applications include genetic diagnostics, forensic testing, and infectious disease detection.

questions.text: 73. During the recording of the EEG, a resting and awake person was instructed to close his eyes and then open them. The dominant wave which decreases on opening the eyes is?
questions.solution:
The dominant wave, which decreases on opening the eyes, is the Alpha wave.

A resting and awake person, when closes his eyes and then opens them to focus attention on something, the alpha rhythm gets replaced by an irregular, low-voltage beta rhythm. This phenomenon is known as alpha block. This can be produced by any form of sensory stimulation or mental concentration, such as solving arithmetic problems.

This is also known as the arousal or alerting response because it is correlated with the aroused, alert state. It has also been called desynchronization because it represents the breaking up of the synchronised neural activity necessary to produce regular waves. However, the term desynchronization is misleading because the rapid EEG activity seen in the alert state is also synchronised, but at a higher rate.

questions.text:
75. Which of the following is true regarding snake bite?

1. Elapidae is myotoxic  2. Viperidae is vasculotoxic 3. Hyaluronidase is secreted by all snake toxins 4. Toxins travel through lymphatics and superficial veins
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, 4 are true regarding snake bites.

Venomous snakes may be commonly divided into: 

* Viperidae (Russell's viper, Saw scaled viper): Venom is mainly vasculotoxic and hemolytic and causes intravascular haemolysis and depression of the coagulation mechanism. It can produce changes in the nervous system as well, but vasculotoxic effects exceed the neurotoxic effects. (Statement 2)

* Elapidae (Cobras, kraits): Venom is mainly neurotoxic, and has a primary toxicity for the respiratory and cardiac centres. Neurotoxic features are due to selective d-tubocurarin-like neuromuscular blockade which results in flaccid paralysis of muscles. It can also produce marked cardiac or vascular changes, or have a direct effect on the blood, but neurotoxic effects exceed vasculotoxic effects. (Statement 1)

* Hydrophidae (Sea snakes): Venom is myotoxic.

Snake venom is a mixture of toxalbumins and enzymes in varying proportions. The enzymatic components cause local and systemic effects and the non-enzymatic compounds provide lethality. Hyaluronidase is present in all venoms and helps in rapid spreading of the venom. Enzymes include phospholipidase A, proteases, and hyaluronidase can cause increase in cell wall permeability, with haemolysis, disruption of connective tissue, muscle and subcutaneous tissue damage leading to necrosis, and promotion of i.v. clotting and fibrinolysis resulting in a defibrinated syndrome. (Statement 3)

Snake venoms travel through lymphatics and superficial veins, and this is why pressure immobilisation is recommended as a first aid for snake bites. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. (Statement 4) However, it is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis. This application of a broad firm bandage on the bitten area is known as the Sutherland wrap.

questions.text: 76. A 38-year-old male with HIV and low CD count presents with painful swallowing and retrosternal pain. Upper GI Endoscopy shows white patches on the mucosa of oesophagus. A biopsy of these lesions would show which of the following?

choices.text: Endodermal cells, fibroblasts,  inflammatory cells and eosinophillic intranuclear inclusions

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male with HIV and low CD count suggest more prone to opportunitic infections and presenting with painful swallowing and retrosternal pain, and upper GI endoscopy showing white patches on the mucosa of the oesophagus, is suggestive of oesophageal candidiasis caused by Candida, and a biopsy of these lesions would show yeast and pseudohyphae.

Candida species are yeast-like fungi that normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell that produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. It causes mucocutaneous and systemic candidiasis. Candidiasis is an opportunistic infection. Risk factors include treatment with corticosteroids or antibiotics, high levels of glucose, and AIDS.

Diagnosis includes :

* Gram staining - Gram-positive budding cells with pseudohyphae.

* Sabouraud agar culture - Creamy white smooth colonies with yeasty odour.

* Corn meal agar culture - Candida albicans form chlamydospores.

* Reynolds Braude phenomenon - Candida albicans forms germ tubes when incubated in human serum.

* CHROMagar - Candida albicans colonies appear green.

Treatment involves Amphotericin B, 5-fluorocytosine, ketoconazole, and fluconazole. The image given below shows yeast and pseudohyphae of Candida.



Other options:

Option B: Squamous cell carcinoma presents as a red, white, or red and white ulcer with an elevated or indurated border. Pain is not prominent in the early lesions. 

Option C: Amastigote and surrounding macrophages are seen in parasitic infections such as Leishmaniasis.

Option D: Endodermal cells, fibroblasts,  inflammatory cells and eosinophillic intranuclear inclusions are seen in Viral infections.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: 77. A 40-year-old chronic smoker undergoes spirometry. FEV1/FVC is 0.65, FVC is 62%, and RV/TLC is 141%. Which of the following describes the condition of his lungs?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a chronic smoker with FEV1/FVC is 0.65, FVC 62%, and RV/TLC 141% signifies obstructive lung disease, which will lead to trapping of air with hyperinflation of lungs.

Chronic smoking leads to airway inflammation and destruction, leading to air trapping and progressive hyperinflation. This further leads to increased residual volume, increased total lung capacity and an increased ratio of residual volume to total lung capacity. To preserve maximum expiratory airflow, hyperinflation of the thorax serves an important role by increasing lung volume and thereby decreasing airway resistance.

At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1). In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced, where the decrease in FEV1 is greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases. 

Other options:

Option B: Restrictive Lung Disease is characterised by a normal to increased FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced residual and lung volumes.

Option C: It is obstructive lung disease and not a normal physiological change with age.

Option D: Compliance refers to the change in lung volume per unit change in surrounding pressure. Compliance can increase in obstructive disease, such as emphysema.

questions.text: 78. Minimum age for MTP is (in years)
questions.solution:
There is no prescribed minimum age for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) under the MTP Act, 1971. Therefore, among the given options, 16 years can be considered the minimum age only in a relative sense among the given options. 

As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), 1971 "No pregnancy of a woman, who has not attained the age of eighteen years, or, who, having attained the age of eighteen years, is a lunatic, shall be terminated except with the consent in writing of her guardian." Therefore, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed at any age, as there is no legally defined minimum. The only distinction is that if the woman is 18 years or older, her written consent alone is required before conducting an abortion. However, if the woman is a minor (under 18 years) or is mentally ill, the written consent of her parent or legal guardian is mandatory.

Note: As per the POCSO Act, statutory rape constitutes of any consensual or nonconsensual sexual activity between a person below 18 years of age. It can be between an adult and a minor or it can also be between minors and in either case, consent remains irrelevant. Hence, abortion service providers are required to report such cases to the police. However in such cases, judicial permission is not required for abortion if there is written consent of parents or legal guardian and if the pregnancy is within legal gestational limits under the MTP Act.

questions.text: 82. A mother brings a child, born at home without complications, who shows cyanosis on crying. There was a noticeable systolic murmur. The doctor diagnosed the case as Tetralogy of Fallot. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is seen in Tetralogy of Fallot. 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic heart disease characterised by the classic tetrad of:

* Severe right ventricular outflow obstruction

* Large VSD

* Aorta that overrides the VSD 

* Right ventricular hypertrophy

The blood flows from the right ventricle into the pulmonary artery across the pulmonary stenosis, producing an ejection systolic murmur. The intensity of the systolic murmur is inversely related to the severity of pulmonary stenosis. The more severe the pulmonary stenosis, the bigger the right-to-left shunt, which further leads to increased cyanosis.

The commonest symptoms are dyspnea on exertion and intolerance to exercise. Anoxic spells occur mostly after waking up or following exertion. The child starts crying, becomes dyspneic, and may also lose consciousness. Convulsions can also occur. The frequency varies from once in a few days to several attacks every day. The patients squat as soon as they get dyspneic. Squatting increases venous return to the right side of the heart and also increases systemic vascular resistance, leading to an increased flow through the obstructed right ventricular outflow.

On auscultation, first sound, a single second sound, and an ejection systolic murmur that ends before the audible single second sound can be heard. The electrocardiogram shows right axis deviation with right ventricular hypertrophy. The T waves are usually inverted in right precordial leads, and P pulmonale may be present, but is uncommon. The absence of the main pulmonary artery segment gives it the shape described as Coeur en Sabot or boot-shaped heart. Pulmonary fields are oligemic. The diagnosis is confirmed on electrocardiography.

questions.text: 83. Which of the following imaging modalities is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The imaging modalities contraindicated in pregnancy among the given options is CT Scan. 

CT is a high-resolution technique using x-rays to generate cross-sectional images of any area of the body. It is associated with high radiation doses. Hence, CT scan is avoided during pregnancy due to the potential adverse effects of radiation on the fetus. 

Other options:

Option A: MRI is useful for high soft tissue contrast and acquisition of images. It is devoid of any ionizing radiation and found to have no fetal harmful effect at any gestational age. However, the gadolinium contrast MRI in pregnancy should be used with caution as gadolinium crosses the placenta.

Option C: Ultrasound is the most commonly used imaging tool in obstetrics. There is no documented harmful effects to the fetus from diagnostic ultrasound. 

Option D: Color Doppler is based on the principle of Doppler frequency shift. Doppler ultrasound is used to measure the speed at which blood is moving within a vessel. The effects of ultrasound on tissues are: temperature elevation, formation of microbubbles and cavitation. However, there is no clear evidence till date that diagnostic ultrasound examination during pregnancy is harmful. Ultrasound should be done with shortest duration possible to avoid unnecessary exposure, especially with the Doppler.

questions.text: 84. During a simple muscle twitch experiment, latent period = 10 ms, contraction period = 40 ms, relaxation period= 20 ms. What is the fusion frequency that is required to tetanize this muscle in Hz.
questions.solution:
The tetanising frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

Tetanising frequency = 1/contraction period (per second)

Therefore, tetanising frequency = 1/40 per millisecond = 1000/40 per second = 25 per second = 25 Hz

With repeated stimulation, contraction occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred. This causes the individual responses to fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called tetanus (tetanic contraction). ​​​Tetanising frequency is the minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Tetanus is of two types: complete tetanus, when no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, when periods of incomplete relaxation occur between the summated stimuli. 

When there is a repeated stimulus to a muscle fibre before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction and the total strength of contraction increases. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

questions.text: 85. Which one of the following is the action of the muscle attached in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the dorsal surface of the sacral bone. The muscle attached in the marked structure is the gluteus maximus and its action is abduction at hip. 

The gluteus maximus originates from the posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament. It inserts primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface. 

It is a large, quadrilateral powerful muscle covering mainly the posterior surface of pelvis and supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2). It is the chief extensor of the thigh at the hip joint. This action is very important in rising from a sitting position and for maintaining the erect posture. Other actions include lateral rotation of the thigh and abduction of the thigh at the hip joint (by upper fibres). Along with the tensor fasciae latae, the muscle stabilises the knee through the iliotibial tract. It supports both the hip and the knee when these joints are slightly flexed. It is an antigravity muscle as well.

Its blood supply is from the inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

questions.text: 86. A 4 year old child presents with developmental regression, hepatomegaly, and a cherry-red spot in the macula. The startle reflex is normal. Which of the following lysosomal enzymes is deficient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of developmental regression along with hepatomegaly, macular cherry-red spot, and normal startle reflex point to a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease. The enzyme deficient in this disease is sphingomyelinase.

Niemann-Pick disease presents in infancy and usually leads to death by 2-3 years of age. The affected infants are normal at birth, but deteriorate rapidly with failure to thrive. The usual clinical presentation includes hepatosplenomegaly and rapid psychomotor retardation.

Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme. There is an extensive accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Lipid-laden foam cells are observed in bone marrow and lymph nodes. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the sphingomyelinase levels in the peripheral leucocytes. 

This condition is managed with supportive treatment, such as physical therapy and a feeding tube for nutrition. Olipudase alfa has been recently approved for non-CNS manifestations of Niemann-Pick disease. 

Other options:

Option B: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is seen in Tay-Sachs disease. While it also presents with progressive neurodegeneration and macular cherry-red spot, there is no organomegaly and lysosomes with onion skin are seen. Startle reflex is exaggerated in Tay-Sachs disease. 

Option C: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease. The patients present with hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal manifestations in the form of bone pain and pathological fractures. Bone marrow examination shows macrophages with a characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.

Option D: Arylsulfatase A deficiency is seen in Metachromatic leukodystrophy. It primarily causes demyelination and psychological disturbances, and does not present with hepatomegaly or a cherry-red macula.

questions.text: 87. What is the function of phase I reactions in xenobiotics?

choices.text: To make the compund more permeable across the membranes
To extract functional proteins through oxidation and reduction reactions
To directly conjugate the compound and facilitate excretion
To introduce functional groups for further metabolism

questions.solution:
The function of phase I reactions in xenobiotic metabolism by CYP enzymes is to introduce functional groups for further metabolism.

Drugs are chemical substances foreign to the body called xenobiotics. Metabolism of xenobiotics is needed to render nonpolar, lipid-soluble compounds to polar, water-soluble, and lipid-insoluble ones so that they are excreted in the renal tubules without being reabsorbed. The elimination of drugs has been divided into 2 phases:

* Phase 1 reactions: which include oxidation, reduction, or hydrolytic reaction. The phase 1 enzymes lead to the introduction of functional groups such as –OH, –COOH, –SH, –O–, or NH2. The addition of functional groups does little to increase the water solubility of the drug but can dramatically alter the biological properties of the drug. Reactions carried out by phase 1 enzymes usually lead to the inactivation of a drug. 

* Phase 2 reactions, in which enzymes catalyze the conjugation of the substrate (the phase 1 product) with a second molecule. Phase 2 enzymes facilitate the elimination of the drug by producing a metabolite with improved water solubility that facilitates drug elimination from the tissue, normally via efflux transporter.

Pearl PM1734: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

* Oxidation

* Reduction

* Hydrolysis

* Cyclisation

* Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

* Glucuronide conjugation

* Sulfate conjugation

* Glycine conjugation

* Glutathione conjugation

* Acetylation

* Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: 88. A 75 year old lady presents with intertrochanteric fracture. What is the management of choice?
questions.solution:
The management of choice for a 75 year old lady presenting with intertrochanteric fracture is proximal femoral Intramedullary nailing.

The intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by intramedullary and extramedullary implants.

* Intramedullary implants include proximal femoral nail and gamma nail which are used in displaced/unstable intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. Compared to dynamic hip screws, the intramedullary fixation with proximal femoral nails has smaller incisions, decreased blood loss, decreased femoral neck shortening, and decreased risk of infection.

* Extramedullary implants include a dynamic hip screw which is used in undisplaced/stable inter-trochanteric fractures

The below image shows the proximal femoral nail with locking and stabilization screws.



Below image shows the dynamic hip screw. It has a long cancellous screw which glides freely inside the sleeve of the side plate.



Inter-trochanteric fracture

Fractures in the inter-trochanteric region of the proximal femur, involving either the greater or the lesser trochanter or both, are grouped in this category. In the elderly, the fracture is normally sustained by a sideway fall or a blow over the greater trochanter. In the young, it occurs following violent trauma, as in a road traffic accident.

Clinical features include a history of a fall or road accident, followed by pain in the region of the groin and an inability to move the leg. There will be swelling in the region of the hip, and the leg will be short and externally rotated. There is tenderness over the greater trochanter.

X-ray of an inter-trochanteric fracture

The ulnar nerve arises from the ventral rami of C8 and T1. It runs downwards with the brachial artery and descends on the back of medial epicondyle of humerus where it can be palpated. questions.text: 90. Which of the following is an example of a feedforward mechanism in homeostasis?

choices.text: Increased cardiac output in severe anemia
Increase heart rate when standing up from supine position

questions.solution:
Vasoconstriction on cooling of the skin is an example of a feedforward mechanism in homeostasis.

Feed-forward control is used to apprise the brain whether a muscle movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscle the next time the movement is required. This mechanism is often called adaptive control.

Examples include

* Temperature regulation – The hypothalamus initiates thermoregulatory responses before the changes in environmental temperature have succeeded in changing the body’s core body temperature

* Stimulation of gastric acid secretion

* Parathyroid hormone stimulating the production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D

Other options:

Options A, B and D: Increased cardiac output in severe anaemia, increased vasopressin secretion during dehydration and increased heart rate when standing up from the supine position are all examples of negative feedback mechanism.

questions.text: 91. A neonate was normal at birth but developed liver disease and muscle weakness 4 months later. She had severe hypoglycemia particularly in the morning after an overnight fast. On examination, there is hepatomegaly. Lab tests done after fasting show ketoacidosis, pH 7.25, increased ALT and AST levels. On administering IV glucagon after a carbohydrate meal, a normal rise in blood glucose levels is seen whereas on giving IV glucagon after an overnight fast, no rise on blood glucose levels is seen. Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen (8% of weight). Which enzyme has a defect?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Cori's disease which has a defect of debranching enzyme. A key diagnostic clue is the liver biopsy showing increased glycogen content (8% of liver weight), indicating that glycogen is being stored but not effectively broken down. Importantly, the IV glucagon test showed a rise in blood glucose after a carbohydrate meal, but no rise after an overnight fast - this suggests that glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be fully mobilized during fasting.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency (glycogen storage disease III) is also known as Cori's disease, Forbes' disease, and limit dextrinosis. The debranching enzyme, together with phosphorylase, is responsible for the complete degradation of glycogen. In this case, the debranching enzyme is defective; hence, the glycogen breakdown is incomplete, which results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains, which resemble limit dextrin.

Cori’s disease can present with fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation. Muscle weakness is slowly progressive and associated with wasting. Accumulation of limit dextrins is seen in Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.

The purpose of the glucagon challenge test is to help differentiate types of glycogen storage diseases (GSDs), particularly Von Gierke’s disease (Type I) and Cori’s disease (Type III). When glucagon is given after a carbohydrate meal, a normal rise in blood glucose occurs in Cori’s disease, because some glycogen is still accessible for breakdown. However, after prolonged fasting, glucagon does not raise blood glucose in either Von Gierke's or Cori’s disease. In Von Gierke’s, glucose-6-phosphatase is defective, so no glucose is released at all, even after feeding. Condition | Glucagon after meal | Glucagon after fast Normal individual | Normal rise in blood glucose | Normal rise in blood glucose Von Gierke’s disease | No rise in blood glucose | No rise in blood glucose Cori’s disease | Normal rise in blood glucose | No rise in blood glucose

Other options:

Option B: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease) affects only skeletal muscle, causing exercise-induced cramps and weakness. Muscle glycogen is abnormally high and blood lactate is low after exercise. It does not cause hypoglycemia or liver enlargement, so it doesn't fit this case.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (Von Gierke disease) causes severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and ketosis. There is no glucose rise even after a meal, unlike in this patient.

Option D: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (Hers disease) results in mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly but typically spares muscle and has milder symptoms. Muscle weakness and severe fasting symptoms are uncommon.
