questions.text: 92. Under the MTP Act of 2021, permission of 2 Registered medical practitioners to terminate a pregnancy is required when the gestational age is ____
questions.solution:
Under the MTP Act of 2021, permission of 2 RMPs (registered medical practitioners) is required to terminate a pregnancy when the gestational age is 20-24 weeks.

As per the Amendement to MTP Act, 2021, termination is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. Opinion of one RMP for MTP up to 20 weeks is needed. Pregnancy beyond 20 weeks needs opinions of two RMPs.

Beyond 24 weeks, pregnancy termination can be done for cases of substantial fetal abnormalities, as diagnosed and decided by the Medical Board which consists of :

* Gynaecologist

* Paediatrician

* Radiologist 

* Any member appointed by the Government

Pearl PM2131: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

* Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother

* Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure

* Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest

* Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

* Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.

* MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.

* The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

* Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion

* 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion

* For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

* Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations

* Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)

* At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: 93. All are correct about Toxoplasma gondi except

choices.text: It Infects both mammals and birds
Infection more common in third trimester than in first trimester
Can be cultured in peritoneal cavity of mice

questions.solution:
All are correct statements about Toxoplasma gondii except that oocysts in stool are infective. 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular coccidian parasite infecting a wide range of mammals and birds. (Option B). It occurs in three forms 

* Trophozoite

* Tissue cyst

* Oocyst

T. gondii completes its life cycle in two hosts:

* Definitive hosts: Cats and other felines, in which both sexual and asexual cycles take place.

* Intermediate hosts: Man and other mammals, in which only the asexual cycle takes place.

Oocysts develop only in definitive hosts, that is, in the intestine of cats and other felines. Cats shed millions of oocysts per day in feces for about 2 weeks during the primary infection. The freshly passed oocyst is not infectious. They undergo sporulation in the soil with the formation of two sporocysts, each containing four sporozoites. The sporulated oocyst is infective (Option A). 

Humans can contract this infection through several routes:

* Consuming undercooked or raw meat, especially lamb and pork, that contains tissue cysts.

* Ingesting mature oocysts via contaminated food, water, or direct or indirect contact with cat feces.

* Intrauterine transmission from an infected mother to her fetus (congenital toxoplasmosis). The risk of fetal infection rises with the progress of gestation; from 25% when the mother acquires primary infection in 1st trimester to 65% in the 3rd trimester (Option C). Conversely, the severity of feral damage is highest when infection is transmitted in early pregnancy.

* Receiving blood transfusions or organ transplants from infected donors.

The life cycle of T. gondii is shown below:



Toxoplasma can be isolated by inoculating body fluids, blood, or tissue specimens by intraperitoneal inoculation in mice or in tissue culture. Mice should be examined for Toxoplasma in their peritoneal exudate after 7-10 days of inoculation. (Option D)

questions.text:
94. Which of the following statements are correct?

1. The epidermis is derived from the ectoderm. 2. The hypodermis and dermis are derived from the endoderm. 3. Stratum corneum is the outermost cellular layer. 4. The epidermis regenerates from deeper follicular cells, such as hair follicles and sebaceous glands.
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 4 are the correct statements. 

The epidermis is derived from the surface ectoderm. During the 2nd month, it presents as two layers- a superficial layer of flat cells called periderm/epitrichium and a deep layer of cuboidal cells called basal/ germinative layer. The cells of the basal layer proliferate to form a third intermediate layer later.

The epidermis regenerates from deeper follicular cells, such as hair follicles and sebaceous glands. This helps to maintain skin homeostasis.

Other statements:

Statement 2: The dermis and hypodermis are derived from mesoderm. The dermatomes give rise only to the dermis on the dorsal aspect of the head and trunk. The dermis of the limbs and that on the lateral and ventral aspects of the trunk arises from lateral plate mesoderm. The dermis over most of the head and the anterior aspect of the neck is derived from the neural crest.

Statement 3: Stratum corneum is not the outermost cellular layer. It is the outermost layer of epidermis, where cells, known as corneocytes, have lost their nuclei and cytoplasmic organelles.

Pearl PM1880: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis | Origin and location | Characteristic features Keratino-cytes | Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ | Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. Melano-cytes | Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis | Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M) Merkel   cells | Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ | Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors. Langerhans cells | Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis | They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text: 95. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Severe cases of alcohol withdrawal can be treated with I.V Flumazenil
Chronic opioid withdrawal can be treated with long acting drugs like Buprenorphine
Cannabis withdrawal is associated with minimal physical symptoms

questions.solution:
Severe cases of alcohol withdrawal can be treated with I.V Flumazenil is the false statement. 

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms include autonomic hyperactivity, such as anxiety, arousal, sweating, facial flushing, mydriasis, tachycardia, and mild hypertension. The classic sign of alcohol withdrawal is tremulousness, commonly called the "shakes" or the "jitters". It also causes psychotic and perceptual symptoms (e.g., delusions and hallucinations), seizures, and delirium tremens. 

These are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as oxazepam, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, and lorazepam. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist and is not used to treat alcohol withdrawal. It is used to reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and in emergency care of benzodiazepine overdosage

Other options: 

Option B: Opioid withdrawal can cause symptoms like drug craving, feeling of temperature change, musculoskeletal pain, and GI distress. Signs of opioid withdrawal include confusion, drowsiness, vomiting, and diarrhea. It is not typically life-threatening, especially compared to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, which can lead to seizures or delirium tremens. Hence, opioid withdrawal is rarely fatal. 

Option C: Chronic opioid withdrawal can be effectively managed using long-acting opioids like buprenorphine or methadone. These medications help reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings and are a cornerstone of opioid substitution therapy.

Option D: Cannabis withdrawal is associated with minimal physical symptoms. The most common features include irritability, cannabis cravings, nervousness, anxiety, restlessness, insomnia, disturbed or vivid dreaming, decreased appetite, weight loss, depressed mood, and tremors.

Pearl PM0416: Substances of abuse

Substance | Withdrawal symptoms | Intoxication features Alcohol | Tremors, delirium, seizures | Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech BZD | Tremors, insomnia, anxiety | Lethargy and drowsiness. Opioid/ Heroin | Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon | Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation. Nicotine/ Tobacco | Increased appetite | Shows a biphasic pattern. 

Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia. Cannabis | Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite | Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks. Amphetamine | Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams | Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.

Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia. Cocaine | Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts | Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis

Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue. LSD/ Haluccinogen | Nothing significant | Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria. Phencyclidine (PCP) | Nothing significant | Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

Pearl PM0417: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation | Symptoms/signs | Onset since last drink (hours) Tremulousness | Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz | 6–8 Alcoholic hallucinosis/

Psychotic and perceptual symptoms | Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. | 8-12 Seizures (rum fits) | Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic | 12–24 Delirium tremens | Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation | < 72

questions.text: 96. A six-week-old infant presents with failure to thrive and poor feeding. He complains of non-bilious vomiting immediately after feeding, which started three weeks after birth. The vomiting is forceful but not projectile. Bowel movements are normal. Per-abdominal examination has no significant findings. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a six-week-old infant with failure to thrive, poor feeding, non-bilious, forceful, non-projectile vomiting immediately after feeding, normal bowel movements, and no significant findings on per-abdominal examination suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease.

It involves the retrograde movement of gastric contents across the lower oesophageal sphincter into the oesophagus. It is the most common oesophageal disorder in children of all ages and can occur physiologically.

Infantile reflux presents with regurgitation, especially postprandially. Signs of esophagitis, like irritability, arching, choking, gagging, and feeding aversion, can also be seen. All these result in failure to thrive. Symptoms resolve spontaneously in the majority of infants by 12-24 months. Infants may also present with obstructive apnea or stridor or lower airway disease, in which reflux complicates primary airway disease, such as laryngomalacia or bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

Treatment depends on the patient’s age, nature and severity of symptoms. Infants should be burped well, and overfeeding must be avoided. Measures such as thickening of feeds can be adopted as they not only increase the calorie content but also reduce visible regurgitation.

Other options:

Option A: Cow milk protein allergy presents with blood in stools.

Option C: Intestinal obstruction presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.

Option D: Pyloric stenosis usually manifests at around 3 weeks of age as projectile vomiting. The vomitus is non-bilious in nature. Clinically, an olive-shaped, firm, movable, approximately 2 cm in length mass is palpable in the epigastrium. When the infant is given a feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right.

questions.text: 97. A 35-year-old patient presented with colicky pain and is suspected to have ureteric stone. Which of the following is the best diagnostic investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
NCCT KUB (Non-contrast CT of the kidney, ureters, and bladder) is the best diagnostic modality for the clinical evaluation of ureteric stones.

NCCT is the preferred investigation for evaluation of:

* Renal stones except for indinavir stones

* Ureteric stones

* Head injury

* Salivary gland stones

Other options: 

Option B: Contrast-enhanced CTs abdomen are not done for renal and ureteric stones, as non-contrast CTs provide enough visualisation. Additionally, the use of contrast material adds an additional risk of developing contrast-induced kidney injury. 

Option C: A USG KUB is less sensitive compared to an NCCT KUB, is operator-dependent, and it can be difficult to visualise mid-ureteric stones.

Option D: Ureteroscopy is an invasive test and is used for therapeutic intervention, not initial diagnosis.

questions.text: 98. A 52-year-old male presents with vomiting and complains of rotational vertigo upon turning his head on the bed in the morning. Which of the following is the best diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for a patient with vomiting and complaints of rotational vertigo upon turning his head on the bed in the morning is Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is characterised by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position. It is not associated with hearing loss or neurological symptoms. It is caused due to the disorder of the posterior semicircular canal.

The attacks are always provoked by changes in head position and caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals, usually dislodged from the posterior canal. A positive Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. 

Steps of the Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre:

* The manoeuvre starts with the patient in a sitting position.

* Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.

* The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.

* The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.

* Now the examiner observes the patient's eye for nystagmus.



In most of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley manoeuvre on the affected side. Epley's manoeuvre is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals.

Epley's manoeuvre is given in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: Meniere's disease is characterised by vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus and a sense of pressure in the involved ear. Vertigo is of sudden onset, lasts for a few minutes to hours.

Option C: Vestibular neuritis is characterised by severe vertigo of sudden onset and lasts from a few days to weeks. There are no cochlear symptoms. 

Option D: Labyrinthitis causes symptoms of hearing loss along with unilateral vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo and associated nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: 99. Amblyopia management includes all except?
questions.solution:
Amblyopia management includes all except Strabismus surgery.

Strabismus surgery is done after all the treatment measures for amblyopia correction are taken, and it is generally the last resort in the management protocol.

Amblyopia treatment should be started as early as possible. Amblyopia therapy works best when initiated in young children under 3 years of age and comprises the following: 

* Refractive error correction is done for cases of anisometropic amblyopia

* Patching, also known as Occlusion therapy, i.e., occlusion of the normal eye to force the use of the amblyopic eye, is the mainstay in the treatment of amblyopia. It can be full-time or part-time occlusion, depending on the age of the patient and the density of amblyopia

* Penalisation, i.e. blurring of vision of the normal eye, either by using atropine or over plus lenses in spectacles (optical penalisation) when occlusion is not possible

* Pharmacologic manipulation using levodopa/ carbidopa can be used as an adjunct to occlusion therapy

* Pleoptic exercises were used earlier to reestablish foveal fixation, especially in young children

* Perceptual learning, like using video games, is also suggested as an adjunct to occlusion therapy

* Computerised active vision therapy using specially designed software is being increasingly used for the treatment of amblyopia, along with occlusion therapy. It works on the concept of operant conditioning (a form of psychological learning). Computerised Home Vision Therapy can be prescribed as supplementary treatment to the occlusion therapy.

questions.text: 100. Identify the immunoglobulin:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

* J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.

* Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.



Other options:

Option B: IgD is found in trace amounts in serum but is the predominant surface-bound immunoglobulin on mature, antigen-inexperienced B cells. These B cells express both IgD and IgM on their surface in a 3:1 ratio, with IgD functioning as a membrane receptor.

Option C: IgM is the first immunoglobulin produced in response to antigen and is secreted as a pentamer, consisting of five H₂L₂ units and one J chain. With 10 identical antigen-binding sites, it has the highest valence and binding capacity, making it highly effective in agglutination and complement fixation.

Option D: IgE is present in very low serum concentrations and binds via its Fc region to high-affinity receptors on mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils. Structurally, it serves as a cell-bound antigen receptor, and antigen binding triggers immediate hypersensitivity (anaphylactic) reactions through mediator release.

Pearl PM2056: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

* Half-life- 23 days

* Appears late, indicates chronic infection

* It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.

* Has 4 subclasses.

* Facilitates opsonization (via Fc receptor binding)

* Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and viruses.

IgM:

* Half-life- 5 days

* Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.

* Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.

* Intravascular distribution.

* Appears early, indicates recent infection.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

* Half-life- 2-8 days.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

* Half-life- 1-5 days

* Causes type I hypersensitivity.

* It is the only heat-labile antibody.

* Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

* Half-life- 6 days

* It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 

* Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: 101. A 30-year-old female with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer has been referred for genetic testing. What is the single best genetic test to diagnose the condition?

choices.text: Q PCR for quantification of BRCA1 and BRCA 2 expression levels

questions.solution:
Q PCR for quantification of BRCA1 and BRCA2 expression levels is the single best genetic test to diagnose the condition.

PCR techniques play a very important role in the identification and detection of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. It has attributes such as flexibility, sensitivity, and selectivity that cannot be matched by any other technique in the therapeutic as well as diagnostic arena. It offers screening methods for genetic testing of diseases such as breast and ovarian cancer that offer precise results at relatively low costs, thus allowing many people to access the test. 

Other options:

Option A: Exome sequencing is a type of targeted sequencing, in which hundreds of thousands of custom probes are used to enrich for the roughly 1.5% of the genome that consists of protein-encoding exons before next-generation sequencing. It is not routinely used in the evaluation of suspected germline disorders.

questions.text: 102. A primigravida came for regular antenatal care in her first trimester. She has no complaints of dysuria or increased frequency, but her urine routine reveals ≥ 10^5 CFU/mL E. coli. Her urine culture was done again and showed the same organism. What is the most common complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition described is asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy, which is defined as the presence of ≥ 10⁵ CFU/mL of bacteria in the urine without urinary symptoms. The most common complication of untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy is preterm labour.

Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary tract in asymptomatic women. It is defined as one or more bacterial species that have a count ≥105 colony-forming units/mL determined by urine culture of a voided specimen. It is more common in women with diabetes.

If asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is not treated, approximately 25 percent of affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy. If not treated, it might progress to pyelonephritis and can have increased risks of low-birthweight neonates, preterm delivery, pregnancy-associated hypertension, and anaemia.

E.coli is the most common species isolated in pregnant women. Empirical oral treatment for 10 days with nitrofurantoin 100 mg at bedtime is usually effective.

Other options:

Option A: Asymptomatic bacteriuria is not significantly associated with first-trimester miscarriage. Most miscarriages in early pregnancy are due to genetic or anatomical causes, not subclinical UTIs.

Option C: Fetal hypoxia typically results from placental or umbilical cord problems and is not a known direct consequence of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy.

Option D: Chorioamnionitis is more commonly due to ascending infections from the genital tract and prolonged rupture of membranes, not from asymptomatic bacteriuria.

questions.text:
103. Identify incorrect statements

1. Alcohol at low doses causes CNS stimulation and at high doses causes CNS depression.  2. Cannabis causes repetitive movements (driven) 3. Opioids are effective analgesics 4. Volatile inhalants are toxic
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect. 

Alcohol is a CNS depressant at all doses. Although alcohol may appear to cause stimulation at low doses, this effect is due to depression of inhibitory control centres in the brain, not true CNS stimulation. (Statement 1)

Cannabis does not produce repetitive movements, which are more characteristic of central nervous system stimulants like amphetamines or cocaine (Statement 2). Cannabis, on the contrary, can impair motor skills. 

Opioids like morphine, codeine, and fentanyl are highly effective analgesics (Statement 3). Opioids act as analgesics primarily by activating μ-opioid receptors, which inhibit GABA release and enhance PAG output, modulating pain pathways in the brain and spinal cord. At the spinal level, they block calcium channels presynaptically, reducing neurotransmitter release, and open potassium channels postsynaptically, causing hyperpolarization. This dual action dampens the excitation of second-order neurons, effectively reducing pain transmission.

Volatile inhalants, such as those in adhesives, butane refills, and aerosol propellants, are highly toxic and can cause sudden death due to cardiac arrhythmias or respiratory depression. Acute abuse leads to rapid intoxication marked by euphoria, hallucinations, and potential cardiac arrest. Chronic use, especially of substances like toluene or n-hexane, can result in lasting damage to the brain, heart, liver, kidneys, and lungs. (Statement 4)

questions.text: 104. The surface tension of the fluid lining the alveoli increases during

choices.text: Change in posture from standing to supine
Change in posture from supine to standing

questions.solution:
The surface tension of the fluid lining the alveoli increases during Inspiration.

The surface tension is low when the alveoli are small due to the presence of surfactant in the fluid lining the alveoli. Surface tension increases as the alveolar size increases during inspiration. 

As per the Laplace law,



where,

P = Collapsing pressure on alveolus (dynes/cm2) or Pressure required to keep alveoli open

T = Surface tension (dynes/cm)

r = Radius of the alveolus (cm)

Collapsing pressure is inversely related to radius, i.e., a large alveolus (one with a large radius) will have a low collapsing pressure and therefore will require only minimal pressure to keep it open. On the other hand, a small alveolus (one with a small radius) will have a high collapsing pressure and require more pressure to keep it open.

Pearl PM1012: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

* SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.

* SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.

* SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text:
105. Which of the following is true about GnRH receptor antagonists:

1. Used for the treatment of hypogonadal hypogonadism in males 2. Used in the management of advanced CA Prostate  3. Used as a tocolytic 4. Used in vitro fertilisation for controlled ovulation
questions.solution:
GnRH receptor antagonists is used in the management of advanced prostate cancer and in vitro fertilisation for controlled ovulation.

GnRH receptor antagonists like degarelix acetate is FDA-approved for treatment of advanced prostate cancer. Degarelix suppresses testosterone levels to 50 ng/dL or less (i.e., medical castration) and lowers prostate-specific antigen more rapidly than GnRH agonists without an initial testosterone surge. It is administered subcutaneously in the abdomen at a starting dose of 240 mg, followed by a maintenance dose of 80 mg every 28 days. Adverse effects include injection site reactions, hot flashes, weight gain, increases in transaminase and γ-glutamyltransaminase levels, prolonged QT interval, and decreased bone mineral density.

GnRH receptor antagonists like ganirelix acetate and cetrorelix acetate are FDA-approved to suppress the LH surge and thus prevent premature ovulation in ovarian-stimulation protocols as part of assisted reproduction technology (in vitro fertilisation). It is given once-daily and administered subcutaneously. When used in conjunction with gonadotropin injections for assisted reproduction, the effects of estrogen withdrawal (e.g., hot flashes) are not seen. Cetrorelix is also used off label for endometriosis and uterine fibroids, both of which are estrogen dependent.

GnRH receptor antagonists have no role in treating hypogonadal hypogonadism in males because they suppress LH and FSH, which would further reduce testosterone levels. In such cases, treatment aims to stimulate or replace testosterone, not inhibit its production (Statement 1).

They also have no role as tocolytics, since they do not influence uterine contractions or the hormonal pathways directly involved in labor (Statement 3).

questions.text: 106. The area marked by the arrow in the given histopathological image can influence the surrounding cells by:
questions.solution:
The area marked by the arrow in the given histopathological image is Islets of Langerhans and it can influence the surrounding cells by paracrine effect. 

The endocrine pancreas is in the form of numerous rounded collections of cells that are embedded within the exocrine part. These collections of polyhedral cells are called Islets of Langerhans. They appear as groups of small cells with lightly stained cytoplasm. Each islet is separated from the surrounding alveoli by a thin layer of reticular tissue and are very richly supplied with blood through a dense capillary plexus.

The Islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells as follows

* α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 

* β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 

* δ or D cells- peripherally placed like α cells and secrete somatostatin and gastrin



While islet hormones maintain systemic homeostasis, they also critically regulate cells within the islet through paracrine signaling mechanisms to fine-tune cell function and survival.  In paracrine signaling, the signaling molecules released by a cell only affect target cells in close proximity to it. The densely packed nature of islet cells and blood vessels facilitates a paracrine signaling network mediated by proximity, cell contact via gap junctions, and local blood flow. Other examples of paracrine signaling include enteroendocrine cells of gastrointestinal tract. 

The below image shows the different types of extracellular cell-to-cell communication mechanisms.

questions.text: 107. Cancer cells consume more glucose by which of the following process?

choices.text: Increased lactate is produced even in the presence of oxygen
Increased conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA

questions.solution:
In cancer cells, increased lactate is produced even in the presence of oxygen which is known as the Warburg Effect.

Neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism for the generation of metabolic intermediates, which are needed for cell growth and multiplication. The Warburg Effect is a phenomenon in which there is an increase in the rate of glucose uptake and conversion into lactate(fermentation), even in the presence of oxygen. Cancer cells derive energy mainly from glycolysis. 

Cancer cells utilize glycolysis (2 ATP) over mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (36 ATP) for glucose metabolism, even though the latter produces more ATP. It is because pure oxidative phosphorylation produces abundant ATP, but also burns glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties suitable for use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.

For this reason, rapidly growing cells, by undergoing glycolysis, produce carbon moieties that are needed for growth and cellular maintenance.

The image given below shows the comparison of glucose metabolism in normal cells versus cancer cells.



As a result of decreased ATP production, the main metabolic function of mitochondria in growing cells is not to generate ATP, but to carry out reactions that generate cellular building blocks. For example, lipid biosynthesis.

Warburg effect is produced by growth factor receptors downstream signalling pathways. These include receptor tyrosine kinase/PI3K/AKT and MYC.

Clinically, cancer cells exhibiting the Warburg effect show a property of glucose hunger. This is used to visualize them via positron emission tomography (PET) scanning.

questions.text: 108. A patient undergoes cardiac surgery with muscle relaxant Vecuronium. After the surgery is completed, which of the following agents can be used for the reversal of this drug?
questions.solution:
Neostigmine can be used in the reversal of muscle relaxants like Vecuronium.

Neostigmine is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor. Its primary mechanism of action is decreased breakdown of acetylcholine at the motor endplate. It increases the concentration of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which can compete with and displace the non-depolarising muscle relaxants, and thus reverse the paralysis. Acute bolus or prolonged administration of anticholinesterases can have deleterious effects on neuromuscular function in otherwise healthy patients.

Sugammadex is a novel reversal drug that shows a high affinity for the steroidal neuromuscular blocking drugs rocuronium and vecuronium. It is a cyclodextrin that forms a tight inclusion complex with these steroidal neuromuscular blocking drugs, thereby inactivating their effects and facilitating rapid reversal of neuromuscular block.

Other options: 

Option A: Baclofen is a central-acting GABA-B agonist used to treat spasticity. It does not affect neuromuscular junctions or reverse non-depolarising muscle relaxants.

Option B: Dantrolene acts directly on skeletal muscle to reduce calcium release and is used for malignant hyperthermia, not for reversing neuromuscular blockade.

Option D: Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent used to prevent bradycardia during reversal, but does not reverse neuromuscular blockade by itself.

Pearl PM0215: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

* Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium

* Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium

* Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

* Atracurium

* Cisatracurium

* Vecuronium

* Rocuronium

* Long-acting (>50 minutes)

* Pancuronium

* Doxacurium

* Pipecuronium

questions.text: 109. A neonate presenting with jaundice due to breastfeeding is due to a fatty acid inhibition of ___
questions.solution:
A neonate presenting with jaundice due to breastfeeding is due to a fatty acid inhibition of the Conjugation of bilirubin.

Breast milk jaundice is a type of neonatal jaundice that occurs in neonates due to breast milk. It usually happens within the second to third week of life due to the abnormal accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to jaundice.

Breast milk contains high concentrations of beta-glucuronidase, which deconjugates bilirubin excreted in the intestine after conjugation by the liver. Increased free fatty acids and increased enterohepatic circulation also interfere with bilirubin conjugation.

Breastfeeding should be continued, and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels. Phototherapy may be beneficial in some cases.

questions.text: 110. A 60-year-old woman presented with abdominal swelling, early satiety, and pelvic discomfort. CA 125 was 990 U/L. On examination fluid wave was present, and a pelvic mass was felt. Ultrasound revealed multilocular solid components in an adnexal mass bilaterally. CECT showed ascites and omental caking. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this 60 year old woman is serous cystadenocarcinoma.

Her symptoms of abdominal swelling, early satiety, and pelvic discomfort are classic for advanced ovarian malignancy. The presence of a fluid wave suggests ascites, and the detection of a pelvic mass on examination further supports an ovarian origin.

A markedly elevated CA-125 level of 990 U/L is strongly indicative of epithelial ovarian cancer, particularly the serous subtype, which is the most common and typically presents with high CA-125 levels. Ultrasound findings of bilateral multilocular solid adnexal masses, and contrast-enhanced CT showing both ascites and omental caking are hallmarks of peritoneal carcinomatosis often seen in advanced serous carcinoma. 

Other options: 

Option A: Granulosa cell tumor are sex cord-stromal tumors that are usually unilateral. They are hormonally active and often produce estrogen, leading to symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding or endometrial hyperplasia, which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, granulosa cell tumors rarely cause massive ascites or omental caking, and they do not typically result in such a high CA-125 level as seen here (990 U/L). 

Option B: Endometroid adenofibroma is a rare and benign tumor that does not typically produce symptoms like abdominal distension, early satiety, or pelvic discomfort. These tumors are usually small, unilateral, and typically doesn't present with ascites, elevated CA-125, or peritoneal spread. Bilateral solid masses and omental caking are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

Option C: Mucinous cystadenoma is a benign epithelial ovarian tumor that is usually large and unilateral, often presenting as a multilocular cystic mass. However, it typically does not cause ascites, omental caking, or elevated CA-125 levels, all of which are present in this case. While it may cause abdominal discomfort due to its size, the presence of bilateral solid components, a markedly elevated tumor marker, and evidence of peritoneal spread are more indicative of a malignant process, making mucinous cystadenoma an unlikely diagnosis.

Note: Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is a malignant form and behaves differently from mucinous cystadenoma.

* Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor

* Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

* Dysgerminoma

* Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)

* Teratoma (Mature/immature)

IV. Gonadoblastoma

questions.text:
111. Which of the following drugs can be used in Acute Mania?

1. Lithium 2. Valproate 3. Haloperidol 4. Amitryptilline
questions.solution:
Lithium, valproate and haloperidol (1, 2 and 3) can be used in Acute Mania.

The pharmacological treatment of bipolar disorders is divided into both acute and maintenance phases. 

Treatment of acute mania includes: 

* Lithium: It is considered the prototypical mood stabilizer. But due to the slow onset of antimanic action with lithium, it usually is supplemented in the early phases of treatment by atypical antipsychotics, mood-stabilizing anticonvulsants, or high-potency benzodiazepines. Major drawback is its narrow therapeutic index (recommended plasma level 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L).

* Valproate: It is only indicated for acute mania at dose levels of 750 to 2,500 mg per day. It is well tolerated and associated with a rapid onset of response. 

* Carbamazepine and Oxcarbazepine: They are one of the first-line treatment for acute mania.

* Clonazepam and Lorazepam. They are high-potency benzodiazepine anticonvulsants which are widely used for adjunctive treatment of acute manic agitation, insomnia, aggression, and dysphoria, and panic.

* Atypical and Typical Antipsychotics: Older agents like haloperidol and chlorpromazine can be used, but atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine have a lesser liability for excitatory postsynaptic potential and tardive dyskinesia. 

Lithium, carbamazepine, and valproic acid, alone or in combination, are the most widely used agents in the long-term treatment of patients with bipolar disorder. 

Amitryptilline (Option 4)is a tricyclic antidepressant and acts by blocking the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine neurotransmitters. It is used to treat major depressive disorder, and not acute mania.

questions.text: 112. A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of increased chronic urinary frequency for the past 3 months. On examination, the prostate is normal and supra pubic tenderness is seen. Urine analysis shows a leukocyte count ( 50/ Ul), and culture shows no bacterial growth. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of increased chronic urinary frequency for the last 3 months, normal prostate, suprapubic tenderness, with urine analysis showing a leukocyte count (> 50/ Ul), and culture showing no bacterial growth suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Sterile pyuria.

Sterile pyuria is pyuria in the absence of bacteriuria and indicates an inflammatory response that may still be related to urinary tract infection or that may be a response to another pathology, such as fastidious organisms (e.g. TB, gonorrhoea), carcinoma in situ (CIS), bladder stones or other inflammatory conditions. Suprapubic tenderness can be seen in patients with cystitis and elderly patients with urinary incontinence or overactive bladder.

Other options:

Option A and C: Since the prostate is normal, the diagnosis cannot be Chronic bacterial prostatitis or Granulomatous prostatitis. Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents with a soft, boggy and tender prostate.

Option D: Acute urinary infection will lead to bacterial growth on culture.

questions.text: 113. Identify the surgery:
questions.solution:
The given image shows SADI-S. 

Single-anastomosis duodenoileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S) is a newer bariatric surgical technique derived from the biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS). It involves performing a sleeve gastrectomy followed by creating an end-to-side duodenoileal anastomosis. The common channel–alimentary limb is typically 250–300 cm in length. This approach offers several benefits, such as retaining the pylorus, avoiding a second anastomosis compared to the traditional duodenal switch, and potentially shortening the operation time and lowering the risk of complications during surgery



Other options:

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery. In this procedure, the pylorus is intact and the pressure in the stomach increases leading to increased chances of reflux. Patients can develop gastroesophageal reflux disease and Barrett's oesophagus as a long-term complication. There is also a risk of becoming obese again in sleeve gastrectomy. Short-term complications include a staple leak at an angle of His, intra-abdominal bleed, and DVT/PE. The staple leak at an angle of his can present up to 30 days after the surgery and can cause sepsis. Urgent CT scans with re-laparoscopy are indicated in such cases.

Option B: Biliopancreatic diversion is indicated in cases where the patient desires maximum weight loss.

questions.text:
114. Identify whether the following statements are true or false :
* Widal test is positive for Typhoid in first week of illness                    
* Microscopic agglutination test is done for Leptospira  
* Weil felix test is done for Typhus fever                        
* Standard agglutination test is done for Brucellosis
* Catalase positive is seen in Streptococcus
questions.solution:
1-F,  2-T, 3-T, 4-T, 5-F is the correct answer. 

Statement 1: Widal test to detect rising titres of H and O agglutinins against Salmonella typhi and paratyphi. The agglutination titre will depend on the stage of the disease. Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week, so blood taken earlier may give a negative result. The titre increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines gradually.

Statement 2: The microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is done for detecting antibodies in leptospirosis. Antibodies appear in serum towards the end of the first week of the disease and increase till the fourth week, declining thereafter. This uses live cultures of different serotypes, and agglutination is observed under the low power dark field microscope.

Statement 3: Weil felix test is a heterophile agglutination reaction used to detect certain rickettsial infections like Typhus fever, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains - Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K.

Inference of Agglutination Pattern in Weil-Felix Reaction: Disease | OX 19 | OX 2 | OX K Epidemic typhus | +++ | + | - Endemic typhus | +++ | +/- | - RMSF (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever) | ++ | ++ | - Scrub typhus | - | - | +++

Statement 4: Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) detects antibodies against Brucella. A titre of 160 or more is considered significant.

Statement 5: The catalase test is demonstrated by placing a microbial colony in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The catalase enzyme degrades hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles and is a positive test. Catalase test is used to differentiate streptococci from staphylococci. Staphylococci is catalase positive while Streptococcus is catalase negative.

questions.text:
115. A patient suffers from diabetic kidney disease. Which of the following is not a typical glomerular lesion seen?

GBM - Glomerular Basement Membrane
questions.solution:
Armani-Ebstein lesion is not a typical glomerular lesion seen in diabetic nephropathy.

Armani-Ebstein lesions are characterised by vacuolization and PAS-positive glycogen accumulation within the cytoplasm of tubular epithelial cells that are seen only in severe cases of diabetic nephropathy.

Loss of podocytes, Mesangial expansion, and Diffuse thickening of GBM are typical glomerular lesions seen in diabetic nephropathy. The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.

Thickening of the GBM occurs in almost all cases of diabetic nephropathy and is best appreciated by electron microscopy. These progressive changes are usually accompanied by mesangial widening and thickening of the tubular basement membranes.

Diffuse Mesangial Sclerosis consists of a diffuse increase in mesangial matrix. The matrix depositions are PAS-positive. As the disease progresses, the mesangial matrix deposits may take on a nodular appearance. Alterations in the GBM lead to disruption in the filtration barrier and loss of podocytes.

Nodular Glomerulosclerosis, also known as intercapillary glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, showing nodules of pink hyaline material in regions of glomerular capillary loops in the glomerulus, is a classical finding. The nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops, known as fibrin caps or adherent to Bowman capsules, known as capsular drops. 

The image below shows Armani-Ebstein lesions (glycogen vacuoles in the tubules).

questions.text: 116. Breast conservation surgery not contraindicated in

choices.text: Previous history of radiation to chest
Persistent positive margins even after resection

questions.solution:
Breast conservation surgery is not contraindicated in tumor involving single quadrant. In fact, a tumor involving only one quadrant allows for adequate excision with clean margins while still maintaining a good cosmetic outcome. 

Breast conservation surgery (BCS) involves removing the tumor along with a 1-cm margin of healthy breast tissue, aiming to preserve most of the breast. It is done in patients whose tumors are localized (usually in a single quadrant), with no multicentric disease, and who can undergo postoperative radiotherapy. After surgery, patients receive radiotherapy to reduce the risk of local recurrence. This combination is called breast conservation therapy (BCT).

Other options:

Option A: BCS requires radiotherapy after surgery. Previous history of radiation limits the ability to safely give more radiation, so BCS is contraindicated.

Option C: Scleroderma and other connective tissue diseases increase the risk of severe radiation reactions, making BCS risky.

Option D: Persistent positive margins after resection that is if cancer cells remain even after attempts to clear margins, BCS is not advisable because complete removal of tumor is essential.

Pearl PM0884: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

* 1st-trimester pregnancy

* Diffuse microcalcifications

* Persistently positive pathologic margin

* Multicentric tumor

Relative contraindications:

* Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis

* Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast

* Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex

* Multifocal tumor

* History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.

questions.text: 117. A 25-year-old presents with recurrent urinary stones and a pathological fracture. Blood reports show high calcium and PTH. Which of the following tests is preferred for localising the parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
Sestamibi scan is preferred for localising the parathyroid gland.

Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation. It shows passive diffusion across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria. Because of its accumulation in the mitochondria, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending on the number of mitochondria in each tissue. 

In parathyroid adenomas, there is a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content.

The three protocols for Sestamibi scanning:

* Single-isotope dual-phase scan

* Dual-isotope subtraction imaging

* Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)

SPECT is commonly used because of its improved spatial resolution. Sestamibi combined with CT can be used to detect smaller parathyroid tissues. It can also detect ectopic glands in the mediastinum or the deeper cervical region.

The image below shows a Sestamibi scan.



Other options:

Option A: Ultrasonography is inexpensive and noninvasive. It can miss adenomas located in retro-oesophageal, retrosternal or retrotracheal areas. It can also be difficult to differentiate between a small parathyroid gland and a normal-appearing lymph node.

Option B: FDG-PET CT is expensive and is not widely available.

Option C: FNAC of the parathyroid alone is not enough to accurately localise the parathyroid glands.

questions.text:
118. Which of the following are acceptable times for the insertion of a Copper IUD?

1. Immediately postpartum 2. Within 48 hours postpartum 3. Until day 5-7 of menstrual cycle 4. Within 7 days before next menstrual cycle
questions.solution:
The acceptable times for the insertion of a copper IUD are immediately postpartum, within 48 hours postpartum and until day 5-7 of menstrual cycle, but not within 7 days before next menstrual cycle. 

The different timings for IUCD insertion are as follows:

* Post-placental: Can be done immediately, within 10 minutes after expulsion of the placenta following a vaginal delivery. (Statement 1)

* Intracesarean: Insertion during cesarean delivery, after removal of the placenta and before closure of the uterine incision.

* Within 48 hours after delivery: Should be done before the patient is discharged from the hospital. (Statement 2)

* Extended postpartum: Any time after 6 weeks postpartum.

* Interval insertion: Refers to insertion during the interconceptional period. It is preferable to insert the IUCD 2–3 days after menstruation ends. However, insertion during the menstrual phase is also safe and offers certain advantages (e.g., open cervical canal, distended uterine cavity, reduced cramping). Therefore, insertion until day 5–7 of the menstrual cycle is acceptable, as the likelihood of pregnancy is low during this time. (Statement 3)

* Postabortal: Can be inserted immediately after pregnancy termination by suction and evacuation or dilatation and evacuation, or following a spontaneous abortion.

* As emergency contraception: May be inserted up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse.

However, insertion within 7 days before the next expected menstrual cycle is not advisable. This is because ovulation may have already occurred, and pregnancy cannot be confidently ruled out, increasing the risk of inserting the IUD in an early, undiagnosed pregnancy (Statement 4).

Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) are a safe, effective and reversible method of contraception. The different types of IUCD are shown below:

questions.text: 119. A neonate born at 36 weeks of gestation presenting with respiratory distress requires to be on 30% FiO2. He is otherwise normal. A chest X-ray is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the newborn of 36 weeks gestation presenting with respiratory distress on 30% FiO2, and chest X-ray showing fluid in the intralobar fissures suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Transient Tachypnea of the newborn.

It is more common in a term infant. Other risk factors are twin gestation, maternal asthma, maternal hypertension, late prematurity, precipitous delivery, perinatal depression, gestational diabetes, macrosomia, and cesarean delivery, particularly without labour. It occurs due to ineffective clearance of fetal lung fluid, which leads to retained fetal lung fluid, which decreases pulmonary compliance and impedes gas exchange. 

It is characterised by the early onset of tachypnea (>60 breaths/min), and sometimes along with retractions or expiratory grunting. Cyanosis, if present, is relieved by minimal O2 supplementation (<40%). The chest radiograph shows prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the intralobar fissures. Small pleural effusions may be present rarely. Supportive treatment is required, and most of the infants recover rapidly. 

Other options :

Option B: Respiratory distress syndrome occurs primarily in neonates of less than 34 weeks of gestation. The X-ray in such cases shows low lung volumes, a diffuse, fine reticular granularity of the parenchyma (ground-glass appearance), and air bronchograms.

Option C: Meconium aspiration syndrome commonly affects term and post-term babies. Also, the chest X-ray here will show patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of both lung fields, increased anteroposterior diameter, and flattening of the diaphragm with possible pneumothorax. There is usually a history of fetal distress and hypoxia requiring resuscitation at birth, and infants are meconium-stained.

Option D: Pneumonia is seen in term and preterm neonates. The neonate also has features of sepsis in addition to respiratory distress. Chest X-ray shows asymmetric patchy parenchymal opacities.

Pearl PM0028: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

* Mediastinal shift

* Bowel loops in the left hemithorax



Respiratory Distress Syndrome

* Low lung volume

* Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)

* Air bronchogram

* White-out lung (severe disease)



Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

* Hyperinflation

* Patchy infiltrates

* Coarse streaking

questions.text: 120. Which is the new psychoactive drug which has a rapid onset of anti-depressant action?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the new psychoactive drug which has a rapid onset of anti-depressant action. 

Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent which has been shown to produce a rapid, substantial, and persistent reduction in symptoms in patients with major depressive disorder. It inhibits the postsynaptic glutamate binding protein N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. Because abnormalities in glutamatergic signaling have been implicated in major depressive disorder, this may account for its efficacy.

Patients usually receive a single infusion of ketamine over a 30-minute period at a concentration of 0.5 mg/kg. A positive response is usually seen within 24 hours, and improved mood lasts for about 2 to 7 days.  Side effects like dizziness, headache, and poor coordination are commonly seen. Dissociative symptoms, including hallucinations, may also occur

Although ketamine appears effective, its use in depression treatment is off-label. Only esketamine, its S-enantiomer, is FDA-approved for major depressive disorder. 

Other options: 

Option A: Bupropion is an antidepressant that acts by dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition. The onset of its therapeutic effect usually occurs during the second week of therapy. and is not known for rapid action. It is mainly indicated for smoking cessation. 

Option B: Mephedrone is a recreational psychoactive drug which has no proven antidepressant effects. 

Option C: Cannabidiol is a non-psychoactive compound from cannabis with potential therapeutic uses. However, its benefits are still being studied, and it is not approved for depression.

questions.text: 121. A 60-year-old man with a previous history of cataract surgery two weeks back presented with diminution of vision, visual acuity 5/60, anterior chamber cells, vitreous haze with no fundus details visible. What is the diagnosis and the organism causing it?

choices.text: Toxic anterior segment syndrome; No organism

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of cataract surgery two weeks prior, presenting with diminution of vision, visual acuity 5/60, anterior chamber cells, vitreous haze, with no fundus details visible, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Endophthalmitis. The organism causing it is Staphylococcus.

Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e. uveal tissue and retina, associated with the presence of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber. The patient presents with pain, swelling of the lid and a marked diminution of vision.

Early-onset endophthalmitis occurs less than 4 weeks (usually within 7 days) after cataract surgery and is usually caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp, gram-negative bacteria (Pseudomonas spp., Proteus spp., Haemophilus influenzae, Klebsiella spp., Escherichia coli, Bacillus spp., Enterobacter spp.) and anaerobes.

Delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis occurs more than 4 weeks (Option B) after cataract surgery and is caused by bacteria like Propionibacterium acnes or fungi like Aspergillus, Fusarium, Candida, Cephalosporium, and Penicillium.

The intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. They are injected after taking a 0.2- to 0.3-mL vitreous aspirate for preparing smears and obtaining cultures. Other modalities of treatment include topical antibiotics, cycloplegics, oral steroids and pars plana vitrectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Toxic anterior segment syndrome is characterised by anterior segment inflammation. Vitreous inflammation is rare.

Option D: Patients of mucormycosis present with pain, proptosis, and necrotic areas with black eschar formation on the mucosa of the palate, turbinates and nasal septum and skin of the eyelids. It is usually seen in immunocompromised patients, like diabetics.

Pearl PM2181: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

* Acute post-operative endophthalmitis

* Retained lens matter

* Corneal edema

* Wound leak and dehiscence

* Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

* Posterior capsule opacification (most common)

* Delayed-onset post-operative endophthalmitis

* Cystoid macular edema

* Secondary glaucoma

* Retinal detachment

* Intraocular lens malpositions:

* Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium

* Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation

* Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation

* Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: 122. The neural center responsible for explicit memory is
questions.solution:
The hippocampus is the neural centre responsible for explicit memory.

Forms of memory are classified into two types, explicit and implicit:

* Explicit/declarative memory is the memory of factual knowledge about people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. It is of 2 types:

*

* Semantic memory (facts), e.g., knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people, etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral and anterior temporal cortex, as well as the prefrontal cortex.

* Episodic memory (events), e.g., recalling the events that occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

* Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory does not involve consciousness or awareness. It is of 4 types:

*

* Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.

* Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependent on the neocortex.

* Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitisation. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.

* Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning, in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for its motor responses.

Pearl PM0907: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: 123. Inflammation associated with caspase-1 is seen in which of the following types of cell death?
questions.solution:
Inflammation associated with caspase-1 is seen in Pyroptosis.

Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:

* Activation of the inflammasome complex

* Activation of caspase-1

* Generation of IL-1 - results in fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment

Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation, including leukocyte recruitment and fever. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

* There is cellular swelling

* There is loss of cell membrane integrity

* It is associated with inflammation

* Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved

Other options:

Option A: Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent, distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function, which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Option B: Apoptosis: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9, whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3 and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclear fragmentation.

Option C: Necroptosis, as the name suggests, has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterised by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. Necroptosis involves two kinases called receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 and 3 (RIPK1 and RIPK3). This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the respiratory bronchiole. It has simple cuboidal epithelial lining lacking cilia and goblet cells with outpockets communicating with the alveoli.

Terminal bronchioles represent the most distal parts of the conducting passage. Each terminal bronchiole ends by dividing into respiratory bronchioles. Terminal bronchioles contain cilia and stratified columnar epithelium, whereas respiratory bronchioles contain few or no cilia, and simple cuboidal epithelium. Another differentiating point between the two is that terminal bronchioles would not communicate with the alveoli but respiratory bronchioles would have a communication with the alveoli. (Option B)

Each respiratory bronchiole ends by dividing into a few alveolar ducts. Each alveolar duct ends in a passage, the atrium, which leads into a number of rounded alveolar sacs. Each alveolar sac is studded with a number of air sacs or alveoli and are lined by simple squamous epithelium. (Option D)

Bronchi and bronchioles can be distinguished by the presence of cartilage and glands in the bronchi which are not present in the bronchioles. (Option C)

questions.text: 125. According to the National Aids Control Programme, which of the following is NOT a high risk group?

choices.text: Men who have sex with men

questions.solution:
Long-distance truck drivers are not included in the high-risk core population for HIV transmission. They are a part of the bridge population.

Bridge populations are those groups that are not in the high-risk group but have proximity to the high-risk group. The relevant bridge populations for HIV transmission are migrant workers and long-distance truckers. Thus, they also receive targeted interventions for the control of AIDS transmission.

Target interventions for the control of AIDS transmission are done for high-risk core populations, like:

* Sex workers

* Men who have sex with men

* Transgender

* Injection drug users

The services offered through targeted interventions include detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases and condom distribution.

questions.text: 126. A 12 year old was brought with rigidity and cognitive impairment. T2W MRI showing tiger eye sign as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the cause?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI image showing the eye of the tiger sign, is suggestive of Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome. Pantothenate kinase deficiency is the cause.

The eye of the tiger sign refers to an abnormal, low T2 signal intensity on MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus, with a longitudinal stripe of high signal intensity (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

This is an autosomal recessive disorder that typically manifests in childhood, leading to spasticity, Parkinsonism, and dystonia. It is classified as a subtype of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA).

The image below shows an MRI depicting the eye of a tiger sign.



Other options:

Option B: Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. Neurological features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia.

Option C: Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase.

Option D: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder. The disease predominantly affects the striatum but progresses to involve the cerebral cortex and other brain regions.

The following image shows spine like pseudopodia of Acanthamoeba:

questions.text: 128. A researcher studies the incidence of measles in a population of 100 children, where 10 children have a previous history of measles, and 20 have been affected by the disease for the first time. What is the incidence?
questions.solution:
The incidence of measles is 22.22%.

Incidence is defined as the number of new cases of a disease in a specific period of time, divided by the total population at risk.

Given data: - Total population = 100 children - Previous history of measles = 10 children (these are not considered "new" cases) - New cases of measles = 20 children

Since incidence only considers new cases, we ignore the 10 children with a previous history of measles. The population at risk is the total population minus those who already had measles, which is 100 - 10 = 90 children.

Incidence = (Number of new cases) / (Population at risk) = 20 / 90 = 0.2222 or 22.22%

Therefore, the correct answer is 22.22%.

Pearl PM0228: Incidence and Prevalence

* Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:



It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

* Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:



It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

* In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".

* In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.

* If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.

* If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text:
129. Which of the following are used to treat scabies in infants?

1. Permethrin 5% 2. Ivermectin 3. Crotamiton 10% 4. Benzyl benzoate 25%
questions.solution:
Permethrin 5% and Crotamiton 10% are used to treat scabies in infants.

Permethrin cream (5%) is the treatment of choice for scabies. It is applied topically twice, 1 week apart, and it is approved for infants ≥ 2 months of age.

Crotamiton (10%) ointment is applied topically overnight on days 1, 2, 3, and 8.

Other options:

Ivermectin is contraindicated in children <15 kg.

Benzyl benzoate (25%) ointment is contraindicated in children.

questions.text:
130. Which of the following statements are correct about negative pressure dressing?
* Decreases bacterial load 
* Pressure of -125 mm Hg used
* Reduces edema and forms more granulation tissue
* Dressing can be done after 5-7 days
* Used continuosly or intermittently
questions.solution:
All the statements (1, 2, 3, 4 and 5) are correct about negative pressure dressing. 

Negative pressure dressing, also called as vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), uses intermittent or continuous topical negative pressure (up to –125 mmHg) through a sealed foam dressing in order to stimulate the formation of granulation tissue, reduce local oedema and tissue exudate and reduce bacterial load. It is used as a dressing to secure a skin graft to its recipient bed, temporary coverage of a complex acute wound (e.g. an open abdomen) until definitive cover can be achieved or to manage chronic wounds such as pressure ulcers. It is not recommended in the setting of exposed vessels, malignancy, untreated osteomyelitis, necrotic tissue or non-enteric and unexplored fstulae. 

Method of VAC application includes thorough debridement, adequate haemostasis and application of sterile foams dressing. A fenestrated tube is embedded in the foam and the wound is sealed with adhesive tape to make it airtight. The fenestrated tube is connected to a vacuum pump with a fluid collection container. The image given below shows negative-pressure wound therapy to promote wound healing in an open abdomen.



Frequent dressing changes during negative-pressure wound therapy are costly and cause patient discomfort. Hence a 5-7 days interval between changes of the dressing is acceptable depending on clinical assessment.

questions.text:
131. Which of the following are the causes of stridor in neonates

1. Subglottic stenosis  2. Recurrent Respiratory papillomatosis 3. Haemorrhagic polyp 4. Laryngomalacia
questions.solution:
Subglottic stenosis and Laryngomalacia are the causes of stridor in neonates.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

* Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

* Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

* Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.



Other options:

Option 2: Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis presents with stridor in children and not in neonates.

Option 3: Haemorrhagic polyp may present with obstruction but not with stridor.

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.
