questions.text: 132. Which is the law under the government which ensures medical data security in India?
questions.solution:
The Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 (DPDP) is the law under the government that ensures medical data security in India.

It is an act to provide for the processing of digital personal data in a manner that recognises both the right of individuals to protect their data and the need to process such personal data for lawful purposes and matters connected with them.

Other options:

Option A: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) of 1996 establishes federal standards protecting sensitive health information from disclosure without a patient's consent.  It was issued by the US Department of Health and Human Services.

Option C: The Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PNDT) Act provide for the prohibition of sex selection, before or after conception, and for regulation of prenatal diagnostic techniques to detect genetic abnormalities or metabolic disorders or chromosomal abnormalities or certain congenital malformations or sex-linked disorders and for the prevention of their misuse for sex determination leading to female foeticide.

Option D: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is the toughest privacy and security law in the world. Though it was drafted and passed by the European Union (EU), it imposes obligations on organisations anywhere, so long as they target or collect data related to people in the EU.

questions.text:
133. In optic neuritis, which of the following statements is true?

1. 70% patients of multiple sclerosis present with optic neuritis  2. Oral steroids are an appropriate treatment  3. It can have a normal fundus with no disc edema  4. Colour vision and contrast are proportionally affected to vision impairment
questions.solution:
The correct statement is Statement 3, it can have a normal fundus with no disc oedema as in Retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis can be classified into three anatomical types:

* Papillitis is characterised by involvement of the optic disc in inflammatory and demyelinating disorders

* Neuroretinitis refers to the combined involvement of the optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area

* Retrobulbar neuritis in which the optic disc appears normal because the optic nerve head is not involved and there is no disc oedema

Other statements:

Statement 1: 70% patients of multiple sclerosis present with optic neuritis is incorrect. Optic neuritis is the presenting feature of multiple sclerosis in up to 30%. Optic neuritis occurs at some point in 50% of patients with established multiple sclerosis.

Statement 2: Oral steroids alone are contraindicated in the treatment of acute optic neuritis, since they do not improve visual outcome and are associated with a significant increase in the risk of new attacks of optic neuritis.

Statement 4: Colour vision and contrast are proportionally affected to vision impairment is not correct as there is not enough evidence for the same to conclude they are proportionally affected.

questions.text: 134. A 14-year-old female with SLE presents with proteinuria and rising creatinine. Renal biopsy shows a wire loop lesion. What is the most appropriate induction therapy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario female with SLE with proteinuria, rising creatinine and renal biopsy showing a wire loop lesion, suggests the diagnosis to be lupus nephritis. The most appropriate induction therapy is Cyclophosphamide + IV steroids.

Corticosteroids form the most important part of the induction therapy. Severe disease is treated with high doses of intravenous methylprednisolone. Corticosteroid dosages are gradually tapered over months as disease manifestations improve.

Cyclophosphamide is a steroid-sparing immunosuppressive agent added to limit cumulative steroid exposure. Cyclophosphamide is used for severe, potentially life-threatening SLE manifestations, such as renal, neurological, and cardiopulmonary disease. It is highly effective in controlling the disease. The potential toxicities include cytopenias, infection, hemorrhagic cystitis, premature gonadal failure, and increased risk of future malignancy.

Other options:

Option A: Rituximab can be used to treat severe haematological manifestations and is not the preferred agent in induction therapy.

Option C: Mycophenolate mofetil can be used in maintenance therapy once the remission has been achieved. Mycophenolate mofetil monotherapy for induction is not recommended. It can be used as an add-on drug, but corticosteroids are the mainstay for induction therapy.

Option D: Only High-dose steroids will not be recommended since additional therapy is required in cases of SLE with renal, neurological, and cardiopulmonary manifestations.

Pearl PM1568: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II) | Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits Focal lupus nephritis (class III) | Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV) | The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy. * Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli

* Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli

* Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus

* Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.solution:
The total dependency ratio in this population is 0.66.

questions.solution:
Erythema > 1/3rd of the breast surface is not included under Stage T4b. 

According to the TNM staging criteria, T4b includes any of the following skin changes:

* Ulceration of the overlying skin (Option D)

* Macroscopic satellite nodules on the ipsilateral breast skin (Option C)

questions.text: 137. All of the following cause fetal bradycardia during labour except:
questions.solution:
Maternal fever causes fetal tachycardia, and not bradycardia. 

Causes of fetal bradycardia (FHR<110bpm):

* Fetal hypoxia due to maternal or fetal causes (eg. placental abruption)

* Fetal sepsis

* Fetal anomalies

* Drugs to mother, e.g., pethidine, antihypertensives (methyldopa, propranolol), MgSO4

* Use of local anesthetic drugs or epidural analgesia

* Fetal congenital heart block or conduction defects

* Maternal hypoglycemia and hypothermia

Low baseline heart rate is also seen in fetal head compression from occiput posterior or transverse positions during second-stage labor.

Prolonged deceleration is seen in placental abruption which is the abrupt decrease in fetal heart rate ( of 15 bpm or more) to levels below the baseline and it lasts >3 min but <10 min. It can also be seen in uterine rupture, cord prolapse and uterine hyperstimulation.

Causes of fetal tachycardia (FHR>160bpm):

* Maternal fever (most common cause)

* Drugs to mother - Eg. Isoxsuprine and ritodrine used to inhibit preterm labor and vagolytics like atropine.

* Maternal hyperthyroidism and metabolic acidemia

* Infection

* Anemia

questions.text: 139. A 2-year-old child presents with leg pain, difficulty walking and easy fatigability. Which is the unusual diagnosis for this?
questions.solution:
The unusual diagnosis for this clinical presentation is Metastatic retinoblastoma.

The given clinical symptom of leg pain signifies that the patient has bone involvement due to a disease. Retinoblastoma spreads by direct extension to the choroid or along the optic nerve to the central nervous system, or by hematogenous or lymphatic spread to distant sites, including bones, bone marrow, and lungs. However, Retinoblastoma rarely presents with metastasis at the time of diagnosis. Evaluation for tumour metastasis using the cerebrospinal fluid, bone marrow, and radionuclide bone scan is required only if indicated by clinical, laboratory, or imaging findings.

Ewing sarcoma, Metastatic renal clear cell sarcoma, and Metastatic neuroblastoma present with bone involvement as a common presentation. 

Other options:

Option A: Ewing sarcoma patients commonly present with pain, swelling, limitation of motion, and tenderness over the involved bone or soft tissue.

Option B: Metastatic renal clear cell sarcoma presents with secondaries to bone. A bone scan to look for bone metastasis is performed as soon as the histologic diagnosis confirms clear cell sarcoma of the kidney or rhabdoid tumour of the kidney. 

Option D: Metastatic neuroblastoma with common sites of metastasis are the regional or distant lymph nodes, long bones and skull, bone marrow, liver, and skin.

questions.text: 140. A 9-month-old child is unable to sit without support but can roll over from side to side. The child can say words like 'mama' and 'dada' without meaning and exhibits stranger anxiety, becoming distressed upon encountering unfamiliar people. What is the appropriate next step in managing this child's development?

choices.text: Reassurance since it is a normal developmental variant
Immediate referral for assessment of development
Start physical therapy to help her sit

questions.solution:
The appropriate next step in managing this child's development is reassurance, since it is a normal developmental variant.

Normally, the gross motor milestone of sitting without support starts developing from the age of 8 months. The upper limit of age for being able to sit without support is 10 months, and the child is only 9 months old. Hence, the mother must be reassured about the concern.

questions.text: 141. "Lord hanuman is celibate. I am celibate. So, I am Lord Hanuman." What is this type of thinking seen in Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
This type of thinking as described is autistic thinking which is seen in Schizophrenia. 

Autistic thinking is defined as thinking in which the thoughts are largely narcissistic and egocentric, with emphasis on subjectivity rather than objectivity, and without regard for reality. It is seen in schizophrenia and autistic disorder. The reasoning "Lord hanuman is celibate. I am celibate. So, I am Lord Hanuman" is an illogical personal association not grounded in rational logic, characteristic of autistic thinking in schizophrenia.

Other options:

Option A: Loosening of association is defined as gradual or sudden deviation in train of thought without blocking, also known as derailment. 

Option B: Neologism refers to new word or phrase whose derivation cannot be understood and is often seen in schizophrenia.

Option D: Verbigeration refers to meaningless and stereotyped repetition of words or phrases, also seen in schizophrenia.

Pearl PM2383: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT (A) Disorder of tempo (i) Flight of Ideas: Continuous flow of rapid, pressured speech that jumps from topic to topic. 

*

"I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great" (ii) Retardation of thinking: Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

*

"I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed" (iii) Circumstantiality: Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

*

Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

*

Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise." (iv) Clang associations: An association of thoughts with the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming)

*

I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram" (B) Disorder of continuity (i) Perseveration: Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

*

Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

*

Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

*

Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul" (ii) Thought blocking: A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

*

"I went to the market (extreme silence)...................." DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT (i) Tangentiality: In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

* Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"

* Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa" (ii) Derailment: A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

* "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war" (iii) Neologisms: The invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.

* The world is not 'gooder' for people like me" (iv) Desultory thoughts: Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

* My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket" (v) Word salad: Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

* Tree bus rain food home car tiger" DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT A. Thought alienation (i) Thought insertion: Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

*

"I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night" (ii) Thought withdrawal: Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

*

"Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep" (iii) Thought broadcasting: Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

*

"I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" (iv) Thought echo: Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

*

"I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions: Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

* Fear of dirt or contamination

* Fear of becoming ill

* Constant thoughts of a certain number

* Need for symmetry or exactness

* Worry about whether something has been done "right"

* Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions: Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

* Washing hands

* Blinking eyes

* Counting items, such as currency

* Checking to see if doors are locked

* Arranging items in a certain way

* Requiring constant approval from people around them DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT (i) Phobia: Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

*

Arachnophobia - fear of spider

*

Barophobia - fear of gravity

*

Cynophobia - fear of dogs

*

Hemophobia - fear of blood

*

Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals (ii) Religious preoccupations: Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

*

"I get instructions from God on how to make my country great" (iii) Ideas of hopelessness: Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

*

"I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study" (iv) Antisocial urges: Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

*

"I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money" (v) Delusions: False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

*

Certainty (held with complete confidence)

*

Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)

*

Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue) DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS *

Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

*

Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

*

Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

*

Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

"I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

*

Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

"The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: 142. A 12 year old boy presents with pain and swelling in the left leg. On examination, the leg is swollen and warm. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and CRP levels. An X-ray shows sclerotic bone fragments with surrounding lucencies in the medulla. Which of the following is unlikely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain, swelling, elevated ESR/CRP, and sclerotic bone with lucencies on X-ray suggests chronic osteomyelitis. Among the organisms listed, Klebsiella is least likely to cause this.

The causative organisms of chronic osteomyelitis are:

* Staphylococcus aureus

* Escherichia coli (Option D)

* Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B)

* Proteus mirabilis

* Pseudomonas aeruginosa

* Staphylococcus epidermidis in the presence of foreign implants

* Mycobacterium tuberculosis, especially in endemic regions, can cause tuberculous osteomyelitis (Option C) 

In contrast, Klebsiella species are rarely associated with osteomyelitis. While Klebsiella can cause a range of infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections, its involvement in bone infections is uncommon. 

In chronic osteomyelitis, the patient presents with pain, pyrexia, redness and tenderness or with a discharging sinus. In long-standing cases, the tissues are thickened and often puckered or folded inwards where a scar or sinus adheres to the underlying bone. There may be a seropurulent discharge and excoriation of the surrounding skin. During acute flares, ESR, CRP and WBC count may be increased.

questions.text: 143. Advanced diabetes mellitus is associated with?
questions.solution:
Advanced diabetes mellitus is associated with tractional retinal detachment.

Tractional retinal detachment occurs due to the retina being mechanically pulled away from its bed by the contraction of fibrous tissue in the vitreous (known as vitreoretinal tractional bands). Advanced diabetes mellitus is characterised by uncontrolled proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which causes traction over the retina.

Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following types:

* Rhegmatogenous/primary retinal detachment

* Tractional

* Exudative

Other causes of Tractional retinal detachment include:

* Retinopathy of prematurity

* Eales' disease

* Sickle cell retinopathy

* Incontinenda pigmenti

* Post-haemorrhagic retinitis proliferans

* Toxocariasis

* Vitreomacular traction syndrome

* Retinal dysplasia

Characteristic signs of tractional RD include a concave configuration of the detached retina with no breaks seen. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and shifting fluid is absent. The patient does not complain of photopsia and floaters because traction develops insidiously.

Other options:

Option B: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal break (hole or tear) through which subretinal fluid seeps and separates the sensory retina from the pigmentary epithelium.

Option C: Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the retina being pushed away by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina following inflammatory or vascular lesions.

questions.text:
145. A 70-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with worsening shortness of breath, pedal oedema, and cough. The ECHO shows concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, left atrial dilation, EF - 60%, normal systolic function, and grade 2 diastolic dysfunction. BNP is 920. What would be the best long-term management for this patient?

SGLT2i - Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter-2 inhibitors

HFpEF- Heart failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction

EF- Ejection Fraction

BNP - Brain Natriuretic Peptide

choices.text: Ivabradine to decrease heart rate and improve ventricular filling
Coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy
Initiate SGLT2i and loop diuretics for management of HFpEF

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with EF-60 % suggests Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF). The best long-term management for this patient will be to initiate SGLT2i and loop diuretics for management of HFpEF. 

Treatment of diabetic patients with SGLT2i has been shown to reduce the incidence of heart failure, raising the possibility that these agents may be effective in such patients. This is a novel therapy for HFpEF, and trials are still going on to assess the benefits. Angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors (ARNI) are also a part of novel therapy under trials. Treatment of HFpEF focuses on decongestion, aggressive management of medical comorbidities, and relief of exacerbating factors.

Other options:

Option A: Ivabradine, an inhibitor of the If current in the sinoatrial node, selectively reduces heart rate without affecting cardiac contractility or vascular tone in cases of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

Option B: Coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy is done in cases of suspected coronary artery blockage, such as when a patient presents with angina.

Option D: Digoxin is used to improve myocardial contractility in HFrEF. It exerts a mild inotropic effect, attenuates carotid sinus baroreceptor activity, and is sympatho-inhibitory. These effects decrease serum norepinephrine levels, plasma renin levels, and possibly aldosterone levels.

questions.text: 146. A 46-year-old man with a history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus presents with a complicated UTI, urinalysis shows more than 40 WBCs. He is hypotensive and not responding to IV fluids. What would be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
A diabetic patient with a complicated UTI, now presenting with hypotension unresponsive to IV fluids, is suggestive of urosepsis (septic shock). Hence, the patient should be treated with Meropenem. In septic shock, there is peripheral vasodilation due to toxins from the infectious agent causing endothelial injury and fluid leak, leading to hypotension, which can be refractory to fluid therapy in the early stages.

Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are more common in diabetic patients due to poor metabolic control, altered immune status, poor bladder control and incomplete voiding. E. coli is the most common organism to cause urinary tract infections. Other organisms causing infections include Klebsiella spp, Proteus spp, Enterobacter spp and Enterococci. A complicated urinary tract infection is accompanied by symptoms that suggest the infection extends beyond the bladder, such as a fever or signs and symptoms of systemic illness.

ESBL-positive E. coli is an emerging pathogen responsible for urinary tract infections. Oral antibiotic therapy may not consistently be effective against this organism. For complicated infections caused by ESBL-positive E. coli, it is recommended to use empiric therapy with a carbapenem.

Carbapenems, including doripenem, imipenem, meropenem, and ertapenem, offer the most reliable coverage for strains containing extended-spectrum β-lactamases. All carbapenems have broad activity against gram-positive cocci, gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes.

Factors that suggest a complicated urinary tract infection:

* Functional or anatomic abnormality of the urinary tract

* Male gender

* Diabetes

* Elderly

* Immunosuppression

* Childhood urinary tract infection

* Recent antimicrobial usage

* Indwelling urinary catheter

* Urinary tract instrumentation

* Hospital-acquired infection

* Symptoms more than 7 days at presentation.

Other options: 

Option B: Amoxiclav is used for the treatment of upper respiratory tract infections and skin and soft tissue infections. Though most cases of UTI are caused by E. coli, due to increased resistance (ESBL-producing strains), it can be challenging to treat with oral beta-lactams and generally, they have lower cure rates compared to other classes of drugs, such as fluoroquinolones or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Option C: Ceftriaxone is given for uncomplicated infections. Fourth and fifth-generation cephalosporins can be used for complicated UTIs.

Option D: Nitrofurantoin is used for the treatment of uncomplicated infections. It is rapidly excreted in the urine but does not obtain therapeutic levels in most body tissues, including the gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, it is not useful for upper tract, complicated infections, or blood-borne infections.

questions.text: 147. Tight junctions are present in which of the following epithelial domains?
questions.solution:
Tight junctions are present in the apicolateral part of the epithelium.

Tight junctions, also known as zonula occludens, tie cells together and endow tissues with strength and stability. They are made up of ridges—half from one cell and half from the other—which adhere so strongly at cell junctions that they almost obliterate the space between the cells. They permit the passage of ions, solutes and intracellular signalling molecules between adjacent cells. 

There are three main families of transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junctions:

* Occludin

* Junctional adhesion molecules

* Claudins 

It is present in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. They are important for endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation. They prevent the movement of proteins in the plane of the membrane, which helps to maintain the different distribution of transporters and channels that make transport across epithelia possible.

questions.text: 148. A child presents with petechiae and ecchymosis. His platelet count is 10,000/mm³, and bone marrow is normal with increased megakaryocytes. What is the next best initial step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with petechiae and ecchymosis, a platelet count of 10,000/mm³, and a normal bone marrow with increased megakaryocytes suggests a diagnosis of Acute Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP). The next best initial step in management in this case is IVIG.

Acute Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura is characterised by immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It usually occurs in childhood with equal frequency in both males and females. Symptoms appear 1 to 2 weeks after a self-limited viral illness, which appears to trigger the development of autoantibodies through uncertain mechanisms. An increased number of megakaryocytes can be seen in the marrow. 

It is characterised by bleeding into the skin and mucosal surfaces. Pinpoint haemorrhages (petechiae) are especially prominent in the dependent areas where the capillary pressure is higher. Petechiae can become confluent, leading to ecchymoses. Often, there is a history of easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and haemorrhages into soft tissues from minor trauma. 

Acute ITP is self-limiting and usually resolves spontaneously within 6 months. Glucocorticoids are given only if the thrombocytopenia is severe.

questions.text: 149. What is the WHO recommended investigation of choice for spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
CBNAAT Is the WHO recommended investigation of choice for spinal tuberculosis.

WHO recommends CBNAAT (GeneXpert) as the investigation of choice for diagnosis of extra-pulmonary tuberculosis, especially for CSF, lymph nodes and other tissue specimens. It has the lowest turnaround time (2 hours) among all the diagnostic methods. It is based on real-time PCR technique and simultaneously detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex DNA and rifampicin resistance (mutations of the rpoB gene). It uses five probes targeting various sequences of rpoB gene. 

In cases of extrapulmonary TB, the demonstration of acid-fast bacilli on the smear is difficult because the bacillary load itself is low. For this reason, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for extrapulmonary TB. Traditional methods such as culture and sensitivity take a long time of around 4-6 weeks. Hence, there is a need for a rapid diagnostic test like CBNAAT (Option B).

Spinal tuberculosis (Pott's spine) is always secondary. The bacteria reach the spine via the haematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes. It spreads via the para-vertebral plexus of veins i.e., Batson's plexus, which has free communication with the visceral plexus of the abdomen, a common site of tuberculosis. Clinical features include pain, stuffiness, swelling (cold abscess), paraplegia or deformity (gibbus). 

The spine is the commonest site of bone and joint tuberculosis. It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. MRI is the radiological investigation of choice. Imaging studies like X-rays or NCCT scans may indicate bony destruction or evidence of abscess but they are not the investigation of choice.  (Option C and D).

Paradiscal areas are the most common site of vertebral involvement. The image below shows the various patterns of involvement in Pott's spine:



Pearl PM1720: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases.  All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II) Type of TB Case | Intensive Phase | Continuation Phase New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) | 2 months HRZE | 4 months HRE (Only HR as per WHO guidelines) Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

* Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

* Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 

* Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

* Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.

* Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: 150. Which of the following is not seen in cardiac failure?

choices.text: Shortness of breath within 2-3 hours after going to bed

questions.solution:
Non-pulsatile elevated JVP is not seen in cardiac failure.

Non-pulsatile elevated JVP is seen in cardiac tamponade. Tamponade results in elevated right atrial pressure and elevated right ventricular pressures. This results in a prominent x descent and a diminished or absent y descent in the JVP. The resultant JVP is elevated but nonpulsatile in nature due to the persistently raised pressures in the right side of the heart. 

Orthopnea, right hypochondriac region pain, and shortness of breath within 2-3 hours after going to bed are seen in cardiac failure.

Cardiac failure is a complex clinical syndrome that results from any structural or functional impairment of ventricular filling or ejection of blood, leading to cardinal manifestations of dyspnea, fatigue, and fluid retention.

Orthopnea refers to dyspnea that occurs in the recumbent position within 1–2 minutes of lying down. It occurs due to the redistribution of fluid from the abdomen and lower body into the chest, increased work of breathing due to decreased lung compliance and elevation of the diaphragm in patients with ascites or hepatomegaly. The symptoms may be relieved by raising the head and chest with pillows or an adjustable bed.

Right hypochondriac region pain occurs due to stretching of the hepatic capsule resulting from hepatic congestion in right heart failure.

Shortness of breath within 2-3 hours after going to bed is known as Paroxysmal Nocturnal Dyspnea. It refers to episodes of shortness of breath that awaken a patient from sleep with feelings of anxiety and suffocation. The symptoms get relieved on sitting upright for 30 minutes or more. Right heart failure | Left heart failure Due to congestion in the systemic circulation | Due to congestion in the pulmonary circulation Symptoms and signs:

* Right hypochondriac region pain

* Congestive hepatomegaly

* Positive hepatojugular reflux

* Ascites

* Bilateral pitting oedema 

* Weight gain due to oedema

* Fatigue- due to ↓pumping of blood to the lungs, leading to ↓oxygenation of the blood | Symptoms and signs: 

* Dyspnea on exertion

* Orthopnea

* Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (characteristic of LVF)

* Pulmonary rales 

* Increased PCWP

* Fatigue- due to ↓cardiac output

Pearl PM0288: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure Abnormality | Cause Weakness, exercise intolerance, fatigue | Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise Ankle, sacral edema | Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation. Hepatomegaly | Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow. Pulmonary congestion | Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces Dyspnea on exertion | Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure Paroxysmal dyspnea, pulmonary edema | Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces. Orthopnea | Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.) Cardiac dilation | Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction. Abnormality | Conditions Prominent a-waves | Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis Cannon a-waves | Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats Absent a-waves | Atrial fibrillation

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole. Abnormality | Conditions Absent x-descent | Severe tricuspid regurgitation Rapid x-descent | Cardiac tamponade

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium. Abnormality | Conditions Dominant v-waves | Tricuspid regurgitation

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle. Abnormality | Conditions Prolonged y-descent | Tricuspid stenosis Rapid y-descent | Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation Absent y-descent | Cardiac tamponade

151. The RMNCH+ A strategy by MoHFW aims to provide comprehensive healthcare across various life stages. The target demographic for the latest RMNCH+A includes which of the following?

1. Maternal and child health  2. Family planning services 3. Geriatric health  4. Adolescent Health
questions.solution:
Maternal and child health, Family planning services, and Adolescent Health are the target demographics included in the latest RMNCH+A.

RMNCH+A covers Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, Adolescent Health and Nutrition.

The RMNCAH+N strategy promotes links between various interventions across thematic areas to enhance coverage throughout the lifecycle to improve child survival in India. The “plus” within the strategy focuses on:

* Inclusion of adolescence as a distinct life stage within the overall strategy.

* Linking maternal and child health to reproductive health and other components like family planning, adolescent health, HIV, gender, and preconception and prenatal diagnostic techniques.

* Linking home and community-based services to facility-based services.

* Ensuring linkages, referrals, and counter-referrals between and among various levels of the health care system to create a continuous care pathway, and to bring an additive effect in terms of overall outcomes and impact.

questions.text: 153. Autoinfection is most commonly seen with which helminths?
questions.solution:
Autoinfection can be seen with both Strongyloides and H.nana, but it is most commonly seen with Strongyloides.

Strongyloides can persist in a host for decades, potentially a lifetime, due to its ability to autoinfect. In contrast, Hymenolepis nana's autoinfection mechanism only sustains the infection for a limited duration of some years.

Autoinfection occurs when a host is reinfected with the parasite already present within the body. There are two types: 

* Internal reinfection: The infective form of the parasite is formed within the intestine. It penetrates the intestinal mucosa and reinfects the host e.g., Strongyloides.

* External reinfection: The infective form, released from the host's body, contaminates the surrounding environment (e.g. perineal region) and re-enters the host through the hand-to-mouth route. 

The following are the parasites causing autoinfection (mnemonic: CHEST.C)

* Cryptosporidium parvum

* Hymenolepis nana

* Enterobius vermicularis

* Strongyloides stercoralis

* Taenia solium

* Capillaria philippinensis

Note: 

Autoinfection in H. nana may occur if eggs hatch inside the host, but re-infection usually happens through hand-to-mouth contact after scratching the anal region.

questions.solution:
P53 is not associated with Mucosal neuromas and hence, the wrong pair.

P53 is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which includes oesophageal cancers, sarcomas, breast cancers, leukaemias, brain tumours, and carcinomas of the adrenal cortex.

MEN-2B is associated with RET gene mutation and characterised by neuromas or ganglioneuromas involving the skin, oral mucosa, eyes, respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, and a marfanoid habitus, with long axial skeletal features and hyperextensible joints.

Option A: PTEN is associated with Cowden syndrome, which includes breast, endometrial, and thyroid carcinoma and benign skin, gastrointestinal, and CNS growths.

Option B: BRCA2 is associated with Prostate cancer. 

Option D: STK 11 is associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and a high risk of breast cancer.

questions.text: 155. Obesity and overweight are linked to several cancers. The risk of which of these is not increased with obesity or overweight?
questions.solution:
The risk of meningioma is not increased with obesity or overweight.

Meningiomas are usually benign, slow-growing, smaller lesions, usually detected incidentally in an elderly patient. They arise from the meninges. If the lesion is large or positioned to impinge on main structures, the patient may require steroids and early surgery.

Other options:

Options A, C, and D: Stomach cancer, especially proximal stomach cancer,  multiple myeloma, and pancreatic cancer can occur due to obesity and being overweight.

questions.text: 156. A 35 year old laborer after falling on his outstreched hand presents with pain and swelling over the anatomical snuff box. X Ray is unremarkable. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Thumb spica cast and review after 10-14 days for imaging
MRI to rule out ligamental injuries

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, history of a fall on an outstretched hand followed by pain and swelling over the anatomical snuffbox, despite normal X-ray findings, is suggestive of scaphoid fracture. The next step in the management is to apply a thumb spica cast and review after 10-14 days for imaging.

All the cases of scaphoid fracture with high clinical suspicion with the absence of fracture line on X-ray should be treated with a scaphoid cast for 2 weeks. After 2 weeks repeat imaging is done because up to 30% of patients may have positive follow-up radiographs. Sometimes, the fracture becomes visible at this stage, because of resorption of the fracture ends. If no fracture is seen even at 2 weeks, no further treatment is required. 

A scaphoid fracture is more common in young adults. Commonly, the fracture occurs through the waist of the scaphoid. Clinical features include pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, one may be able to elicit tenderness in the scaphoid fossa(anatomical snuff box). X-ray with an oblique view of the wrist is taken in addition to the anteroposterior and lateral views. Sometimes a fracture line is not visible on initial X-rays. If a fracture is strongly suspected, X-rays should be repeated after 2 weeks.



The affected hand is immobilized in a scaphoid cast for 3-4 months. The scaphoid cast extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads including the thumb up to the inter-phalangeal joint. The wrist is maintained in a little dorsiflexion and radial deviation (glass holding position). In widely displaced fractures, open reduction and internal fixation using a special compression screw (Herbert's screw) is required.

The common complications of scaphoid fracture include:

* Non-union and delayed union

* Avascular necrosis

* Wrist osteoarthritis

Other options:

Options B and C: If pain persists but repeat X-rays remain normal, MRI or CT can then be considered. MRI is more sensitive than CT and has a negative predictive value of 100%, but it is expensive and not always readily available. In contrast, initial immobilization with re-evaluation is a safe and cost-effective approach. Urgent CT or MRI should only be considered if an acute diagnosis is absolutely necessary.

It's important to note that even if an urgent CT confirms a fracture, the patient would still be treated conservatively with thumb spica immobilization. Conversely, if the CT is negative but clinical suspicion remains high, immobilization would still continue with repeat imaging planned later. In other words, CT does not change the initial management, making it an unnecessary early investigation. Furthermore, the primary concern here is a possible scaphoid fracture—not a ligamentous injury. Even if MRI were to reveal a ligamentous injury, the immediate management would still involve immobilization in a thumb spica cast.

Option D: Discharging the patient with only analgesia is inappropriate because a clinically suspected scaphoid fracture, even with a normal initial X-ray, carries a significant risk of complications such as non-union or avascular necrosis due to the bone’s tenuous blood supply. Without proper immobilization, even a small, undetected fracture can worsen, leading to chronic complications.

questions.text: 157. Which of the following describes the metabolic status of Marasmus?

choices.text: Edema due to severe protein deficiency
Severe calorie deficit with normal serum protein
Increased insulin levels with reduced lipolysis
Positive Nitrogen balance and low cortisol levels

questions.solution:
Severe calorie deficit with normal serum protein describes the metabolic status of Marasmus.

Marasmus is a severe form of wasting due to starvation or illness. Fat and muscle tissues are consumed to make energy, leading to severe wasting of these tissues. There is a loss of muscle mass due to catabolism and depletion of the somatic protein compartment. This provides the body with amino acids as a source of energy. The visceral protein compartment, which is more critical for survival, is depleted only marginally, so serum albumin levels are either normal or only slightly reduced.

The child appears very thin with marked loss of fat. There is wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks and thighs. The loss of the buccal pad of fat gives an aged or wrinkled appearance, also known as the monkey facies. The loosening of the skin of the buttocks gives a baggy pants appearance. There is no oedema. Children with marasmus appear to be alert in spite of their condition. 

Other options:

Option A: There is no oedema in marasmus. Oedema is seen in kwashiorkor.

Option C: Decreased insulin levels with increased lipolysis are seen in marasmus due to increased usage of the energy stores of the body.

Option D: Negative Nitrogen balance occurs due to increased breakdown of tissues, and high cortisol levels are seen due to chronic starvation.

questions.text:
159. In Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, what will be the bilirubin finding?

Options | Direct bilirubin | Indirect bilirubin | Urine urobilinogen 1 | Normal | Increased | Increased 2 | Increased | Normal | Absent 3 | Normal | Normal | Normal 4 | Decreased | Decreased | Increased
questions.solution:
In Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, direct bilirubin is normal, indirect bilirubin is increased and urine urobilinogen is increased. 

Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme that plays a critical role in redox reactions that occur in all aerobic cells. It is the only source of NADPH in erythrocytes that helps in the formation of reduced glutathione. This reduced form protects erythrocytes against oxidative stress. Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is an X-linked inheritance disorder. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. But when exposed to oxidative triggers, they are prone to develop acute hemolytic anemia. The various oxidative triggers include:

* Fava beans

* Infections

* Drugs such as primaquine, chloroquine, sulfonamides/sulfones, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. In hemolytic anemia, liver function tests will reveal an elevated indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin because excess hemoglobin from RBCs is converted to bilirubin. The increased production of bilirubin leads to increased production of urobilinogen, which appears in the urine in large amounts. Bilirubin is not usually found in the urine in hemolytic jaundice, so the combination of increased urobilinogen and absence of bilirubin in urine is suggestive of hemolytic jaundice.

questions.text: 161. A patient presents to the OPD with fever. Which area is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The area most likely involved in fever is the Preoptic nucleus.

The preoptic area contains large numbers of heat-sensitive neurons. These neurons function as temperature sensors for controlling body temperature. When the preoptic area is heated, the skin all over the body starts sweating, whereas the skin blood vessels over the entire body become dilated. This response is an immediate reaction to help the body to lose heat, thereby helping to return the body temperature toward the normal level. In addition to this, any excess body heat production is inhibited.

The pathogenesis of fever involves:

* Release of toxins from bacteria, such as endotoxin

* Toxins act on monocytes, macrophages, and Kupffer cells to produce cytokines that act as endogenous pyrogens

* These circulating cytokines are polypeptides that act on the OVLT, one of the circumventricular organs

* This in turn, activates the preoptic area of the hypothalamus

* Raise in temperature set point leading to fever

questions.text: 162. What is the most common type of pituitary adenoma?
questions.solution:
The most common type of pituitary adenoma is a non-functioning adenoma. 

Approximately one-third of all adenomas are clinically non-functioning and produce no distinct clinical hypersecretory syndrome. Most of them arise from gonadotrope cells and may secrete small amounts of α- and β-glycoprotein hormone subunits or, rarely, intact circulating gonadotropins.

questions.text:
163. Match the following.

1. Acute Tolerance | A. Rapid tolerance developing with repeated use on a single occasion, such as in a “binge" 2. Reverse Tolerance | B. Repeated use of a drug in one category confers tolerance to other drugs in the same category 3. Cross Tolerance | C. Increase in response with repetition of the same dose of the drug
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1A, 2C, 3B. 

* Acute tolerance refers to rapid tolerance developing with repeated use on a single occasion, such as in a “binge.” For example, repeated doses of cocaine over several hours produce a decrease in response to subsequent doses of cocaine during the binge. This is the opposite of sensitization, observed with an intermittent-dosing schedule.

* Reverse tolerance or sensitization refers to an increase in response with repetition of the same dose of the drug. Sensitization, in contrast to acute tolerance during a binge, requires a longer interval between doses, usually about one day. Sensitization often occurs with stimulants such as cocaine or amphetamine, but also occurs with other drugs.

* Cross tolerance occurs when repeated use of a drug in a given category confers tolerance not only to that drug but also to other drugs in the same pharmacological category, such as opioid receptor agonists. For example, a patient on methadone maintenance therapy might not experience analgesia elicited by morphine due to cross tolerance.

questions.text: 164. The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to secretion of concentrated urine by all of the following mechanisms except

choices.text: Increases water permeability in collecting ducts
Increased absorption of urea from descending limb of loop of Henle
Increased reabsorption of sodium from thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
Increased absorption of urea  from medullary collecting duct

questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to the secretion of concentrated urine by all of the mentioned mechanisms except for increased absorption of urea from the descending limb of the loop of Henle.    

The primary action of ADH on the kidneys is to enhance absorption of water from the tubular fluid or leads to secretion of concentrated urine by:

* Increasing the water permeability of the distal tubule and collecting duct.

* Increasing the permeability of the medullary portion of the collecting duct to urea.

* Stimulating NaCl reabsorption by the thick ascending limb of Henle’s loop, distal tubule, and collecting duct.

questions.text: 165. A patient with depression was on Imipramine and was started on Diphenhydramine for nasal congestion. Which of the following statements is true regarding the pharmacological relationship between Imipramine and Diphenhydramine?
questions.solution:
Both Imipramine and Diphenhydramine block muscarinic receptors. 

Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant which acts by blocking selective serotonin reuptake, norepinephrine transporter, α1, H1, and M1 receptors. It is used in major depression. Side effects include orthostatic hypotension, weight gain, GI disturbances, sexual dysfunction, seizures, irregular heart beats. 

Diphenhydramine is a first generation antihistamine which acts as H1 receptor inverse agonists. Many of the first-generation H1 antagonists tend to inhibit muscarinic cholinergic responses. It is used in treating motion sickness due to its anticholinergic properties, nausea and vomiting, insomnia. Apart from sedation, side effects include dizziness, tinnitus, incoordination, fatigue, blurred vision, tremors. 

Hence, both Imipramine and Diphenhydramine are muscarinic receptor blockers, which increases the risk of anticholinergic side effects when used together. Neither drug inhibits the metabolism of the other, and only Imipramine acts as a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, not Diphenhydramine.

166. Match the following:

1. Organic irritants | a. Opiod 2. Metallic irritants | b. Croton 3. Deliriant | c. Cocaine 4. Depressant | d. Lead
questions.solution:
The correctly matched class of poisons with their examples are:  Type of Poison | Example 1. Organic irritants | b. Croton 2. Metallic irritants | d. Lead 3. Deliriant | c. Cocaine 4. Depressant | a. Opiod

Poisons may be classified according to the chief symptoms that they produce:

* Organic irritants include (a) Vegetable- Abrus precatorius, castor, croton, calotropis, aloes and (b) Animal- Snake and insect venom, cantharides, ptomaine

* Metallic irritants include arsenic, antimony, copper, lead, mercury, silver, and zinc

* Delirants include datura, belladonna, hyoscyamus, cannabis, and cocaine

* CNS depressants include alcohols, general anaesthetics, opioid analgesics, hypnotics, and sedatives.

The seeds of croton (jamalgota, jaipala, naepala) contain crotin, a toxalbumen (image below). They can produce hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, vomiting, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse and death. When applied to the skin, the oil produces burning, redness and vesication.



Lead is a metallic poison which interacts with sulphydryl groups and interferes with the action of enzymes necessary for heme synthesis, and for haemoglobin and cytochrome production. It interferes with mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation, ATPases, calcium-dependent messengers and enhances oxidation and cell apoptosis. It also causes haemolysis.

Cocaine is obtained from the leaves of Erythroxylum coca (image below). It is a powerful stimulant of CNS for a short time, followed by depression. Similar but less marked effect is seen on the spinal cord. It is an excitant and stimulator of autonomic nervous system. It has sympathomimetic properties.



Opioids exert their effects because of their chemical similarity to natural substances called endorphins. The opiate drugs activate receptor sites normally occupied by the natural opiates or endorphins. It depresses all centres except oculomotor, vomiting and sweating. It is a peripherally acting analgesic. It also stimulates non-propulsive rhythmic contraction of small intestine.

questions.text: 167. Which of the following uterine-stimulating drugs is not used in the management of PPH?
questions.solution:
Dinoprostone is not used in the management of post-partum hemorrhage (PPH). 

Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue which is primarily important for cervical ripening. Intracervical application of dinoprostone (0.5 mg) gel is the gold standard for cervical ripening. It can also be used in the form of tablet or controlled release pessary.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) defined as the excessive bleeding following delivery (>500 mL in vaginal delivery or >1000 mL in cesarean delivery) accompanied by signs and symptoms of hypovolemia.  Atonicity of the uterus is the commonest cause of postpartum hemorrhage.

For the management of PPH, Oxytocin 20-40 units in 1 L of normal saline IV is started at the rate of 20-40 drops per minute immediately. Carbetocin, a longer acting oxytocin derivative is found (100 µg) to be as effective as oxytocin infusion.

In refractory cases,

* Injection 15 Methyl PGF2α 250 µg IM in the deltoid muscle can be given every 15 minutes (up to maximum of 2 mg) or,

* Misoprostol (PGE1) 1000 mg per rectum can also be given.

The test samples in northern, southern, and western blot tests are RNA, DNA, and protein, respectively. Hence, the correct answer is Northern blotting - RNA, Southern blotting - DNA, Western blotting  - Protein. 

Blot transfer tests are of three types based on the sample being tested and the probes used. Here is a table summarizing the test samples and probes used in the blot transfer test. | Northern blot | Southern blot | Western blot Test sample | RNA | DNA | Protein Probe | cDNA | cDNA | Antibody

The common step between them is transferring the separated fragments onto a specific blotting paper after gel electrophoresis. The probe is then added, and it binds to complementary fragments, which are then detected by specific methods like X-ray imaging or autoradiography.

questions.text: 169. A resident ordered the medical student to take procalcitonin for a patient with suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia and was on empirical antibiotic therapy. What is the role of procalcitonin?
questions.solution:
Procalcitonin role is to decide the duration of antibiotics.

Procalcitonin assays are used to decide the duration of antibiotics and for initiating or discontinuing antibiotics in lower respiratory tract infections and for patients with sepsis. 

C-reactive protein (CRP) and Procalcitonin (PCT) are common markers of inflammation that increase in response to  infections. However, PCT is not accurate enough to diagnose community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and should not be the  basis for withholding initial antibiotic treatment.  These tests should be used alongside patient history, physical examination, imaging studies, and other lab tests to ensure effective management and antibiotic stewardship for seriously ill CAP patients.

questions.text: 170. Which of the following is the most common colloid used in the Muir and Barclay formula?
questions.solution:
The common colloid used in Muir and Barclay formula is albumin. 

The original Muir and Barclay formula utilised fresh-frozen plasma as the colloid of choice, but now the most commonly used colloid is human albumin solution.

The most commonly used colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula:

* 0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion

* A total of six portions are given in 36 hours 

* Three portions: One portion for every 4 hours in 12 hours.

* Two portions: One portion for every 6 hours in the next 12 hours.

* One portion: Remaining one portion in the last 12 hours.

Albumin should be preferably administered after the frst 12 hours post burn as the massive fuid shifts drive proteins out of the cells. Plasma proteins are responsible for inward oncotic pressure that counteracts the outward capillary hydrostatic pressure. Parkland formula and Evan's formula are used to calculate the crystalloid volume to be given in the first 24 hours.

questions.text: 171. Cyanide and carbon monoxide act on which of the Heme proteins:
questions.solution:
Cyanide and carbon monoxide act on Cytochrome c oxidase . 

Carbon monoxide binds to the heme iron of cytochrome c oxidase in its reduced (ferrous, Fe²⁺) state. This prevents oxygen from binding and accepting electrons, halting the production of water and the proton gradient. Poisoning with CO can lead to severe hypoxia at the cellular level, even in the presence of normal oxygen levels.

Cyanide binds irreversibly to the ferric (Fe³⁺) iron in the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase. It completely blocks electron transfer to oxygen, making it a potent inhibitor. Cyanide poisoning results in rapid cellular asphyxiation and is life-threatening. 

Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain (ETC) is the terminal enzyme that facilitates the transfer of electrons to molecular oxygen, reducing it to water. Various inhibitors can block this process, leading to impaired oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis including hydrogen sulfide which inhibits Complex IV at high concentrations by binding to its heme groups, similar to cyanide. Its inhibition is dose-dependent, but it remains a strong inhibitor at high levels.

Pearl PM0078: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: 172. The triad of abrasion, bruises, and puncture laceration wounds would be seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The triad of abrasion, bruises, and puncture laceration wounds is known as the Marshall's triad and it is is seen in bomb-blast injury. 

Marshall described the characteristic secondary blast injuries associated with bomb explosions. It includes:

* Abrasions

* Bruises/ contusions

* Puncture lacerations

Blast injuries are classified as:

* Primary injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures. External injuries are absent and are characterized by internal injuries. The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible to this.

* Secondary injuries- injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.

* Tertiary injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.

* Quaternary injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, gas, etc.

* The specific pulmonary injury of air blast is known as blast lung.

* When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.

* Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.

* Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: 173. What will be seen during rapid ascent to high altitude?
questions.solution:
Respiratory alkalosis will be seen during rapid ascent to high altitude.

At High Altitudes:

* The composition of air stays the same, but the total barometric pressure falls with increasing altitude, leading to a fall in PO2

* Hypoxic stimulation of the chemoreceptors under normal breathing causes increased ventilation

* Alveolar PO2 falls less rapidly, and the alveolar PCO2 declines because of the hyperventilation

* Fall in arterial PCO2 produces respiratory alkalosis

* To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, the kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion

questions.text: 174. A child is planned for cleft lip surgery. Which of the following muscle is first repaired?
questions.solution:
Orbicularis oris is the first muscle that is repaired in cleft lip surgery. 

A cleft lip is characterized by a partial or complete lack of circumferential continuity of the lip. The deformity involves the mucosa, orbicularis oris muscle, and skin. Hence, continuity of the orbicularis oris muscle is disrupted in babies born with a cleft lip. 

The main aim of cleft surgery is muscle reconstruction to correct the underlying anatomical abnormalities that can lead to issues with appearance and function. Cleft lip repair is performed between 3 and 6 months of age. Millard cleft lip repair is done by downward rotation of the medial portion of the lip and advancement of the lateral portion into the defect created by the rotation. It involves detachment of the orbicularis oris muscle’s abnormal attachments and creating a horizontal bridge across the cleft to form a complete sphincter around the mouth. Hence the first muscle that is repaired in cleft lip surgery is orbicularis oris. 

The image below shows the rotation-advancement procedure of Millard cleft lip repair. Flap A is moved between B and C, C is rotated slightly while B is pushed down to create the cupid's bow.

questions.text: 175. Gene pool refers to all the alleles in ________
questions.solution:
Gene pool refers to all the alleles in population. 

Gene pool is defined as the total genetic information present in all the breeding individuals of that population. This concept is central to sexually reproducing species, where individuals interbreed and share genetic material. The gene pool changes over time due to mutations, natural selection, genetic drift, and gene flow between populations. It reflects the overall genetic diversity and evolutionary potential of a population.

questions.text: 176. Which of the following nerves is not involved in olfaction?
questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve is not involved in olfaction.

The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) is a purely motor nerve that innervates the muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). It does not carry any sensory or special sensory (smell) fibers, and it has no anatomical or functional connection to the olfactory system. Therefore, it plays no role in the sense of smell. The other three cranial nerves—trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves are mixed cranial nerves and contribute to olfaction.

Other options:

Option A: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), particularly its ophthalmic and maxillary divisions, is involved in olfaction indirectly. While it does not detect odors, it carries general sensory information like pain, touch, and temperature from the nasal mucosa. Trigeminal fibers can detect noxious chemicals (like ammonia and sulphur dioxide), contributing to the perception of irritation or burning, which complements the sense of smell.

Option B: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries general sensation from the pharynx and larynx and can respond to strong irritants. Vagal nerve stimulation has been shown to modify the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

Option C: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) carries taste and general sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. While it is primarily involved in gustation, it can be indirectly involved in olfaction and contribute to the overall flavour of food.

questions.text: 177. In uncontrolled diabetes, in which of the following cells is there decreased glucose uptake due to insulin deficiency?
questions.solution:
There is decreased glucose uptake in skeletal muscle due to insulin deficiency. 

GLUT-4 is the transporter in skeletal muscle, heart and adipose tissue that is stimulated by insulin. A pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of insulin-sensitive cells. Insulin results in the transport of GLUT-4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane by activating phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase.

Insulin-sensitive tissues also contain a group of GLUT-4 vesicles that move into the cell membrane in response to exercise, leading to lower blood sugar after exercise. questions.text: 178. A 17 year old boy presents with leg pain and difficulty walking. His X-ray shows sunburst pattern and periosteal elevation (Codman’s triangle). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with X-Ray showing sunburst appearance and periosteal elevantion (Codman's triangle) is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. It has a bimodal age distribution peak in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.

It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal femur and humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle (image below) or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.



Other options:

Option A: Giant cell tumor:

It is a benign but locally aggressive tumour, commonly affecting the age group of 20-45 years. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings (image below): 

* Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis

* Soap bubble appearance

* Periosteal new bone formation is absent



Option B: Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 10-20 years and more frequently in males. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings (image below): Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.



Option D: Chondrosarcoma: It is the second most common primary malignant tumors that occurs in any site of the bone. It presents in 3rd to 8th decade of life and is slow growing, with deep pain and/or shows an enlarging mass. Most commonly involves proximal femur, pelvis and proximal humerus.

Radiographic findings (image below): Large, intraosseous and osteolytic tumors. Irregular and granular calcifications present which shows a characteristic “honeycomb” or “popcorn”appearance.

questions.text: 179. A patient underwent a bone marrow transplant without HLA matching. In which of the following disorders does transplant rejection not occur?
questions.solution:
Transplant rejection does not occur in Bare lymphocyte syndrome.

In a patient with bare lymphocyte disease, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to MHC class II deficiency on the lymphocytes.

Bare lymphocyte disease occurs due to mutations in transcription factors required for class II MHC gene expression. This results in the lack of class II MHC molecules, leading to the impaired development of CD4+ T cells. As these CD4+ T cells are required for both cellular immunity and for assisting B cells, class II MHC deficiency results in a combined immunodeficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Jobs Syndrome occurs due to inherited defects in Th17 responses, leading to chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis and bacterial infections of the skin.

Option B: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome is an X-linked disease characterised by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

Option D: Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterised by defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, resulting in defective phagocyte function and increased susceptibility to infections.

questions.text: 180. A young male presented to triage after an RTA, with a GCS 8/15. On examination, patient was unconscious, has absent breath sounds on the right side, is hypotensive with SBP 90 mm Hg and has an SpO₂ of 85%. What is the sequence of management?

choices.text: Secure airway, insert ICD and administer IV fluids
Take history, administer dextrose, and perform  eFAST
Perform CT- brain, then secure airway

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, decreased oxygen saturation (85%), GCS of 8/15 and absent breath sounds on the right side of the chest, with a history of a road traffic accident are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The next step of management in this case is to secure the airway, insert ICD and administer IV fluids

According to the latest ATLS guidelines, the order of primary survey in a trauma patient is ABCDE, identify life-threatening conditions:  

* Airway with cervical spine protection

* Breathing 

* Circulation with control of haemorrhage

* Disability(neurological status)

* Exposure to assess for other injuries and environmental 

This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8, which indicates a severely altered level of consciousness. As per ATLS, patients with severe head injuries who have an altered level of consciousness or a GCS score of 8 or lower usually require the placement of a definitive airway i.e., cuffed, secured tube in the trachea. Therefore, securing the airway is the first priority, with care taken to restrict cervical spine motion due to the mechanism of injury (road traffic accident).

After securing the airway, breathing can be assessed. The patient’s oxygen saturation of 85%, and absent breath sounds on the right side strongly suggests tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confrmation. Treatment consists of immediate decompression by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula into the second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line of the affected side, followed by insertion of a chest tube through the fifth intercostal space in the anterior axillary line. However, current teaching advocates undertaking decompression in the triangle of safety as shown in the image below:



Once the airway and breathing are secured, hemodynamic instability must be corrected by securing two large-bore peripheral venous catheters to maintain circulation. Other investigations, such as NCCT head and CT head, are done later on during further evaluation in the secondary survey.

questions.text:
181. What are the indications of a cochlear implant?

1. Congenital hearing loss  2. Aminoglycosides induced profound hearing loss 3. Otosclerosis  4. Congenital malleus fixation
questions.solution:
Congenital hearing loss and aminoglycosides-induced profound hearing loss are types of sensorineural hearing loss and are indications of a cochlear implant.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and for those who do not benefit from a hearing aid. It works by directly stimulating the auditory nerve and bypassing the cochlear hair cells that are damaged. The principle of the surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. An intact 8th nerve and the higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for surgery. 

Components of a Cochlear Implant are:

* External component: It consists of an external speech processor and a transmitter. 

* Internal component: It is surgically implanted and comprises the receiver/stimulator package with an electrode array.



The candidates for a cochlear implant should have the following features

* Severe or profound sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally

* No improvement with hearing aids 

* No medical contraindication for surgery

* Realistic expectation

* Good family and social support toward habilitation

* Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device

Other statements:

Statement 3: Otosclerosis leads to conductive hearing loss, and hence cochlear implant cannot be used.

Statement 4: Congenital malleus fixation leads to conductive hearing loss, and hence cochlear implant cannot be used.

Pearl PM1817: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:



Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC). The electrodes of the cochlear implant are placed in the scala tympani and are passed through the round window from the middle ear.

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

* Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)

* Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: 182. In a chronic limb ischemia patient, what is the ABPI below which it can cause imminent gangrene?
questions.solution:
In a chronic limb ischemia patient, ABPI (Ankle-brachial Pressure Index) below 0.3 can cause imminent gangrene.

The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of the systolic blood pressure at the ankle to that in the arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery serves as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator. It is used to assess patients who may be at risk for cardiovascular events. To measure it: 

* Blood pressure is taken in both upper limbs, and the highest systolic reading is used as the reference (denominator)

* An ankle cuff is placed just above the ankle to measure blood flow in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries

* A pencil doppler probe is used to detect the return of blood flow in each artery

* The systolic pressure from each ankle artery is divided by the highest arm systolic pressure to calculate the ABPI for both arteries

ABPI values can be clinically interpreted as:

* Between 0.5 and 0.7 is typically seen in patients with claudication.

* Between 0.3 and 0.5 is associated with rest pain.

* Below 0.3 is seen in patients with gangrene.

These values can vary depending on how compressible the vessels are and may be less reliable in individuals with heavily calcified arteries.

questions.text:
185. Which of the following statements are true about thalidomide?

1. Its immunosuppressive action is due to antimetabolite effects 2. Used in the management of refractory relapsing multiple myeloma 3. Used in the management of erythema nodosum leprosum 4. It is a teratogenic drug to fetus
questions.solution:
Statement 2, 3, 4 are correct about thalidomide. 

Thalidomide is currently used for treatment of erythema nodosum leprosum. It is also used in patients with newly diagnosed and heavily pretreated relapsed/ refractory multiple myeloma (MM).

Thalidomide originally was used for the treatment of pregnancy- associated morning sickness but was withdrawn from the market due to teratogenicity and dysmelia (stunted limb growth). 

Thalidomide is not an antimetabolite. Its antiangiogenic and has immunomodulatory effect due to the following proposed mechanisms: 

* Disruption of the antiapoptotic effect of BCL2 family members by blocking NF-κB signaling, and inhibition of the production of IL-6.

* Decreased angiogenesis due to the inhibition of cytokine and growth factor production and release

* Enhanced T-cell production of cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ

* Inhibition of MM cell adhesion to bone marrow stromal cells partially due to the reduction of IL-6 release

questions.text: 186. A young man presented with painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, with superficial erosions. Image as depicted. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young man complaining of painful genital vesicular lesions with superficial erosions, with histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Herpes genitalis (HSV-2), and the drug to be given is Acyclovir.

Acyclovir is the most frequently used for the treatment of HSV infections and is available in IV, oral, and topical formulations. Other drugs that can be used are ganciclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir. All these drugs are found to be effective in shortening the duration of symptoms and lesions of mucocutaneous HSV infections in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients

Herpes infection can be caused by the HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses.
