questions.text: 187. A thermometer factory worker presents with lethargy, coarse tremors, and cognitive difficulties. Which of the following features would point towards chronic mercury exposure?

choices.text: Hyperkeratosis and Mees lines on  nails
Lead line on bone X Ray

questions.solution:
Features like tremors and Mad Hatter's shake points towards chronic mercury poisoning.

Chronic mercury poisoning may result from continuous accidental absorption by the workers, excessive therapeutic use, from recovery from a large dose, and if ointment is used as external application for a long time. Features of mercury poisoning include:

* Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Mad Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.

* Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury. The industrial discharges of mercury into Minamata Bay in Japan became biomethylated to form methyl mercury, which then accumulated in fish. On consumption of these fishes, people developed visual deficits and several neurological manifestations such as loss of sensation, gait, memory, cognition, etc.

* Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.

* Mercurialentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

* Acrodynia or pink disease is thought to be an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction particularly seen in children, caused by chronic mercury exposure in any form. The onset is insidious with anorexia, insomnia, sweating, skin rash and photophobia. Hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, painful, paraesthetic with peeling of skin. 

Other options:

Option A: Hyperkeratosis and Mees lines on nails are seen in arsenic poisoning, not mercury. The image below shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning.



Option B and C: Lead line on bone X-ray and basophilic stippling are associated with lead poisoning.

questions.text: 188. Which technique is shown in the image below?

choices.text: Surface plasmon resonance for Ab affinity
Surface plasmon resonance for Ab concentration

questions.solution:
The image shows surface plasmon resonance done for Ab affinity. 

Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) is a method commonly used to detect affinity and reaction rates of antigen-antibody interactions. It works by detecting changes in reflectance at a metal surface (typically gold) coated with antigen, when antibody binds to it. This interaction alters surface plasmon waves, electromagnetic waves that propagate at the interface between the metal and solvent, making SPR sensitive to any molecular adsorption on the surface.

A beam of polarized light is directed through a prism onto the metal-coated chip. At a specific resonance angle, some light is absorbed to create surface plasmon waves. The angle shift caused by antibody binding is detected, and this change is proportional to the amount of bound antibody. The rate at which the resonance angle changes indicates the kinetics of binding.

A typical sensorgram from an SPR experiment has four stages:

* Stage I: Only buffer flows through; no antigen-antibody complexes form

* Stage II: Antibody is introduced, and complexes form. The slope of the curve represents the forward reaction rate (k₁)

* Stage III: Binding reaches saturation. The plateau height reflects antibody concentration

* Stage IV: Buffer without antibody is passed through. Complexes dissociate. The slope shows the dissociation rate (k₂)

The ratio k₁/k₂ = Ka, is the association constant.

questions.text: 189. H.pylori infects half of the global population. Why does H. pylori infection not lead to peptic ulcer disease in every infected person?

choices.text: Combination of host and environment factors
H-pylori colonises exclusively in gastric antrum
Most H. pylori infections are asymptomatic and resolve spontaneously
Due to concurrent use of NSAIDS

questions.solution:
H. pylori infection cannot lead to peptic ulcer disease in every infected person because of a combination of host and environmental factors. 

Nearly half of the global population harbors Helicobacter pylori within the gastric mucosa, where it can persist lifelong unless eliminated with suitable antibiotic therapy. This chronic colonization predisposes individuals to peptic ulcer disease, which, if left unmanaged, may progress to gastric adenocarcinoma or mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma.

Most H. pylori–colonised persons do not develop clinical sequelae. Some individuals develop overt disease, whereas others do not. This is related to a combination of factors: 

* Bacterial strain differences: Certain H. pylori virulence factors, like the cag pathogenicity island, increase disease risk. The CagA protein alters host cell signaling, causing inflammation and structural changes, while VacA forms pores in cell membranes. Strains with active CagA or VacA, along with adhesins like BabA, are more often linked to peptic ulcers and gastric cancer.

* Host susceptibility to disease: The host determinants of disease are genetic polymorphisms leading to enhanced activation of the innate immune response, including polymorphisms in cytokine genes and in genes encoding bacterial recognition proteins such as Toll-like receptors. For example, colonized people with polymorphisms in the interleukin 1 gene that increase the production of this cytokine in response to H. pylori infection are at increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

* Environmental factors: Environmental cofactors are important in pathogenesis. Smoking increases the risks of duodenal ulcers and gastric cancer in H. pylori–positive individuals. Diets high in salt and preserved foods increase cancer risk, whereas diets high in antioxidants and vitamin C are modestly protective.

Other options: 

Option B: H. pylori does not colonize exclusively in the gastric antrum. Its colonization pattern varies, and this variation affects disease outcomes—antral-predominant gastritis is linked to duodenal ulcers, while pan-gastritis or corpus-predominant gastritis is associated with gastric ulcers and cancer. 

Option C: Most infections are asymptomatic, but they do not usually resolve spontaneously without treatment. 

Option D: NSAIDs are an independent cause of gastric ulcers, not the reason why H. pylori doesn’t cause ulcers in every infected person. In fact, H. pylori is a well-established risk factor for ulcers, and eradicating it greatly reduces ulcer recurrence. While NSAID-related ulcers are increasing, especially in developed countries, they do not explain the variable outcomes of H. pylori infection.

questions.text: 191. Which of the following pulses can be best explained by Frank-Starling law?
questions.solution:
Pulsus Alternans can be explained by the Frank-Starling law. 

Frank-Starling law of the heart states relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume is best represented by the length-tension relationship. The volume of blood ejected by the ventricle depends on the volume present in the ventricle at the end of diastole. The length of the myocytes depends on the volume (and hence tension) present at the end of the diastole, which in turn, depends on the volume returned to the heart, or the venous return. It governs normal ventricular function and ensures that cardiac output equals venous return, within physiological limits.

Pulsus Alternans is seen in left ventricular dysfunction in heart failure and is characterised by alternating strong and weak pulses due to reduced left ventricular contraction in every other cardiac cycle. When the left ventricular contractility is reduced, there is a decrease in stroke volume, leading to a weak pulse and increased residual volume within the ventricles. This increase in residual volume leads to increased end-diastolic volume in the next cardiac cycle, leading to stronger ventricular contractility, greater stroke volume and a stronger pulse. Hence, pulsus alternans follows the Frank-Starling law of the heart.



Other options:

Option A: Pulsus Parvus refers to a weak pulse. Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus, which is seen as a low-amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.

Option B: Pulsus Bisferiens is a pulse with double peaks.

Option D: Pulsus Paradoxus refers to a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration.

questions.text: 192. A 5 year old boy came with perianal itching which gets worse at night. His mother sometimes notices white thread like structures near the perianal area. On examination there is redness and excoriation due to excessive scratching perianally. A cellophane tape test under microscopy revealed the following organism. What is the organism causing this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perianal itching which gets worse at night, white thread like structures near the perianal area, redness and excoriation due to excessive scratching perianally and cellophane tape test under microscopy revealing the given organism is suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection. 

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. They are oviparous. Man acquires infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. Its life cycle is shown below:



At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus and lays its sticky eggs on the perianal skin. This leads to pruritus and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

Since pinworms are rarely released in feces, fecal examination is not useful in the diagnosis. The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane is attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass slide and examined microscopically.The image given below shows the NIH swab.



Another method of demonstrating eggs is the scotch tape method. Here, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides, and transferred to a glass slide. A drop of toluene is added and examined under the microscope.The below image shows the scotch tape method.



The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

Frequent hand washing, fingernail cleaning, regular bathing, and frequent washing of night clothes and bed linen should be done. Infection can be treated with pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, or mebendazole as single-dose therapy.

Other options:

Option B: Ascaris typically causes abdominal discomfort or intestinal obstruction, not perianal itching. The worms are large and not seen near the anus. The life cycle is shown below.



Option C: Hymenolypis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm. Patients are usually asymptomatic. However, in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability. It does not cause nocturnal perianal itching or show up as thread-like worms externally. The life cycle is shown below.



Option D: Ancylostoma duodenale or hookworm infects a person by direct penetration of the skin by filariform larvae. They develop into adult worms in the small intestine, but they don't present as visible worms near the anus. They can cause severe local itching at the site of penetration, cutaneous larva migrans, and respiratory symptoms. Adult hookworm disease is characterized by anemia, epigastric pain, dyspepsia, vomiting, and reddish black stools. The life cycle is shown below.

questions.text: 193. A 30-year-old man presents with severe headache and vomiting. There is neck stiffness, photophobia and Brudzinski's sign is positive. CT head shows a small hydrocephalus but no haemorrhage. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a severe headache, vomiting, neck stiffness, photophobia and positive Brudzinski's sign, with CT head showing a small hydrocephalus but no haemorrhage, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Subarachnoid Haemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Other options:

Option A and B: Bacterial Meningitis is characterised by high fever, neck stiffness, and positive Brudzinski's sign. Viral encephalitis is characterised by a throbbing headache. Delayed neurologic deficits like small hydrocephalus and absence of fever are more associated with SAH rather than Bacterial meningitis and Viral encephalitis.  

Option D: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus leads to urinary incontinence, cognitive decline, and difficulty in walking.

questions.text: 194. A 30-year-old man complained of painful lesions on his palms and soles. He also gave a history of sexual contact and a transient genital lesion one month ago. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old man complaining of painful lesions on his palms and soles, with a history of sexual contact and a transient genital lesion one month ago, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be secondary syphilis. A serological test is most appropriate for him.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacterium. It is a sexually transmitted infection. A history of sexual contact and a transient genital lesion one month ago suggests a painless indurated chancre, which is usually single. This stage is primary syphilis, and the chancre heals spontaneously in 3–8 weeks.

Secondary syphilis is characterised by generalised manifestations that occur on the skin and mucous membranes. Rashes in secondary syphilis are non-itchy, coppery red in colour and symmetrical in distribution. These first appear at around 8 weeks. Constitutional symptoms include fever, headache and bone and joint pains that are more evident at night.

Serological testing is the most important screening test. It is done using a standard non-treponemal antibody test (VDRL, RPR) and a specific treponemal antibody test(TPHA, FTA-ABS). The VDRL slide test is widely used and requires the microscopic demonstration of antigen–antibody flocculation in heat-inactivated serum.

Reactivity to non-treponemal antibody tests develops 1–4 weeks after the chancre appears in primary syphilis. Specific treponemal antibody tests are qualitative procedures and detect antibodies to antigenic determinants of treponemes. They do not help assess treatment responses.

Treponema pallidum can be identified by dark-field microscopy. It shows corkscrew motility. Molecular amplification tests, like the Polymerase chain reaction, can also be used for identification, especially where interpretation of serological test results is difficult.

Primary syphilis:

* Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

* Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

* Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:



* A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.

* C & D: Condyloma lata.

* E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia

* F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.

* G: Pigmentary plaques

* H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

* Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

* Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor

* Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

* CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

* CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

* Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection

* Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: 195. Which one of the following is not an aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Bloom Syndrome is not an aneuploidy.

Bloom Syndrome is caused by a defect in DNA repair. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss-of-function mutations in a helicase that is required for homologous recombination repair. It leads to developmental anomalies and an increased risk of developing many different types of cancer.

Aneuploidy occurs due to an error in meiosis or mitosis, and a cell acquires a chromosome complement that is not an exact multiple of 23.

questions.text: 196. A 53 yr old farmer got a corneal transplant for healed fungal keratitis. What medium is used to store the donor corneal graft? What suture material is used to suture the donor corneal graft?
questions.solution:
The medium used to store the donor corneal graft is McCarey Kaufman medium, and the suture material used to suture the donor corneal graft is Nylon.

McCarey Kaufman medium is of pink colour and comprises Tissue culture-199, 5% Dextran-40, HEPES buffer (to adjust pH at 7.4), and gentamycin 0.1 mg/mL. Cornea can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank using various preservation techniques for different intervals:

* Short-term preservation (24 to 96 hours)- A moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium is used

* Intermediate-term preservation (up to 2 weeks)- Medium containing chondroitin sulphate is used

* Long-term preservation (up to months to years)- Preserved up to 1 year by cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or glycerol

Corneal transplantation, also known as keratoplasty, is the procedure in which the patient's diseased cornea is replaced by a healthy, clear cornea. The steps are:

* Excision of donor corneal button

* Excision of the recipient corneal button

* Suturing of corneal graft into the host bed is done with either continuous or interrupted 10-0 nylon sutures.

questions.text: 197. A 26-year-old male comes with pus in the urethral meatus and dysuria. He has a history of unprotected heterosexual activity 1 week back. Urinalysis shows plenty of pus cells, and culture for antimicrobial sensitivity shows resistance to penicillins. Gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci, which are mostly intracellular. Which will be the most appropriate management for him?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for him is Ceftriaxone.

The given clinical scenario of a male with a history of unprotected heterosexual activity, dysuria, urinalysis showing plenty of pus cells and gram stain showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Gonococcal urethritis, which is resistant to penicillins. 

Urethral discharge can be classified as gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, or nongonococcal urethritis, caused usually by Chlamydia trachomatis. Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted disease where infection occurs due to the adhesion of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces with the help of pili. By the third day of infection, the cocci have penetrated intracellular spaces and reached subepithelial tissue. The incubation period ranges from 2 to 8 days. The main symptoms are urethral discharge and dysuria.

In males, the disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection has the potential to spread down the urethra and into the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis. Chronic urethritis can lead to stricture formation. Infections in the periurethral tissues can lead to abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses known as watercan perineum.

In females, the infection begins in the cervix and urethra and may spread to the Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. The vaginal mucosa is usually unaffected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to cocci infection and also because vaginal secretions have an acidic pH. Rarely, peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation known as Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain, which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

The image below shows the Gram stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular Gram-negative diplococci.



Pearl PM2456: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

* It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.

* The ulcers are painful.



Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

* It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.

* The ulcers are usually painless.

* Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 

* Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:



Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

* Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.

* The ulcer is painful.

* Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.

* It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 

* Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance



Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

* It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.

* The ulcer is painless.

* Causes painless lymphadenopathy.

* Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.



Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

* It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.

* The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.

* Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:





Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

* It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.

* It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.

* The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

questions.text: 198. A 74-year-old female complains of lower back pain. STIR sequence MRI performed showed the Honda H sign. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Sacral insufficiency due to sacral compression fracture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female complaining of lower back pain and STIR sequence MRI showing the Honda H sign suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Sacral insufficiency due to sacral compression fracture.

Sacral insufficiency fractures are a subtype of stress fractures, which are the result of normal stresses on abnormal bone, most frequently seen in patients with osteoporosis. They are usually seen in elderly females who present with low back pain without any history of significant trauma. Risk factors include osteoporosis, rheumatoid arthritis, Paget's disease, osteomalacia, diabetes mellitus and history of radiation therapy.

A typical H-sign or Honda sign (uptake in H pattern) on Tc-99m MDP scan is shown below.



Other options:

Option B: Multiple myeloma presents with lytic punched-out lesions, mostly in the skull.

Option C: Osteomyelitis is characterised by the presence of sequestrum, involucrum, and cloacae.

Option D: Transient marrow edema syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion and generally presents in the vertebral bodies and bones of the extremities. It is characterized by pain and increased interstitial fluid within bone marrow without an obvious cause.

questions.text: 199. All of the following are cardinal symptoms of depression as per ICD-10 except:

choices.text: Low mood most of day and at all times

questions.solution:
Lack of self-esteem and confidence is not a cardinal symptom of depression as per ICD-10. 

According to the ICD-10 Classification of Mental and Behavioural Disorders, a depressive episode is typically diagnosed when at least two of the following three cardinal symptoms are present:

* Depressed mood (persistent low mood) to a degree that is definitely abnormal for the individual, present for most of the day and almost every day, largely uninfluenced by circumstances, and sustained for at least 2 weeks (Option C)

* Loss of interest or pleasure in activities that are normally pleasurable (Option A)

* Decreased energy or increased fatiguability. (Option D)

In addition, one or more of the following symptoms should also be present to make up a minimum total of four symptoms:

* Loss of confidence or self-esteem

* Unreasonable self-reproach or excessive and inappropriate guilt

* Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide, or any suicidal behaviour

* Diminished ability to think or concentrate (e.g. indecisiveness or vacillation)

* Psychomotor changes (agitation or retardation, subjective or observed)

* Sleep disturbances of any kind

* Change in appetite (increased or decreased), often with weight change

Loss of confidence and self-esteem is considered an additional symptom of depression in ICD-10, not one of the cardinal symptoms (Option B).

Pearl PM0496: Signs and symptoms of depression

Mnemonic "SIGECAPS"

Sleep disorder (increased or decreased)

Interest deficit (anhedonia): loss of interest in previously pleasurable activities

Guilt (worthlessness, hopelessness, regret)

Energy deficit

Concentration deficit

Appetite disorder (increased or decreased)

Psychomotor retardation or agitation

Suicidal tendency

questions.text:
200. In the following enterovirus, which causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?

1. Coxsackie A  2. Coxsackie B 3. Polio virus 4. Enterovirus 70
questions.solution:
Coxsackie A and Enterovirus 70 cause acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by Picornavirus, namely Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. 

A patient of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis presents with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling. On examination, conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple haemorrhages in the bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid oedema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy can be seen. 

It has a rapid onset and is usually self-limiting, running a course of 1-2 weeks. Broad-spectrum antibiotic eye drops can be used to prevent secondary bacterial infections.
